games.name: Texas Hold'em
games.description: The world's most popular poker variant, a community card game where each player receives two private hole cards and shares five community cards dealt face-up in three stages (flop, turn, river). Players strategically combine their two hole cards with any of the five community cards to make the best five-card poker hand. Betting rounds occur before the flop, after the flop, after the turn, and after the river, creating multiple opportunities for strategic play and bluffing. The player with the best hand wins the pot.

games.name: Blackjack
games.description: The classic casino card game where players compete against the dealer to get closer to 21 without busting. Players receive two cards face up while the dealer gets one face up and one face down (the hole card). Number cards are worth their face value, face cards (J, Q, K) are worth 10, and Aces can be worth 1 or 11. Players can hit (take another card), stand (keep current hand), double down (double their bet and take exactly one more card), or split pairs into two separate hands. The goal is to beat the dealer's hand without exceeding 21. A natural blackjack (Ace plus any 10-value card) pays 3:2 and typically wins immediately unless the dealer also has blackjack.

games.name: Klondike Solitaire
games.description: The classic and most recognizable single-player solitaire game, famously included in Windows. The game begins with 28 cards dealt into 7 tableau columns (with 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, and 7 cards respectively), with only the top card of each column face up. The remaining 24 cards form the stock pile. Players build four foundation piles from Ace to King by suit, and organize tableau columns in descending order with alternating colors (red and black). Face-up cards and complete sequences can be moved between columns. Stock cards are turned over three at a time, and the goal is to successfully move all 52 cards to the foundation piles.

games.name: Hearts
games.description: A classic trick-taking game for exactly four players where the goal is to avoid penalty cards. Each player receives 13 cards, and before play begins, players pass 3 cards to another player (typically left, right, or across depending on the round). The first player leads with any card except hearts, which cannot be led until they've been 'broken' (played on a different suit). Players must follow suit if possible, otherwise can play any card. The highest card of the led suit wins the trick. Each heart card is worth 1 penalty point, and the queen of spades is worth 13 penalty points. The player with the lowest score wins, and the game typically ends when a player reaches 100 points.

games.name: Spades
games.description: A strategic partnership trick-taking game for exactly four players in two teams. Each player receives 13 cards, and before play begins, players bid on how many tricks their partnership will take. Spades are always the trump suit, making them the most powerful cards. Players must follow suit if possible, and the highest card of the led suit or the highest spade wins the trick. Partnerships score 10 points for each trick they bid, but lose 10 points for each overtrick (tricks taken beyond their bid). A nil bid (bidding zero tricks) scores 100 points if successful, but loses 100 points if the player takes any tricks. The game requires careful communication and strategy between partners.

games.name: Go Fish
games.description: A fun and simple matching game perfect for children and families. Players are dealt 7 cards each (or 5 cards if playing with 3-4 players), with the remaining cards forming a draw pile. On your turn, you ask any other player for a specific rank (e.g., 'Do you have any sevens?'). If they have cards of that rank, they must give you all of them. If not, they say 'Go Fish!' and you draw a card from the draw pile. When you successfully collect all four cards of the same rank, you lay them down as a completed set. The game ends when all possible sets have been collected, and the player with the most sets wins.

games.name: War
games.description: An extremely simple two-player game of pure chance, perfect for young children. All cards are dealt evenly between the two players. Players simultaneously flip their top card face up, and the highest card wins both cards (Ace is high, followed by King, Queen, Jack, 10, 9, 8, 7, 6, 5, 4, 3, 2). When cards match in rank, it triggers a 'war': each player places three cards face down, then flips a fourth card face up. The player with the higher fourth card wins all the cards in play. The game continues until one player collects all 52 cards and wins.

games.name: Crazy Eights
games.description: A fast-paced shedding game where players try to be the first to discard all their cards. Each player receives 7 cards (or 5 cards if playing with just 2 players), and the top card of the remaining deck is turned up to start the discard pile. Players must match either the suit or rank of the top card, or play an 8, which acts as a wild card that can be played as any suit. If you cannot play a card, you must draw from the deck until you can play. The first player to successfully discard all their cards wins the round.

games.name: Rummy
games.description: A classic card-matching game where players aim to be the first to use all their cards by forming valid combinations. Each player receives 7 cards (or 10 cards if playing with just 2 players), with the remaining cards forming a stock pile and the top card starting a discard pile. On your turn, you draw either from the stock or the discard pile, then discard one card. Players form sets (three or more cards of the same rank) or runs (three or more consecutive cards of the same suit). Once you have valid combinations, you can lay them down on the table. The first player to discard all their cards wins, and remaining players count their leftover cards as penalty points.

games.name: Euchre
games.description: A fast-paced trick-taking game for exactly four players in partnerships, using a shortened deck of only 24 cards (9, 10, Jack, Queen, King, and Ace of each suit). Each player receives 5 cards, with the remaining 4 cards used to determine potential trump. Players bid on whether to accept the trump suit, and the highest bidder's suit becomes trump. The right bower (jack of the trump suit) and left bower (jack of the same color as trump) are the two highest cards. The partnership that makes the bid must win at least 3 tricks, or they are 'euchred' and lose points. The game is known for its quick rounds and strategic bidding.

games.name: Contract Bridge
games.description: The world's most sophisticated trick-taking card game, played by exactly four players in two partnerships. Each player receives 13 cards, and the game consists of two distinct phases. First is the auction phase, where players bid on the number of tricks they'll take and the trump suit (or no-trump). The highest bid becomes the contract. In the play phase, the declarer (the partnership that won the bid) tries to fulfill the contract, while the defenders attempt to prevent it. Scoring is complex, based on the contract level, suit, vulnerability, and whether the contract was made. The game is typically played in rubbers, making it a deep strategic experience requiring partnership communication and card play skills.

games.name: Five Card Draw
games.description: The classic original poker game that was the standard before community card games became popular. Each player receives 5 cards face down, followed by a betting round. Players then have the opportunity to discard and draw up to 5 new cards (or stand pat), followed by a final betting round. The best five-card poker hand wins according to standard rankings: Royal Flush, Straight Flush, Four of a Kind, Full House, Flush, Straight, Three of a Kind, Two Pair, One Pair, and High Card. This game emphasizes reading opponents and strategic discarding.

games.name: Omaha Hold'em
games.description: A popular community card poker variant similar to Texas Hold'em, but with a crucial difference: each player receives four private hole cards instead of two. Five community cards are dealt face-up in stages (flop, turn, river), and players must use exactly two of their hole cards combined with exactly three community cards to make their best five-card hand. This rule creates more potential hand combinations and makes the game more action-packed. Betting occurs before the flop, after the flop, after the turn, and after the river. The player with the best hand wins the pot.

games.name: Pinochle
games.description: A unique trick-taking game that uses a special 48-card deck containing two of each card from 9 through Ace in all four suits. Played by exactly four players in partnerships, each player receives 12 cards. The game features a bidding phase where players bid on the points they'll make through both melds (card combinations laid down before play) and tricks won during play. The trump suit is determined during bidding, and scoring includes points for aces, tens, kings, queens, jacks, and various meld combinations. The partnership that makes the bid must reach their bid total or lose points, making it a game of careful calculation and partnership coordination.

games.name: Canasta
games.description: A popular rummy-style card game played by four players in partnerships. Each player receives 11 cards, and the goal is to form melds (sets of three or more cards of the same rank). The game's namesake is the canasta, a meld of seven or more cards of the same rank, which scores bonus points. Red 3s are special bonus cards that must be laid down immediately, and jokers and 2s act as wild cards that can substitute for any card. Players draw from the stock, lay down melds when possible, and discard one card per turn. The first partnership to reach 5000 points wins the game, making it a longer, more strategic experience than standard rummy.

games.name: Cribbage
games.description: A distinctive scoring card game traditionally played with a special pegging board used to track points. The game can be played by two players or four players in partnerships. Each player receives 6 cards and discards 2 cards to the 'crib' (an extra hand that scores for the dealer). The dealer turns up a starter card, then players alternate playing cards, scoring points for pairs, runs, combinations that total exactly 15, and combinations that total 31. After the play phase, players count their hands (including the starter card) for additional points from pairs, runs, flushes, and combinations of 15. The crib scores for the dealer only. The first player or partnership to reach 121 points wins.

games.name: Gin Rummy
games.description: An elegant two-player rummy variant that emphasizes strategy and card counting. Each player receives 10 cards, and players take turns drawing from either the stock pile or the discard pile, then discarding one card. The goal is to form sets (three or more of the same rank) and runs (three or more consecutive cards of the same suit). When your deadwood (unmatched cards) totals 10 points or less, you can 'knock' to end the hand. Your opponent can then lay off any of their cards onto your sets or runs to reduce their deadwood. The player with the lower deadwood count wins the difference in points. Achieving 'gin' (having no deadwood at all) scores a significant bonus. The first player to reach 100 points wins the game.

games.name: Old Maid
games.description: A simple matching game perfect for children, where one queen is removed from the deck before play begins. All remaining cards are dealt to the players, and players immediately remove all pairs from their hands. Players then take turns drawing one card from the next player's hand. If the drawn card makes a pair with a card in your hand, you discard the pair. The game continues until all pairs have been matched and discarded. The unlucky player left holding the unmatched queen (the 'old maid') loses the game. The game combines luck with a bit of strategy in choosing which card to draw.

games.name: Slapjack
games.description: A fast-paced, action-packed game that tests players' reflexes and attention. All cards are dealt evenly among the players, and players take turns placing cards face up in a center pile. When a jack appears, the first player to slap it wins the entire center pile. However, if you slap incorrectly (when it's not a jack), you must give one card from your hand to the player who played the card. The game requires quick reactions and careful observation, as players must watch for jacks while avoiding false slaps. The player who successfully collects all the cards wins the game.

games.name: Spit
games.description: An intense, fast-paced two-player game that requires speed and quick thinking. Each player has a stock pile and a spit pile (face-up pile). Players simultaneously and continuously flip cards from their stock pile onto their spit pile, creating a race-like atmosphere. Cards can be played in either ascending or descending sequence on either of the two center spit piles, and players can play on either pile. The game moves at breakneck speed as both players try to be the first to play all cards from their stock pile. There's no taking turns—it's all about speed and seeing sequences quickly.

games.name: Seven Card Stud
games.description: A classic poker variant that was the most popular form of poker before Texas Hold'em took over. Each player receives two cards face down (hole cards) and one card face up to start (third street), followed by a betting round. Then players receive another face-up card (fourth street) and bet again. This pattern continues through fifth and sixth streets (each with a face-up card and betting round). Finally, players receive a seventh card face down (seventh street), followed by a final betting round. The unique aspect is that most cards are visible, allowing players to read opponents' hands and make informed decisions. The best five-card poker hand wins the pot.

games.name: Speed
games.description: A lightning-fast two-player card game that tests reflexes and quick thinking. Each player has a hand of 5 cards and a stock pile of 15 cards. Two center piles start with one card each face up. Players simultaneously play cards in ascending or descending sequence on either of the center piles, creating a competitive race. When you can't play any cards, you draw from your stock pile to replenish your hand. The game moves at a frantic pace as both players try to be the first to play all cards from their stock pile. There are no turns—both players play as fast as they can, making it an exciting test of speed and observation.

games.name: President
games.description: A social hierarchy game where players compete to get rid of all their cards first, establishing a ranking system that carries over to the next round. All cards are dealt, and the player with the 3 of clubs starts. Players play cards of the same rank (single cards, pairs, triples, etc.), and higher ranks beat lower ranks. If you can't beat the current play, you pass. The first player to run out of cards becomes the President in the next round, while the last player becomes the Scum. Between rounds, the Scum must give their two best cards to the President, and the President gives their two worst cards to the Scum, creating a dynamic where rankings can change dramatically.

games.name: Bullshit
games.description: A fun bluffing and deception game where players can lie about what cards they're playing. All cards are dealt, and the player with the Ace of spades starts. Players play cards face down while claiming a rank (e.g., 'three aces'). The next player must either play one rank higher (claiming the same number of cards) or call 'bullshit' if they suspect the previous player is lying. If bullshit is called and the player was indeed lying, they must take the entire pile. If they were telling the truth, the caller must take the pile. The first player to successfully discard all their cards wins, making it a game of risk, bluffing, and reading your opponents.

games.name: FreeCell
games.description: A popular solitaire variant that is theoretically winnable in most deals, thanks to four free cells that can temporarily store cards. All 52 cards are dealt into 8 columns (4 columns with 7 cards, 4 with 6 cards), all face up. The game features four free cells and four foundation piles. Players build foundation piles from Ace to King by suit, and build the tableau in descending order with alternating colors. The strategic use of free cells allows players to temporarily store cards and move sequences more effectively. The goal is to successfully move all cards to the foundation piles.

games.name: Spider Solitaire
games.description: A challenging solitaire game played with two decks (104 cards total), known for its difficulty and strategic depth. The game begins with 54 cards dealt into 10 columns (6 columns with 6 cards, 4 with 5 cards), with only the top card of each column face up. Players build sequences in descending order (any suit can be used), and when a complete sequence from King down to Ace of the same suit is formed, it is automatically removed from play. When no moves are available, players draw 10 more cards (one to each column). The goal is to successfully remove all eight complete sequences, making it one of the more difficult solitaire variants.

games.name: Pyramid Solitaire
games.description: A unique solitaire game where 28 cards are arranged in a pyramid shape with 7 rows, creating a triangular tableau. The remaining 24 cards form the stock pile. Players remove pairs of exposed cards (cards not covered by others) that total exactly 13. Kings are worth 13 and can be removed alone, while other pairs must total 13 (Queen+1, Jack+2, 10+3, 9+4, 8+5, 7+6). As cards are removed, previously covered cards become exposed. When no more pairs can be removed, players draw from the stock pile. The goal is to successfully remove the entire pyramid by pairing all cards.

games.name: Tri Peaks Solitaire
games.description: A visually appealing solitaire game where cards are arranged in three overlapping peaks, creating a distinctive triangular layout. One card is placed face up in the waste pile to start. Players remove cards from the peaks that are exactly one rank higher or lower than the current waste card (wrapping around so Ace can pair with King or 2). When no more moves are available, players draw a new card from the stock pile to become the new waste card. The goal is to successfully remove all cards from the three peaks, requiring careful planning to expose cards in the right order.

games.name: Razz
games.description: A Seven Card Stud variant where the lowest hand wins instead of the highest, creating an inverted poker experience. Aces are always low, and straights and flushes don't count against you (making them irrelevant). The best possible hand is A-2-3-4-5 (the wheel). The game follows the same structure as Seven Card Stud: each player receives two cards face down and one face up, followed by betting rounds after each subsequent card is dealt. Players make their best low five-card hand, and the lowest hand wins the pot. This reversal of traditional poker strategy makes it a unique and challenging variant.

games.name: Seven Card Stud Hi-Lo
games.description: A split-pot variant of Seven Card Stud where the pot is divided between the highest and lowest hands, doubling the strategic complexity. Aces can be used as either high or low cards. The best high hand and the best qualifying low hand (A-2-3-4-5, known as the wheel) each win half the pot. However, if no player has a qualifying low hand (five unpaired cards 8 or lower), the high hand takes the entire pot. This creates interesting situations where players must decide whether to pursue the high hand, the low hand, or try for both, making it one of the more strategic poker variants.

games.name: H.O.R.S.E.
games.description: A mixed poker game format that rotates through five different poker variants, testing players' versatility across multiple game types. The rotation follows the acronym H.O.R.S.E.: Hold'em, Omaha Hi-Lo, Razz, Seven Card Stud, and Seven Card Stud Hi-Lo. Each variant is played for a predetermined number of hands (typically 8-10) before rotating to the next game. This format is popular in high-stakes tournaments because it prevents players from specializing in just one game type, requiring mastery of multiple poker variants. The game rewards well-rounded poker skills and adaptability.

games.name: Chinese Poker
games.description: A unique poker variant where each player receives 13 cards and must arrange them into three separate hands without drawing or discarding. Players create a front hand (3 cards, which should be the worst), a middle hand (5 cards), and a back hand (5 cards, which should be the best). The back hand must beat the middle hand, and the middle hand must beat the front hand according to standard poker rankings. Players then compare each of their three hands against their opponent's corresponding hands. You win 1 point for each hand that beats your opponent's, and 3 bonus points for a sweep (winning all three hands). The game is typically played to an agreed-upon score.

games.name: Deuce to Seven Triple Draw
games.description: A lowball poker variant where the lowest hand wins, but with specific rules that make it challenging. Aces are always high (bad for low hands), and both straights and flushes count against you, making the best possible hand 7-5-4-3-2 of mixed suits (unsuited). Each player receives 5 cards, and there are three rounds of betting and drawing (where players can discard and receive new cards). After the final draw and betting round, the player with the best low hand wins the pot. This game is popular among professional poker players and requires careful card selection and reading of opponents' drawing patterns.

games.name: Badugi
games.description: A unique four-card lowball poker game that originated in Asia and has gained popularity worldwide. The goal is to make the lowest four-card hand, but with a crucial constraint: all four cards must be of different suits and different ranks. The best possible hand is A-2-3-4, each of a different suit. Each player receives 4 cards, and there are up to three drawing rounds where players can discard and draw new cards. The game uses a specific hand ranking system where a 'Badugi' (four different suits and ranks) beats any hand with pairs or same-suited cards. This creates an interesting strategic challenge of balancing low cards with suit and rank diversity.

games.name: Five Card Stud
games.description: An older poker variant that was popular before Seven Card Stud, featuring a simpler structure with fewer cards. Each player receives one card face down (the hole card) and one card face up, followed by a betting round. Players then receive three more face-up cards, with a betting round after each card. This means players have four visible cards and one hidden card, allowing for some reading of opponents' hands while maintaining an element of mystery. The best five-card poker hand wins the pot. While less complex than Seven Card Stud, it still requires skill in reading visible cards and managing betting rounds.

games.name: Courchevel
games.description: An Omaha Hold'em variant that adds an interesting twist by dealing the first flop card face up before the pre-flop betting round. Each player receives four hole cards (as in standard Omaha), but before any betting begins, one of the three flop cards is revealed. This gives players additional information to consider during pre-flop betting. After the pre-flop betting round, the remaining two flop cards are dealt, followed by the turn and river. Like standard Omaha, players must use exactly two of their hole cards combined with three community cards. This variant adds an extra layer of strategy to the pre-flop decision-making process.

games.name: Big O
games.description: An Omaha Hi-Lo variant that increases the action by giving each player five hole cards instead of four. Like Omaha Hi-Lo, the pot is split between the highest and lowest qualifying hands. However, players must use exactly two hole cards to make their high hand and exactly two (potentially different) hole cards to make their low hand. The best low hand is A-2-3-4-5 (the wheel). With five cards to choose from instead of four, players have more possibilities and the game tends to be more action-packed. This variant is popular in home games and some poker rooms, especially in the southern United States.

games.name: Irish Poker
games.description: A hybrid poker game that combines elements of both Texas Hold'em and Omaha, creating a unique strategic challenge. Each player receives four hole cards. During the first two betting rounds (pre-flop and flop), the game follows Hold'em rules, meaning players can use 0, 1, or 2 of their hole cards. However, after the turn card is dealt, the game switches to Omaha rules, requiring players to use exactly two hole cards to make their best hand. This transition creates interesting strategic decisions, as players must consider both game formats when making their pre-flop and flop decisions. The game tests versatility and adaptability in poker strategy.

games.name: Yukon
games.description: A solitaire variant similar to Klondike, but with the key advantage that all cards are dealt face up from the beginning, eliminating the element of chance. All 52 cards are dealt into 7 columns, with the first column having 1 card and subsequent columns having increasing numbers of cards. Since all cards are visible, players can plan their moves strategically. Players build foundation piles from Ace to King by suit, and build the tableau in descending order with alternating colors. Complete sequences can be moved between columns. There is no stock pile, so all moves must be made with the cards as initially dealt. The goal is to move all cards to the foundation piles.

games.name: Canfield
games.description: A challenging solitaire game named after the famous Canfield Casino in Saratoga Springs, New York. The game begins with 13 cards dealt face down as a reserve pile (with the top card turned face up), one card dealt to a foundation pile (which determines the starting rank for all foundations), and four cards dealt face up to the tableau. Players build foundation piles from the base card up by suit, and build the tableau in descending order with alternating colors. Cards are drawn from the reserve three at a time, and only the top card of each reserve group is available. The goal is to successfully move all cards to the foundation piles, making it a difficult but rewarding solitaire variant.

games.name: Klondike (Turn Three)
games.description: The standard version of Klondike Solitaire where stock cards are turned over three at a time instead of one, which is the default in most digital implementations. The game follows all the same rules as classic Klondike, but when drawing from the stock pile, three cards are revealed at once. However, only the top card of the three is available to play, and you must play through the three cards before moving to the next group. This makes the game significantly more challenging than the turn-one variant, as you have less access to the cards in the stock pile. It's the version most people are familiar with from computer solitaire games.

games.name: Accordion
games.description: A unique solitaire game where all 52 cards are dealt face up in a single row, creating a linear tableau. Players can stack a card on the card immediately to its left if they match in either suit or rank. Alternatively, players can stack a card on the card three positions to its left if they match. As cards are stacked, the row contracts like an accordion (hence the name). The game continues until no more moves are possible. The goal is to end with just one stack containing all 52 cards, which is extremely difficult and requires careful planning of the stacking sequence. It's a game of pure logic and spatial reasoning.

games.name: Golf
games.description: A solitaire game with a golf-themed scoring system where the goal is to achieve the lowest possible score. Seven columns of 5 cards each are dealt face up, and one card is placed face up in the waste pile. Players remove cards from the tableau that are exactly one rank higher or lower than the current waste card. Kings and Aces are considered adjacent (wrapping around), so a King can be removed when an Ace is showing, and vice versa. When no more cards can be removed, a new card is drawn from the stock to become the waste card. The goal is to remove all tableau cards, and the game is scored based on how many cards remain in the stock when you finish (lower is better, like golf).

games.name: Scorpion
games.description: A challenging solitaire game similar to Spider Solitaire, but played with a single deck and featuring face-down cards that add an element of mystery. All 49 cards are dealt into 7 columns, with the first 4 columns having 7 cards each and the last 3 columns also having 7 cards each. The top 3 cards of the first 4 columns are dealt face down, while all other cards are face up. Players build sequences in descending order (any suit can be used), and when a complete sequence from King to Ace of the same suit is formed, it is removed. Only face-up sequences can be moved. The goal is to reveal all face-down cards and remove all eight complete sequences, making it a test of both strategy and patience.

games.name: Forty Thieves
games.description: A challenging two-deck solitaire game that uses 104 cards (two standard decks), significantly increasing the complexity and difficulty. The game begins with 10 columns of 4 cards each, all dealt face up. Players build foundation piles from Ace to King by suit, and build the tableau in descending order by suit (unlike Klondike which uses alternating colors). Only one card can be moved at a time (no sequences), making it more restrictive. Empty spaces can be filled with any card. The goal is to successfully move all 104 cards to the foundation piles, requiring careful planning and patience.

games.name: Baker's Game
games.description: A FreeCell variant that changes the tableau building rules, making it more restrictive but also more strategic. Like FreeCell, the game features four free cells and four foundation piles, with all 52 cards dealt into 8 columns. However, unlike FreeCell which builds the tableau in descending order with alternating colors, Baker's Game requires building in descending order by the same suit. This restriction makes the game more challenging, as you can only stack cards of the same suit in sequence. The goal is to move all cards to the foundation piles, and the strategic use of free cells becomes even more critical.

games.name: Seahaven Towers
games.description: A FreeCell-like solitaire game that increases the tableau size and provides reserve cells for strategic card storage. The game begins with 10 columns of 5 cards each, all dealt face up, creating a larger playing area than FreeCell. Four foundation piles and four reserve cells are available. Players build foundation piles from Ace to King by suit, and build the tableau in descending order with alternating colors. The reserve cells can temporarily store cards, allowing players to free up tableau spaces and move sequences more effectively. The goal is to successfully move all cards to the foundation piles.

games.name: Monte Carlo
games.description: A unique solitaire game played on a 5x5 grid, creating a spatial puzzle element. Twenty-five cards are dealt face up in a grid formation. Players remove pairs of cards that are adjacent (horizontally, vertically, or diagonally) and have the same rank. After removing pairs, the remaining cards shift to close up the gaps, and new cards are dealt from the stock to fill the grid back to 25 cards. The game continues until no more pairs can be removed. The goal is to successfully remove all cards from the deck, requiring both luck and strategic planning of which pairs to remove to create new adjacent pairs.

games.name: Castle
games.description: A solitaire game with a distinctive layout featuring 8 columns of 6 cards each, all dealt face up from the start. Four foundation piles are available, and players build them from the base card up by suit (the base card is determined by the first card dealt to each foundation). The tableau is built in descending order with alternating colors, and complete sequences can be moved between columns. Since all cards are visible from the beginning, players can plan their strategy carefully. The goal is to successfully move all 52 cards to the foundation piles.

games.name: Streets and Alleys
games.description: A Klondike variant that eliminates the stock pile and deals all cards face up, making it a game of pure strategy. The game begins with 8 columns: the first column has 1 card, and the remaining 7 columns each have 7 cards. All cards are dealt face up, so there's no hidden information. Players build foundation piles from Ace to King by suit, and build the tableau in descending order with alternating colors. Complete sequences can be moved. Without a stock pile to draw from, all moves must be made with the cards as initially dealt, making it more challenging than standard Klondike but also more strategic since you can see everything from the start.

games.name: Westcliff
games.description: A challenging two-deck solitaire game that uses 104 cards (two standard decks), significantly increasing the complexity. The game begins with 10 columns of 5 cards each, all dealt face up. Players build foundation piles from Ace to King by suit (with 8 foundation piles total, one for each suit from both decks). The tableau is built in descending order with alternating colors, and empty spaces must be filled immediately with any available card. The goal is to successfully move all 104 cards to the foundation piles, making it one of the more difficult solitaire variants due to the large number of cards and the requirement to fill spaces immediately.

games.name: King Albert
games.description: A Klondike variant named after King Albert I of Belgium, featuring all cards dealt face up in 9 columns. The first column has 1 card, and each subsequent column has one more card, with the last column having 9 cards. Since all cards are visible from the start, players can plan their entire strategy. Players build foundation piles from Ace to King by suit, and build the tableau in descending order with alternating colors. Complete sequences can be moved between columns. There is no stock pile, so all moves must be made with the cards as initially dealt. The goal is to move all cards to the foundation piles.

games.name: Klondike (Turn One)
games.description: An easier variant of Klondike Solitaire where stock cards are turned over one at a time instead of three, significantly improving the win rate. The game follows all the same rules as classic Klondike, but when drawing from the stock pile, only one card is revealed at a time. This gives players access to every card in the stock pile, rather than being limited to the top card of groups of three. Players can go through the stock pile multiple times, cycling through all cards. This variant is much more winnable than the turn-three version and is preferred by players who want a better chance of success while still enjoying the classic Klondike experience.

games.name: 500 Rummy
games.description: A points-based rummy variant where players score positive points for melds (sets and runs) and negative points for unmelded cards left in hand. Each player receives 7 cards (or 13 cards if playing with just 2 players). On your turn, you draw from either the stock pile or the discard pile, then can lay down melds and lay off cards on existing melds (your own or opponents'). You must discard one card to end your turn. Cards have specific point values (face cards are typically 10, aces 15 or 1, number cards their face value). The first player to reach 500 points wins the game. Unmelded cards in your hand when someone goes out count as negative points, so going out first is advantageous.

games.name: Kalooki
games.description: A rummy variant popular in Jamaica and the Caribbean that uses jokers as wild cards and requires an initial meld threshold. Each player receives 13 cards, and two jokers are included in the deck as wild cards that can represent any card. Players must form sets (three or more of the same rank) and runs (three or more consecutive cards of the same suit). Before you can lay off cards on your own melds, you must first make an initial meld worth at least 40 points. The first player to go out (discard their last card) wins the hand. Jokers are valuable as wild cards but have a high point value if left in your hand when someone goes out, so using them strategically is important.

games.name: Canasta Rummy
games.description: A simplified version of Canasta that maintains the core mechanics but with streamlined rules. Each player receives 11 cards, and the game is played in partnerships. Players form melds of three or more cards of the same rank. Canastas (melds of seven or more cards) score bonus points. Jokers and 2s act as wild cards that can substitute for any card. Red 3s are special bonus cards that must be laid down immediately and score extra points. The game uses two decks with jokers, and the first partnership to reach 5000 points wins. It's a faster, more accessible version of the classic Canasta game.

games.name: Oklahoma Rummy
games.description: A contract rummy variant where each round features a specific contract that must be completed before a player can go out. Each player receives 7 cards, and each round has a predetermined contract such as two sets, one set and one run, two runs, etc. Players must complete their contract before they can go out (discard their last card). The scoring is similar to 500 Rummy, with points for melds and penalties for unmelded cards. The game is played over multiple rounds, and the first player to reach 500 points wins. This adds a strategic element as players must balance completing their contract with going out quickly.

games.name: Contract Rummy
games.description: A structured rummy variant played over exactly 7 rounds, with each round requiring a progressively more difficult contract. Each player receives 10 cards per round. The contracts typically progress: two sets, one set and one run, two runs, three sets, two sets and one run, one set and two runs, and three runs (though variations exist). Players must complete their contract before they can meld any other cards. If you fail to complete your contract, you receive penalty points. After all 7 rounds, the player with the lowest total score wins. This game rewards consistency and careful planning across multiple rounds.

games.name: Shanghai Rummy
games.description: A challenging rummy variant played over 10 rounds, with contracts that become progressively more difficult as the game advances. Each player receives 11 cards per round. The contracts start simple (like two sets) and become increasingly complex (such as three sets and two runs). Players must complete their contract before they can go out, and they can lay off cards on their own melds. Unmelded cards left in hand when someone goes out count as penalty points. After all 10 rounds are completed, the player with the lowest total score wins. The progressive difficulty makes it a test of both skill and endurance.

games.name: Manila Rummy
games.description: A rummy variant that requires players to make a substantial initial meld before they can lay off additional cards on their own melds. Each player receives 13 cards. Players form sets (three or more of the same rank) and runs (three or more consecutive cards of the same suit). Before you can lay off cards on your own melds, you must first make an initial meld worth at least 51 points. Going out requires discarding your last card after all your other cards are melded. The first player to go out wins the hand, and other players count their unmelded cards as penalty points. The high initial meld requirement makes it more challenging than standard rummy.

games.name: Whist
games.description: A classic English trick-taking game that was the predecessor to Bridge and remains popular today. The game is played by exactly four players in two partnerships. Each player receives 13 cards, and the last card dealt to the dealer is turned face up to determine the trump suit for that hand. If the turned card is a spade, the hand is played with no trump. Players must follow suit if possible, and the highest card of the led suit or the highest trump card wins the trick. The partnership that takes the most tricks wins the hand. Whist is known for its simplicity and elegance, making it accessible to players of all skill levels.

games.name: Call Partner Euchre
games.description: A variant of Euchre designed for 5-6 players that adds a hidden partnership element. The game uses the same 24-card deck as standard Euchre (9, 10, Jack, Queen, King, Ace of each suit). Before play begins, the dealer calls out a card that is not in their hand. The player holding that card becomes the dealer's secret partner, but this partnership is not revealed until the called card is actually played. The game then proceeds as a partnership game, with the dealer and their secret partner playing against the other players. This hidden partnership element adds intrigue and makes the game more social and unpredictable.

games.name: Partnership Pinochle
games.description: The classic partnership version of Pinochle, played by exactly four players in two teams. The game uses a special 48-card deck containing two of each card from 9 through Ace in all four suits. Each player receives 12 cards. The game features a bidding phase where players bid on the points they'll make through both melds (card combinations) and tricks. The trump suit is determined during bidding. After bidding, players lay down their melds and then play tricks. Scoring combines points from melds and tricks won. The first partnership to reach 150 points wins the game. Partnership Pinochle requires excellent communication and coordination between partners.

games.name: Sheepshead
games.description: A traditional German trick-taking game for exactly five players that features bidding and a kitty (blind cards). The game uses a 32-card deck (7, 8, 9, 10, Jack, Queen, King, Ace of each suit). Each player receives 6 cards, and 2 cards are dealt to the kitty. Players bid to become the 'picker,' who takes the kitty and plays against the other four players. The trump suit is determined during bidding, and the jack of the trump suit (right bower) is the highest card. The picker must win a majority of tricks to succeed. Sheepshead is particularly popular in Wisconsin and other areas with German heritage, and it's known for its complex scoring and strategic depth.

games.name: Skat
games.description: Germany's national card game, a sophisticated three-player trick-taking game with complex bidding and scoring. The game uses a 32-card deck (7, 8, 9, 10, Jack, Queen, King, Ace of each suit). Each player receives 10 cards, and 2 cards are dealt to the skat (a blind kitty). An elaborate bidding process determines the declarer, who plays alone against the other two players. The declarer can choose to play with a trump suit, without a trump suit (grand), or with a specific suit as trump. The scoring system is highly complex, based on the game type, the value of cards taken, and whether the declarer made their bid. Skat is considered one of the most intellectually demanding card games.

games.name: Tarot
games.description: A traditional French trick-taking game played with a specialized 78-card tarot deck, which includes the standard 52 cards plus 21 trump cards and a fool card. The game is played by four players, with each player receiving 18 cards and 6 cards going to the 'dog' (kitty). A bidding process determines the declarer, who plays against the other three players. The 21 trump cards (numbered 1-21) act as a permanent trump suit, with higher numbers beating lower numbers. The fool is a special card that can be played to avoid following suit. The scoring system is complex, based on the bid, the value of cards taken, and various bonus conditions. Tarot is particularly popular in France and other European countries.

games.name: Belote
games.description: France's most popular card game, a trick-taking game for exactly four players in partnerships. The game uses a 32-card deck (7, 8, 9, 10, Jack, Queen, King, Ace of each suit). Cards are dealt in two phases: first 5 cards to each player, then 3 more cards. A bidding process determines the trump suit. The game features unique trump rankings where the jack of trump (belote) and the 9 of trump are the two highest cards, followed by the other trump cards in standard order. Players must follow suit if possible. The partnership that scores the most points through tricks and special combinations wins. Belote is deeply embedded in French culture and is played in cafes and homes throughout France.

games.name: Klaverjas
games.description: The national card game of the Netherlands, a trick-taking game for exactly four players in partnerships. The game uses a 32-card deck (7, 8, 9, 10, Jack, Queen, King, Ace of each suit). Each player receives 8 cards. The trump suit is determined by the suit of the first card played in the first trick, making the opening lead crucial. Like Belote, the jack and 9 of the trump suit are the two highest cards. Players must follow suit if possible. The game features special scoring for tricks and particular card combinations. Klaverjas is extremely popular in the Netherlands and is often played in social clubs and cafes.

games.name: Doppelkopf
games.description: A popular German trick-taking game for four players that uses a double deck (48 cards total - two of each 9, 10, Jack, Queen, King, Ace). Each player receives 12 cards. The game has a unique feature where all queens and jacks are permanent trumps, regardless of suit, creating a large trump suit. Teams are not fixed partnerships but are determined during play based on which players have certain cards (typically the queens of clubs). Players must follow suit if possible. The game is scored based on tricks taken, with special scoring for particular card combinations. The first team to reach 501 points wins. Doppelkopf is particularly popular in northern Germany and is known for its social, party-game atmosphere.

games.name: Oh Hell
games.description: A classic trick-taking game with bidding that's also known as 'Oh Pshaw' or 'Up and Down the River.' The number of cards dealt varies by round, typically starting with one card and increasing each round, then decreasing back down. Each player bids on the exact number of tricks they'll take in that round. Players must follow suit if possible. The unique scoring feature is that you only score points if you make your exact bid - you get points for being right, but lose points if you take too many or too few tricks. The game is played over multiple rounds, and the player with the highest total score wins. It's a game that rewards accurate prediction and careful play.

games.name: Wizard
games.description: A modern trick-taking game that uses a standard deck plus 4 special wizard cards (which always win tricks) and 4 jester cards (which always lose tricks). The number of cards dealt varies by round, typically starting with one card and increasing. Each player bids on the exact number of tricks they'll take. During play, wizards beat everything (and the highest wizard wins if multiple are played), while jesters lose to everything. Players must follow suit if possible, but wizards and jesters can be played at any time. You score points only if you make your exact bid. The player with the most points after all rounds wins. The special cards add chaos and strategy to the traditional trick-taking format.

games.name: Memory
games.description: A classic memory and concentration game, also known as Concentration or Pairs, that tests players' ability to remember card positions. The deck is shuffled and all cards are laid face down in a grid formation. Players take turns flipping two cards face up. If the two cards match in rank (same number or face card), the player keeps the pair and takes another turn. If they don't match, both cards are flipped back face down, and play passes to the next player. The game requires careful observation and memory as players try to remember where specific cards are located. The player who collects the most pairs wins the game. It's an excellent game for children and helps develop memory skills.

games.name: Snap
games.description: A fast-paced matching game that tests players' reflexes and attention. All cards are dealt evenly among players, and players take turns simultaneously flipping their top card face up into a central pile. When two cards of the same rank appear consecutively in the pile, the first player to shout 'Snap' wins the entire pile. The game requires quick reactions and careful observation as players must watch for matching ranks while managing their own cards. The player who successfully collects all the cards wins the game. It's a simple but exciting game perfect for children and parties.

games.name: Beggar My Neighbor
games.description: A simple but engaging children's card game that relies on luck and can create dramatic swings. All cards are dealt evenly among players, and players take turns placing their top card face up in a central pile. The game's unique mechanic involves face cards: when a Jack, Queen, King, or Ace is played, the next player must 'pay' a certain number of cards (typically 1 for Jack, 2 for Queen, 3 for King, and 4 for Ace). If the paying player reveals another face card, the payment obligation passes to the next player. If no face card appears during the payment, the player who played the original face card wins the entire pile. The game continues until one player runs out of cards and loses. Despite its simplicity, the game can create exciting moments when face cards chain together.

games.name: Pigs
games.description: A fast-paced matching game perfect for children and parties, where players simultaneously pass cards and try to collect four of a kind. All cards are dealt evenly among players. On each turn, all players simultaneously pass one card to the player on their left. When a player successfully collects four cards of the same rank, they quietly put a finger on their nose. The last player to notice and put their finger on their nose loses the round. The game is played over multiple rounds, and it's a test of both speed and observation as players must watch for the nose signal while continuing to pass cards.

games.name: Spoons
games.description: An extremely fast-paced and chaotic matching game that requires quick reflexes and attention. Place one fewer spoon than the number of players in the center of the table. Each player receives 4 cards. Players simultaneously pass one card to the left on each turn. When a player collects four of a kind, they grab a spoon from the center. As soon as one spoon is taken, all other players must grab a spoon as well. The player left without a spoon receives a letter, starting with 'S'. Players who spell out 'SPOONS' are eliminated. The game is known for its frenetic energy and the potential for minor injuries from enthusiastic spoon-grabbing.

games.name: Egyptian Ratscrew
games.description: A fast-paced slapping game that tests reflexes and can get quite competitive. All cards are dealt evenly among players. Players take turns placing cards face up in a central pile. When two cards of the same rank appear consecutively, the first player to slap the pile wins all the cards in the pile. Face cards (Jack, Queen, King, Ace) trigger special rules: when a face card is played, the next player must play another face card within a certain number of cards, or the player who played the face card wins the pile. The player who successfully collects all the cards wins. The game is known for being fast, loud, and occasionally painful for enthusiastic slappers.

games.name: Uno (with standard deck)
games.description: A version of the popular Uno card game adapted to use a standard playing card deck. Assign colors to suits (typically red suits represent one color, black suits another, or assign specific colors to each suit). Each player receives 7 cards. Players match either the color (suit) or rank of the top card. Special cards have specific functions: 8s act as skip cards, Jacks reverse the direction of play, Queens force the next player to draw 2 cards, and Kings are wild cards that can be played on any card and allow you to choose the color. The first player to discard all their cards wins. When you have one card left, you must say 'Uno' or draw penalty cards if caught.

games.name: Mao
games.description: A unique shedding game where the rules are secret and must be discovered through play, making it a game of observation and deduction. Each player receives 5-7 cards. Players take turns playing cards that match either the suit or rank of the top card. However, there are numerous secret rules (such as saying 'Mao' when playing certain cards, or specific actions required for certain plays) that players must figure out by watching others. When you break a rule, you draw penalty cards, but you're not told which rule you broke. The first player to discard all their cards wins and gets to add a new secret rule to the game for future rounds. The game evolves and becomes more complex over time.

games.name: Presidents and Assholes
games.description: A variant of President with more explicit hierarchy names, creating a social dynamic game where players compete to get rid of all their cards first. The player who goes out first becomes the President, while the last player to go out becomes the Asshole. Between rounds, the President gives their two worst cards to the Asshole, and the Asshole must give their two best cards to the President. This creates a self-reinforcing hierarchy where the President has an advantage in subsequent rounds, while the Asshole is at a disadvantage. The game continues until players decide to stop, and the social dynamics often become as important as the card play itself.

games.name: Scum
games.description: A hierarchy-based shedding game similar to President, where players compete to get rid of all their cards first. All cards are dealt evenly, and the player with the 3 of clubs starts. Players play cards of the same rank (single cards, pairs, triples, etc.), and higher ranks beat lower ranks. If you can't beat the current play, you pass. The first player to discard all their cards becomes the President, while the last player becomes the Scum. In the next round, the Scum deals the cards and must give their best card to the President before play begins. This creates a social hierarchy that persists across rounds.

games.name: Tichu
games.description: A popular Chinese shedding game for exactly four players in partnerships that combines elements of poker and trick-taking games. Each player receives 8 cards, and 8 cards are dealt face down (not used in that hand). Players can make bold predictions: calling 'Tichu' means you'll be the first to go out, while 'Grand Tichu' is called before looking at your cards. Players discard cards by playing combinations (single cards, pairs, straights, etc.), and higher combinations beat lower ones. The first team to reach 1000 points wins. Tichu is known for its strategic depth, partnership play, and the high-stakes predictions that can dramatically swing the score.

games.name: Concentration
games.description: A classic memory and matching game, also known as Memory or Pairs, that tests players' ability to remember card positions. All cards are laid face down in a grid formation. Players take turns flipping two cards face up. If the two cards match in rank (same number or face card), the player keeps the pair and takes another turn. If they don't match, both cards are flipped back face down, and play passes to the next player. The game requires careful observation and memory as players try to remember where specific cards are located. The player who collects the most pairs wins. It's an excellent game for developing memory skills and is suitable for all ages.

games.name: Casino
games.description: A classic Italian card capturing game, also popular in English-speaking countries, where players capture cards from the table by matching ranks or building combinations. Each player receives 4 cards, and 4 cards are dealt face up on the table. On your turn, you can capture cards by playing a card of the same rank, building combinations that total a specific value, or taking all cards of a suit if you have the right card. Scoring is based on capturing the most cards, the most spades, aces, the big casino (10 of diamonds worth 2 points), and the little casino (2 of spades worth 1 point). The game combines strategy, memory, and mathematical calculation.

games.name: Scopa
games.description: One of Italy's most beloved card games, a capturing game where players capture cards from the table that total a specific value. Each player receives 3 cards, and 4 cards are dealt face up on the table. On your turn, you play one card to capture one or more table cards that total the value of your card, or you place your card on the table if you can't capture. If you capture all the cards on the table, it's called a 'scopa' (broom) and is worth 1 bonus point. Scoring includes points for most cards captured, most diamonds captured, the settebello (7 of diamonds), and the primiera (best combination of one card from each suit). The first player or team to reach 11 points wins.

games.name: Briscola
games.description: A popular Italian trick-taking game that can be played by three or four players. Each player receives 3 cards, and one card is turned up to determine the trump suit. Players play tricks, and must follow suit if possible. The highest card of the led suit or the highest trump card wins the trick. Only certain cards are worth points: aces are worth 11 points, 3s are worth 10 points, and face cards (King, Queen, Jack) are worth 4, 3, and 2 points respectively. All other cards are worth 0 points. The game is played over multiple hands, and the first player or team to reach 60 points wins. Briscola is simple to learn but requires strategic card play.

games.name: Trente-et-Un
games.description: A French card game similar to blackjack, where players try to get as close to 31 as possible, but with the important constraint that all cards must be of the same suit. Each player starts with 3 cards. Face cards (King, Queen, Jack) are worth 10 points each, and aces are worth 11 points. Number cards are worth their face value. Players can draw additional cards or stand with their current hand. The goal is to have the highest total value with all cards of the same suit, without exceeding 31. If you go over 31, you're out. The best hand wins, and the game can be played for stakes. It's a game of risk management and suit management.

games.name: Cheat
games.description: A classic bluffing and deception game, also known as 'I Doubt It' or 'Bullshit,' where players can lie about what cards they're playing. All cards are dealt evenly among players, and the player with the ace of spades starts. Players play cards face down while claiming a rank (e.g., 'three aces'). The next player must either play one rank higher (claiming the same number of cards) or call 'cheat' if they suspect the previous player is lying. If cheat is called and the player was indeed lying, they must take the entire pile. If they were telling the truth, the caller must take the pile. The first player to successfully discard all their cards wins. It's a game of psychology, risk assessment, and keeping a poker face.

games.name: Spit in the Ocean
games.description: A Five Card Draw poker variant that adds a wild card element through a community card. Each player receives 4 cards, and one card is dealt face up in the center of the table (the 'spit card'). The rank of this spit card becomes wild for all players throughout the hand. This means if the spit card is a 7, all 7s in the deck are wild cards. The game follows standard Five Card Draw structure with betting rounds before and after the draw. Players make their best five-card hand using the spit card rank as wild. This creates interesting strategic decisions as players know which rank is wild from the start, making it easier to make strong hands.

games.name: Baseball
games.description: A Seven Card Stud poker variant with baseball-themed rules that create action-packed hands. In this game, 3s and 9s are wild cards (representing 'strikes' and 'innings' or '3 outs' and '9 innings'). Additionally, if you receive a 4 face-up, you get a 'free card' - meaning you can see your next card without having to bet. The game follows standard Seven Card Stud structure with betting rounds after each card. With multiple wild cards in play, high-value hands like four of a kind and straight flushes are much more common than in standard poker. The best five-card hand wins, and the game is known for creating exciting, high-stakes situations.

games.name: Follow the Queen
games.description: A Seven Card Stud poker variant that features dynamic wild card determination. When a queen is dealt face up to any player, the next card dealt (regardless of to whom) determines which rank becomes wild for the remainder of that hand. For example, if a queen is turned up and the next card is a 5, then all 5s become wild cards. If another queen appears face up later, the wild card rank can change again based on the next card dealt. This creates constantly shifting strategic situations as players must adapt to changing wild card ranks. The game follows standard Seven Card Stud betting structure, and the best five-card hand wins.

games.name: Lowball
games.description: A poker variant where the lowest hand wins instead of the highest, inverting traditional poker strategy. The specific rules vary by variant (such as Ace-to-Five Lowball or Deuce-to-Seven Lowball), but the core concept is that players want to make the worst possible hand according to standard poker rankings. Aces can typically be used as low cards, and the best low hand is usually A-2-3-4-5 (the wheel). Straights and flushes may or may not count against you depending on the variant. Lowball can be played in various formats including Draw, Stud, and community card games. The player with the lowest qualifying hand wins the pot.

games.name: High-Low Split
games.description: A poker variant where the pot is split between the player with the highest hand and the player with the lowest qualifying hand, creating dual objectives for players. The game can be played in various formats including Five Card Draw, Seven Card Stud, or community card games. Aces can be used as either high or low cards, giving players flexibility in pursuing both high and low hands. The best high hand and the best qualifying low hand (typically A-2-3-4-5, known as the wheel) each win half the pot. If no player has a qualifying low hand (usually requiring five unpaired cards below 8), the high hand takes the entire pot. This variant requires players to balance their strategy between pursuing high and low hands simultaneously, making it more complex than standard poker.

games.name: Stud Horse
games.description: A Seven Card Stud Hi-Lo variant where the pot is split between the highest and lowest hands, but with a specific constraint: players must use exactly two cards from their hand to make their high hand and exactly two (potentially different) cards to make their low hand. Aces can be used as either high or low cards. The best high hand and the best qualifying low hand (typically A-2-3-4-5) each win half the pot. If no player has a qualifying low hand, the high hand takes the entire pot. This variant requires players to balance their strategy between pursuing high and low hands simultaneously.

games.name: Cowboy Poker
games.description: A Five Card Draw poker variant where all face cards (Jacks, Queens, and Kings) are wild cards, creating action-packed hands with frequent high-value combinations. The game follows standard Five Card Draw structure with betting rounds before and after the draw phase. With 12 wild cards in the deck (4 of each face card rank), players frequently make strong hands like four of a kind, straight flushes, and even five of a kind. The best five-card hand wins the pot. The abundance of wild cards makes this a high-action game where even modest starting hands can become winners after the draw.

games.name: Deuces Wild
games.description: A popular Five Card Draw poker variant where all four 2s (deuces) are wild cards, making it easier to form strong hands. The game follows standard Five Card Draw structure with betting rounds before and after the draw. With four wild cards available, high-value hands are common. The hand rankings are slightly modified: four deuces is the second-best possible hand, losing only to a natural five of a kind (which would require all five cards of the same rank without using wild cards, which is extremely rare). The best five-card hand wins the pot. Deuces Wild is popular in both home games and some casino poker rooms.

games.name: One-Eyed Jacks
games.description: A Five Card Draw poker variant named after the specific cards that are wild: the one-eyed jacks (jack of hearts and jack of spades, which show only one eye in profile) and the suicide king (king of hearts, which shows the king holding a sword to his head). These three specific cards act as wild cards throughout the game. The game follows standard Five Card Draw structure with betting rounds. The best five-card hand wins. This variant is popular in home games and adds an interesting twist by making only specific cards wild rather than entire ranks, requiring players to remember which cards are wild.

games.name: Night Baseball
games.description: A variant of Baseball poker that adds an extra layer of wild card determination. Like standard Baseball, 3s and 9s are wild, and 4s dealt face down allow a free card (no betting required). However, in Night Baseball, the last card dealt to any player determines an additional wild card rank. For example, if the last card dealt is a 7, then all 7s also become wild cards. This creates even more action and higher-value hands than standard Baseball. The game follows Seven Card Stud structure with betting rounds, and the best five-card hand wins. The dynamic wild card determination adds strategic depth as players must adapt to the final wild card rank.

games.name: Chicago
games.description: A Seven Card Stud variant that adds a side pot element based on hidden spades. In addition to competing for the best poker hand, players also compete for the highest spade that is face down (in the hole). The pot is split between the player with the highest spade face down and the player with the best five-card hand. If the same player has both the highest hidden spade and the best hand, they win the entire pot. The game follows standard Seven Card Stud structure with betting rounds. This variant adds an extra strategic element as players must consider both their hand strength and their hidden spade when making betting decisions.

games.name: Razzle Dazzle
games.description: A poker variant that combines Razz (lowball) and Seven Card Stud (high) in alternating hands, testing players' versatility in both directions. Each hand alternates between Razz rules (where the lowest hand wins, with aces low and straights/flushes not counting) and standard Seven Card Stud rules (where the highest hand wins). The pot is split between the best high hand and the best low hand, so players must pursue both strategies. This variant requires players to be skilled in both high and low poker, making it a true test of all-around poker ability. It's popular among experienced players who enjoy the challenge of switching strategies.

games.name: Countdown
games.description: A progressive Five Card Draw poker variant where the wild cards count down from aces to deuces over multiple hands. In the first hand, all aces are wild. In the second hand, all kings are wild. The pattern continues down through queens, jacks, 10s, 9s, 8s, 7s, 6s, 5s, 4s, 3s, and finally deuces (2s). The final hand is played with no wild cards at all. The best hand wins each round. This creates an interesting progression where players start with many wild cards and gradually transition to standard poker, requiring adaptation to changing game conditions. It's typically played as a tournament format with elimination or scoring across all hands.

games.name: Criss Cross
games.description: A unique poker variant where cards are dealt in a cross pattern, creating a distinctive layout. Each player receives 5 cards arranged in a cross formation, with one card in the center that is shared and visible to all players. This center card's rank becomes wild for all players throughout the hand. The game includes betting rounds, and players make their best five-card hand using the center card rank as wild. The cross pattern layout and shared wild card create interesting strategic decisions as all players know which rank is wild from the start. The best five-card hand wins the pot.

games.name: Dime Store
games.description: A Five Card Draw poker variant where all four 10s (dimes) are wild cards. The game follows standard Five Card Draw structure with betting rounds before and after the draw phase. With four wild cards available, players frequently make strong hands. Four 10s is an extremely powerful hand (essentially four of a kind with all wild cards), second only to five of a kind. The best five-card hand wins the pot. This variant is popular in home games and creates action-packed hands with frequent high-value combinations.

games.name: Dutch Straight
games.description: A Five Card Draw poker variant that uses modified hand rankings compared to standard poker. The game follows standard Five Card Draw structure with betting rounds, but the hand rankings are adjusted. Typically, a flush beats a full house (opposite of standard poker), and other rankings may be modified. The best hand according to these special rankings wins the pot. This variant is popular in some regions and adds an interesting twist by inverting or modifying traditional poker hand values.

games.name: Iron Cross
games.description: A poker variant where cards are dealt in a cross pattern, creating a distinctive layout. Each player receives 5 cards arranged in a cross formation with one card in the center. The center card's rank becomes wild, and all other cards of that same rank throughout the deck are also wild. This means if the center card is a 7, then all four 7s in the deck are wild cards. The game includes betting rounds, and players make their best five-card hand using the wild cards. The best hand wins the pot. The cross layout and shared wild card create interesting strategic decisions.

games.name: Kentucky Derby
games.description: A Five Card Draw poker variant with horse racing-themed wild card rules. The specific wild card rules vary by house rules, but typically involve certain cards becoming wild based on the round or specific conditions. The game follows standard Five Card Draw structure with betting rounds before and after the draw. The best five-card hand wins the pot. This variant is popular in home games and adds excitement through its themed wild card mechanics.

games.name: Lazy Susan
games.description: A progressive Five Card Draw poker variant where the wild card rank rotates each hand, like a lazy susan rotating on a table. The wild cards progress through the ranks: first hand all aces are wild, second hand all kings are wild, then queens, jacks, and so on down through the ranks. Each hand follows standard Five Card Draw structure with betting rounds. The best five-card hand wins each round. This variant requires players to adapt their strategy as the wild cards change, making it a dynamic and engaging format for multi-hand play.

games.name: Little Chicago
games.description: A variant of Chicago poker with modified scoring rules. Like standard Chicago, players compete for both the best poker hand and the highest spade that is face down (in the hole). The player with the highest hidden spade splits the pot with the player who has the best five-card hand. The scoring or split mechanics may differ slightly from standard Chicago. The game follows Seven Card Stud structure with betting rounds. This variant maintains the dual-objective gameplay of Chicago while offering a slightly different scoring experience.

games.name: Mustache
games.description: A Five Card Draw poker variant named for the facial hair theme, where all kings (which often show mustaches) and the one-eyed jacks (jack of hearts and jack of spades) are wild cards. This gives players 6 wild cards total (4 kings and 2 one-eyed jacks). The game follows standard Five Card Draw structure with betting rounds before and after the draw. With multiple wild cards, high-value hands are common. The best five-card hand wins the pot. This variant is popular in home games and adds a fun thematic element to the wild card selection.

games.name: Omaha Hi-Lo
games.description: A popular split-pot variant of Omaha Hold'em where the pot is divided between the highest and lowest qualifying hands. Each player receives four hole cards, and five community cards are dealt. Players must use exactly two of their hole cards combined with three community cards to make their high hand, and exactly two (potentially different) hole cards combined with three community cards to make their low hand. Aces can be used as either high or low. The best high hand and the best qualifying low hand (A-2-3-4-5, known as the wheel) each win half the pot. If no player has a qualifying low hand (five unpaired cards 8 or lower), the high hand takes the entire pot. This variant is extremely popular in both cash games and tournaments.

games.name: Pineapple
games.description: A community card poker variant similar to Texas Hold'em, but with an interesting twist: each player receives three private hole cards instead of two. After the flop (first three community cards) is dealt, players must discard one of their hole cards, leaving them with two hole cards for the remainder of the hand. The game then continues with the turn and river community cards, following standard Hold'em betting structure. Players must use exactly two of their remaining hole cards combined with three community cards to make their best five-card hand. This variant adds strategic depth as players must decide which hole card to discard after seeing the flop, making it more complex than standard Hold'em.

games.name: Crazy Pineapple
games.description: A variant of Pineapple poker that adds an extra layer of strategic decision-making. Like standard Pineapple, each player receives three private hole cards. However, in Crazy Pineapple, players discard one hole card after the flop (first three community cards) and then discard another hole card after the turn (fourth community card), leaving them with just one hole card for the river. Players must use exactly two hole cards combined with three community cards to make their best five-card hand, but since they only have one hole card remaining after the turn, they must use that one hole card plus one of the two previously discarded cards (which are set aside but still part of their hand). This creates complex strategic situations as players must plan their discards carefully throughout the hand.

games.name: Lazy Pineapple
games.description: A simplified variant of Pineapple poker that removes the discarding mechanic. Each player receives three private hole cards, just like in standard Pineapple, but players keep all three cards throughout the entire hand without discarding any. Five community cards are dealt in the standard Hold'em fashion (flop, turn, river). Players must use exactly two of their three hole cards combined with three community cards to make their best five-card hand. This variant is called 'Lazy' because it eliminates the strategic decision of which card to discard, making it simpler than standard Pineapple while still offering more hand combinations than traditional Hold'em due to the extra hole card.

games.name: Courchevel Hi-Lo
games.description: A split-pot variant of Courchevel poker that combines the unique Courchevel structure with high-low split rules. Like standard Courchevel, the first card of the flop is exposed before the pre-flop betting round, giving players additional information. Each player receives five hole cards (Omaha-style), and the pot is split between the player with the best high hand and the player with the best qualifying low hand. Players must use exactly two hole cards for both their high hand and their low hand (though they can be different cards for each). Aces can be used as either high or low cards. The best high hand and the best qualifying low hand (typically A-2-3-4-5) each win half the pot. If no player has a qualifying low hand, the high hand takes the entire pot.

games.name: Six Plus Hold'em
games.description: A fast-paced Hold'em variant that uses a shortened 36-card deck (removing all cards from 2 through 5, keeping only 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, Jack, Queen, King, and Ace). Each player receives two hole cards, and five community cards are dealt in the standard Hold'em fashion. The reduced deck creates modified hand rankings: a flush beats a full house (because flushes are harder to make with fewer cards), and three of a kind beats a straight (because straights are easier to make). The game follows standard Hold'em betting structure with pre-flop, flop, turn, and river betting rounds. Six Plus Hold'em is popular in high-stakes games and online poker rooms, known for its action-packed nature and frequent big hands.

games.name: Short Deck Hold'em
games.description: Another name for Six Plus Hold'em, a popular Hold'em variant that uses a shortened 36-card deck (removing all cards from 2 through 5). The game follows the same structure as Six Plus Hold'em: each player receives two hole cards, five community cards are dealt, and the modified hand rankings apply (flush beats full house, three of a kind beats straight). The reduced deck creates more action and bigger hands, making it particularly popular in high-stakes cash games and tournaments. The name 'Short Deck' refers to the smaller deck size, and the game has gained significant popularity in recent years, especially in Asian poker markets and high-roller events.

games.name: Drawmaha
games.description: A hybrid poker game that combines elements of Omaha and Five Card Draw, creating a unique and complex variant. Each player receives five private hole cards, similar to Omaha. The game includes community cards (flop, turn, river) like Omaha, but players also have the option to discard and draw new cards like in Draw poker. Players must use exactly two hole cards combined with three community cards to make their best five-card hand, following Omaha's rule.
