The combination of community cards and the draw mechanic creates interesting strategic situations where players must balance improving their hand through both the community cards and the draw phase. Betting occurs at multiple stages throughout the hand.

games.name: Dramaha
games.description: A variant of Drawmaha with slight rule variations that maintains the core hybrid structure of combining Omaha and Draw poker elements. Like Drawmaha, each player receives five hole cards, and the game includes both community cards and a draw phase. Players must use exactly two hole cards combined with three community cards to make their best five-card hand, following Omaha's requirement. The specific rule variations from standard Drawmaha may involve the timing of the draw phase, betting structure, or other minor adjustments. The game combines the strategic depth of Omaha with the hand improvement opportunities of Draw poker, creating a complex and action-packed variant.

games.name: Round of Each
games.description: A rotating poker format that cycles through different poker variants each hand, testing players' versatility and adaptability across multiple game types. The rotation typically includes popular variants like Texas Hold'em, Omaha, Seven Card Stud, Five Card Draw, and other poker games. Each hand is played according to the rules of the current variant, and then the game moves to the next variant in the rotation. This format rewards players who are skilled in multiple poker variants rather than specializing in just one. It's popular in mixed game formats and home games where players want variety, and it prevents any single player from dominating by being an expert in just one game type.

games.name: 8-Game Mix
games.description: A comprehensive mixed poker format that rotates through eight different poker variants, each played for a set number of hands before moving to the next. The standard rotation includes: Limit Hold'em, Limit Omaha Hi-Lo, Razz (lowball Stud), Seven Card Stud, Seven Card Stud Hi-Lo, No Limit Hold'em, Pot Limit Omaha, and No Limit 2-7 Single Draw. This format is popular in both live and online poker rooms, particularly in high-stakes mixed game events. The 8-Game Mix tests players' skills across a wide range of poker variants, requiring expertise in both high and low games, limit and no-limit betting structures, and community card, stud, and draw formats. It's considered one of the most challenging poker formats and is featured in prestigious tournaments like the World Series of Poker.

games.name: Auld Lang Syne
games.description: A challenging solitaire game that begins with all cards dealt face up in 8 columns of 6 cards each, providing full visibility of the layout from the start. Four foundation piles are available to build from Ace to King by suit. The tableau columns are built in descending order with alternating colors (red and black). When a space opens in the tableau, it must be filled immediately with any available card. The game requires careful planning and strategic card movement since all cards are visible from the beginning, eliminating the element of hidden cards found in many solitaire variants. The goal is to successfully move all 52 cards to the foundation piles.

games.name: Beleaguered Castle
games.description: A solitaire game where all 52 cards are dealt face up at the start, creating a challenging puzzle with full information. The cards are arranged into 8 columns: the first and last columns each have 6 cards, while the middle 6 columns each have 7 cards. All cards are visible from the beginning. Four foundation piles are available to build from Ace to King by suit. The tableau columns are built in descending order with alternating colors (red and black). There is no stock pile, so all moves must be made using the cards already on the table. The game requires careful sequencing and planning since you can see all cards but have limited movement options. The goal is to successfully move all cards to the foundation piles.

games.name: Blockade
games.description: A straightforward solitaire game that begins with all 52 cards dealt face up into 13 piles of 4 cards each, providing complete visibility of the layout. Four foundation piles are available to build from Ace to King by suit. The tableau piles are built in descending order with alternating colors (red and black). When a space opens in the tableau, it can be filled with any available card. The game's simplicity comes from having all cards visible from the start, but the challenge lies in the strategic sequencing of moves to free up cards and build the foundations. The goal is to successfully move all cards to the foundation piles.

games.name: Cruel
games.description: A challenging solitaire game that lives up to its name with a difficult layout and limited movement options. The game begins with 12 cards dealt face up in the tableau, while the remaining 40 cards form the stock pile. Four foundation piles are available to build from Ace to King by suit. The tableau is built in descending order with alternating colors (red and black). Cards from the stock are turned over one at a time, and each card can either be played to the foundations, moved to the tableau, or discarded if it cannot be used. The game's difficulty comes from the limited tableau space and the need to carefully manage the stock pile. The goal is to successfully move all 52 cards to the foundation piles.

games.name: Deuces
games.description: A solitaire game with a unique foundation building pattern that starts with deuces (2s) instead of aces. The game begins with 8 columns of 6 cards each, all dealt face up, providing full visibility of the layout. Four foundation piles start with the four deuces (2s), one for each suit. Foundations are built upward by suit from 2 to Ace, then continue downward from King to 3, creating a complete cycle. The tableau columns are built in descending order with alternating colors (red and black). The game requires careful planning to build the foundations in both directions. The goal is to successfully move all 52 cards to the foundation piles, completing the full cycle from 2 to Ace and then from King to 3.

games.name: Easthaven
games.description: A FreeCell-like solitaire game that combines strategic planning with the use of reserve cells. The game begins with 8 columns of 7 cards each, all dealt face up, providing full visibility of the layout. Four foundation piles are available to build from Ace to King by suit. The tableau is built in descending order with alternating colors (red and black). Four reserve cells are available to temporarily store cards, which is crucial for managing the tableau and freeing up cards for the foundations. The strategic use of these reserve cells is key to success, as they allow you to move cards around and access cards that would otherwise be blocked. The goal is to successfully move all 52 cards to the foundation piles.

games.name: Fortress
games.description: A challenging two-deck solitaire game that requires managing 104 cards. The game begins with all cards dealt face up into 10 columns of 5 cards each, providing complete visibility of the layout. Eight foundation piles are available (one for each suit) to build from Ace to King. The tableau columns are built in descending order with alternating colors (red and black). When a space opens in the tableau, it must be filled immediately with any available card. The game's difficulty comes from managing twice as many cards as standard solitaire while maintaining the strategic sequencing needed to free up cards and build the foundations. The goal is to successfully move all 104 cards to the foundation piles.

games.name: Gaps
games.description: A unique solitaire game that focuses on arranging cards in sequential order rather than building foundation piles. All 52 cards are dealt face up in 4 rows of 13 cards each. The four aces are immediately removed and placed in a foundation row at the top. The remaining 48 cards are arranged in the tableau. The goal is to move cards to fill gaps in the tableau, but only cards that are exactly one rank higher than the card to the left can fill a gap. For example, if there's a gap after a 5 of hearts, only a 6 of hearts can fill it. As cards are moved, new gaps are created, allowing further movement. The ultimate goal is to arrange all cards in sequence by suit, with each suit running from Ace to King in order.

games.name: Grandfather's Clock
games.description: A solitaire game with a unique clock-themed layout where 12 piles are arranged in clock positions (representing the 12 hours). Each pile contains 4 cards, with the top card face up and the rest face down. One foundation pile is available in the center. The foundation is built from the base card (the card revealed when the first card is moved to the foundation) upward by suit, wrapping around from King to Ace if necessary. The tableau piles are built in descending order with alternating colors (red and black). Cards can be turned over from the tableau piles as they become available. The goal is to successfully move all 52 cards to the single foundation pile, creating a challenging game with limited foundation space.

games.name: Klondike by Threes
games.description: A variant of Klondike Solitaire that increases the difficulty by turning over stock cards three at a time instead of one at a time. The game follows the same basic structure as standard Klondike: 28 cards are dealt into 7 tableau columns, four foundation piles are built from Ace to King by suit, and the tableau is built in descending order with alternating colors. However, when going through the stock pile, cards are turned over in groups of three, and you can only access the top card of the three. This means you must use or pass over cards in the group before accessing the cards beneath them, making the game more challenging than the turn-one variant. The goal remains to move all 52 cards to the foundation piles.

games.name: Labyrinth
games.description: A complex solitaire game that lives up to its name with intricate movement rules and strategic challenges. The game begins with 8 columns of 6 cards each, all dealt face up, providing full visibility of the layout. Four foundation piles are available to build from Ace to King by suit. The tableau columns are built in descending order with alternating colors (red and black). The game's complexity comes from its movement rules, which may involve restrictions on which cards can be moved, how sequences can be transferred, or when spaces can be filled. These complex rules create a puzzle-like experience where players must carefully plan their moves to navigate through the 'labyrinth' of cards. The goal is to successfully move all 52 cards to the foundation piles.

games.name: Miss Milligan
games.description: A challenging two-deck solitaire game that requires managing 104 cards with strategic planning. All cards are dealt face up into 8 columns of 7 cards each, providing complete visibility of the layout from the start. Eight foundation piles are available (one for each suit) to build from Ace to King. The tableau columns are built in descending order with alternating colors (red and black). When a space opens in the tableau, it must be filled immediately with any available card. The game's difficulty comes from managing twice as many cards as standard solitaire while maintaining careful sequencing to free up cards and build the foundations. The goal is to successfully move all 104 cards to the foundation piles.

games.name: Napoleon at St. Helena
games.description: A challenging solitaire game named after Napoleon's exile, reflecting its difficult nature. The game begins with all 52 cards dealt face up into 8 columns of 6 cards each, providing full visibility of the layout. Four foundation piles are available to build from Ace to King by suit. The tableau columns are built in descending order with alternating colors (red and black). There is no stock pile, so all moves must be made using only the cards already on the table. This constraint makes the game particularly challenging, as you cannot rely on additional cards from a stock to help free up blocked cards. The game requires careful planning and strategic sequencing to successfully move all 52 cards to the foundation piles.

games.name: Odessa
games.description: A FreeCell variant that combines strategic planning with reserve cell management. The game begins with 8 columns of 7 cards each, all dealt face up, providing full visibility of the layout. Four foundation piles are available to build from Ace to King by suit. The tableau columns are built in descending order with alternating colors (red and black). Four reserve cells are available to temporarily store cards, which is essential for managing the tableau and freeing up cards for the foundations. The strategic use of these reserve cells is crucial, as they allow you to move cards around and access cards that would otherwise be blocked. The goal is to successfully move all 52 cards to the foundation piles.

games.name: Red and Black
games.description: A challenging two-deck solitaire game that requires managing 104 cards with strategic card movement. All cards are dealt face up into 8 columns of 7 cards each, providing complete visibility of the layout from the start. Eight foundation piles are available (one for each suit) to build from Ace to King. The tableau columns are built in descending order with alternating colors (red and black), which gives the game its name as players must alternate between red and black suits. When a space opens in the tableau, it can be filled with any available card. The game requires careful planning to manage twice as many cards as standard solitaire while building all eight foundation piles. The goal is to successfully move all 104 cards to the foundation piles.

games.name: Sir Tommy
games.description: A simple and straightforward solitaire game that serves as an excellent introduction to solitaire. The game begins with 4 cards dealt face up in a tableau. Four foundation piles are available to build from Ace to King by suit. The remaining 48 cards form the stock pile, which is turned over one card at a time. Each card from the stock can either be moved to a foundation pile (if it's the next card in sequence for that suit) or placed in a waste pile. The simplicity of the game comes from its minimal tableau and straightforward rules, but it still requires strategic decisions about when to use cards from the stock versus when to hold them. The goal is to successfully move all 52 cards to the foundation piles.

games.name: Streets
games.description: A Klondike variant that increases difficulty by dealing all cards face up and eliminating the stock pile. The game begins with 8 columns: the first column has 1 card, while the remaining 7 columns each have 7 cards. All cards are dealt face up, providing complete visibility of the layout. Four foundation piles are available to build from Ace to King by suit. The tableau columns are built in descending order with alternating colors (red and black). There is no stock pile, so all moves must be made using only the cards already on the table. This constraint makes the game more challenging than standard Klondike, as you cannot rely on additional cards from a stock to help free up blocked cards. The goal is to successfully move all 52 cards to the foundation piles.

games.name: Thumb and Pouch
games.description: A challenging two-deck solitaire game that requires managing 104 cards with strategic planning. All cards are dealt face up into 10 columns of 5 cards each, providing complete visibility of the layout from the start. Eight foundation piles are available (one for each suit) to build from Ace to King. The tableau columns are built in descending order with alternating colors (red and black). When a space opens in the tableau, it can be filled with any available card. The game's difficulty comes from managing twice as many cards as standard solitaire while maintaining careful sequencing to free up cards and build all eight foundation piles. The goal is to successfully move all 104 cards to the foundation piles.

games.name: Tower
games.description: A solitaire game with a distinctive tower-like layout that creates a visually interesting and strategically challenging game. The game begins with 8 columns of 6 cards each, all dealt face up, providing full visibility of the layout. Four foundation piles are available to build from Ace to King by suit. The tableau columns are built in descending order with alternating colors (red and black). The tower-like structure of the columns creates interesting movement patterns as players work to free up cards and build the foundations. The game requires careful planning and strategic sequencing to successfully navigate through the tower structure. The goal is to successfully move all 52 cards to the foundation piles.

games.name: Vegas Solitaire
games.description: A scoring variant of Klondike Solitaire that adds a monetary element to the classic game. The game follows the same basic structure as standard Klondike: 28 cards are dealt into 7 tableau columns, four foundation piles are built from Ace to King by suit, and the tableau is built in descending order with alternating colors. However, Vegas Solitaire uses a scoring system: you start with -52 dollars (representing the cost to play), and you win 5 dollars for each card successfully moved to a foundation pile. Additionally, you can only go through the stock pile once, making the game more challenging than standard Klondike. The goal is to finish with a positive score (make money) by moving as many cards to the foundations as possible, ideally all 52 cards for a maximum score of 208 dollars.

games.name: Will o' the Wisp
games.description: A challenging two-deck solitaire game named after the elusive will-o'-the-wisp, reflecting its tricky and sometimes elusive nature. All cards are dealt face up into 8 columns of 7 cards each, providing complete visibility of the layout from the start. Eight foundation piles are available (one for each suit) to build from Ace to King. The tableau columns are built in descending order with alternating colors (red and black). When a space opens in the tableau, it can be filled with any available card. The game requires careful planning and strategic sequencing to manage 104 cards while building all eight foundation piles. The goal is to successfully move all 104 cards to the foundation piles, which can be as elusive as the will-o'-the-wisp itself.

games.name: Yukon Turn One
games.description: A variant of Yukon Solitaire with slight rule variations that maintains the core gameplay of the original. Like standard Yukon, all cards are dealt face up from the start, providing complete visibility of the layout. Four foundation piles are available to build from Ace to King by suit. The tableau is built in descending order with alternating colors (red and black). The specific rule variations from standard Yukon may involve the initial layout, movement rules, or other minor adjustments. The game requires strategic planning and careful sequencing to free up cards and build the foundations. The goal is to successfully move all 52 cards to the foundation piles.

games.name: Tien Len
games.description: A popular Vietnamese shedding game, also known as 'Thirteen' or 'Vietnamese Cards', that combines elements of poker and traditional shedding games. The game is played by exactly four players, with each player receiving 13 cards. The player holding the 3 of spades starts the game. Players can play various combinations: single cards, pairs, triples, straights (sequences of consecutive cards), flushes (cards of the same suit), and full houses. Higher combinations beat lower ones, and players must beat the previous play or pass. The first player to successfully discard all their cards wins the hand. The game requires strategic thinking about when to play high cards versus saving them, and how to sequence your combinations to maximize your chances of going out first.

games.name: Big Two
games.description: A popular Chinese shedding game, also known as 'Choi Dai Di' or 'Big Deuce', that combines elements of poker and traditional card games. The game is played by exactly four players, with each player receiving 13 cards. The player holding the 3 of diamonds starts the game. Players can play various combinations: single cards, pairs, triples, straights (sequences of consecutive cards), flushes (cards of the same suit), and full houses. The unique feature is that 2s (deuces) are the highest-ranking cards, higher than aces. Higher combinations beat lower ones, and players must beat the previous play or pass. The first player to successfully discard all their cards wins the hand. The game requires strategic thinking about when to play high cards versus saving them, and how to sequence your combinations.

games.name: Thirteen
games.description: A Chinese shedding game similar to Big Two, where players compete to be the first to discard all their cards. The game is played by exactly four players, with each player receiving 13 cards. Players can play various combinations to discard cards: single cards, pairs, triples, straights, flushes, and full houses. Higher combinations beat lower ones, and players must beat the previous play or pass. The first player to successfully discard all their cards wins the hand. The game shares many similarities with Big Two but may have slight variations in rules or card rankings depending on the specific variant being played. Strategic thinking is required to sequence your combinations effectively and time when to play your high cards.

games.name: Chinese President
games.description: A Chinese version of the President card game that combines shedding gameplay with social hierarchy dynamics. All cards are dealt evenly among players, and players compete to get rid of all their cards first by playing combinations (single cards, pairs, triples, straights, etc.). Higher combinations beat lower ones, and players must beat the previous play or pass. The first player to discard all their cards becomes the President, while the last player becomes the Peasant. Between rounds, the Peasant must give their best cards to the President, and the President gives their worst cards to the Peasant, creating a self-reinforcing hierarchy. The game continues over multiple rounds, with the social dynamics and card trading between rounds adding an extra layer of strategy and interaction.

games.name: Daihinmin
games.description: A Japanese shedding game similar to Big Two, where players compete to be the first to discard all their cards. The game is played by exactly four players, with each player receiving 13 cards. Players can play various combinations to discard cards: single cards, pairs, triples, straights, flushes, and full houses. Higher combinations beat lower ones, and players must beat the previous play or pass. The first player to successfully discard all their cards wins the hand. The game shares many similarities with Big Two and other Asian shedding games, with strategic thinking required to sequence your combinations effectively and time when to play your high cards versus saving them for later.

games.name: Daifugo
games.description: A popular Japanese hierarchy-based card game that combines shedding gameplay with social dynamics. The game is played by four to five players, with all cards dealt evenly among players. Players compete to get rid of all their cards first by playing combinations (single cards, pairs, triples, straights, etc.). Higher combinations beat lower ones, and players must beat the previous play or pass. The first player to discard all their cards becomes the Daifugo (rich man or president), while the last player becomes the Hinmin (poor man or peasant). Between rounds, the Hinmin must give their best cards to the Daifugo, and the Daifugo gives their worst cards to the Hinmin, creating a self-reinforcing social hierarchy. The game continues over multiple rounds, with the social dynamics adding an extra layer of strategy and interaction.

games.name: Asshole
games.description: A drinking game variant of President that combines the hierarchy-based card game with drinking rules. The game follows the same basic structure as President: players compete to get rid of all their cards first, with the first player out becoming the President and the last player becoming the Asshole. Between rounds, the Asshole deals the cards and must give their best card to the President, while the President gives their worst card to the Asshole. The game is often played with drinking penalties for various actions, such as the Asshole having to drink, or players having to drink when they make certain mistakes. The social hierarchy and card trading between rounds create a self-reinforcing dynamic, while the drinking element adds an extra layer of social interaction and fun.

games.name: Kemps
games.description: A fast-paced partnership matching game that requires teamwork, observation, and subtle communication. The game is played by exactly four players in two partnerships. Each player receives 4 cards, and the goal is to collect four of a kind (all four cards of the same rank). Players take turns drawing from a central pile and discarding one card, trying to collect their four of a kind. The unique twist is that players must secretly signal their partner when they have four of a kind using pre-agreed signals (like touching your nose, winking, or other subtle gestures). When you notice your partner has four of a kind, you call 'Kemps!' to win the round. However, if you're wrong, the other team wins. The game requires careful observation to spot your partner's signals while avoiding detection by opponents, making it a test of both card skills and communication.

games.name: Kentucky Salad
games.description: A fast-paced matching game that tests players' observation skills and reflexes. Each player receives 4 cards, and the goal is to collect four of a kind (all four cards of the same rank). Players take turns drawing from a central pile and discarding one card, trying to collect their four of a kind. When a player successfully collects four of a kind, they must immediately and subtly put their finger on their nose. All other players must quickly notice this signal and put their finger on their own nose. The last player to notice and put their finger on their nose loses the round. The game is played over multiple rounds, and it requires careful observation as players must watch for the nose signal while managing their own cards. It's a fun party game that combines card matching with quick reactions.

games.name: Screw Your Neighbor
games.description: A simple but entertaining card game that combines luck with psychological elements. Each player receives one card face down, but players are not allowed to look at their own card. Instead, players hold their card on their forehead so that everyone else can see it, but they cannot. A betting round follows, where players can bet, raise, or fold based on what they see on other players' foreheads. After betting, all players reveal their cards, and the player with the lowest card loses and must pay the pot to the winner. The game is played over multiple rounds, and it creates interesting dynamics as players must make decisions based on others' reactions to cards they cannot see themselves. It's a fun party game that combines poker-like betting with a unique twist.

games.name: Up and Down the River
games.description: A popular drinking game that combines card dealing with rule-based drinking penalties. Each round, the dealer deals a number of cards equal to the number of players. The dealer then calls out a rule for that round, such as 'lowest card drinks', 'highest card drinks', 'red cards drink', or other creative rules. Players reveal their cards simultaneously, and those who match the rule must drink. The dealer rotates each round, giving everyone a chance to create rules. The game is played over multiple rounds, and the number of cards dealt typically increases and then decreases (going 'up and down the river'), creating variety in the gameplay. It's a social party game that's easy to learn and creates lots of interaction and fun.

games.name: Ride the Bus
games.description: A drinking game that tests players' card knowledge and memory through a series of progressively difficult questions. The dealer asks players questions about cards, such as 'Is the next card higher or lower?' or 'What suit is this card?' Wrong answers result in drinking penalties. Players progress through multiple levels, with questions becoming more difficult as the game continues. The last person remaining (or the person who answers incorrectly the most) 'rides the bus' and must drink the most. The game is played over multiple rounds, and it combines card game mechanics with drinking penalties, creating a social party game that's both challenging and entertaining. The game requires players to pay attention and use their memory and card knowledge to avoid drinking.

games.name: Kings
games.description: A classic drinking game, also known as 'Ring of Fire' or 'Circle of Death', that combines card drawing with rule-based drinking penalties. All cards are placed face down in a circle around a central cup. Each card rank has an associated rule (for example, Ace might mean 'waterfall', 2 might mean 'you', 3 might mean 'me', etc.). Players take turns drawing cards and following the corresponding rule. When a King is drawn, the player must pour some of their drink into the central cup. When the fourth King is drawn, that player must drink the entire contents of the central cup. The game continues until all cards have been drawn. It's a popular party game that's easy to learn and creates lots of social interaction and fun, with the central cup building up throughout the game until someone must drink it all.

games.name: Asshole Presidents
games.description: A variant of President that uses more explicit hierarchy names, creating a social dynamic game where players compete to get rid of all their cards first. All cards are dealt evenly among players, and players compete to discard all their cards by playing combinations (single cards, pairs, triples, straights, etc.). Higher combinations beat lower ones, and players must beat the previous play or pass. The first player to discard all their cards becomes the President, while the last player becomes the Asshole. Between rounds, the Asshole must give their best cards to the President, and the President gives their worst cards to the Asshole. This creates a self-reinforcing hierarchy where the President has an advantage in subsequent rounds, while the Asshole is at a disadvantage. The game continues over multiple rounds, with the social dynamics and card trading adding an extra layer of strategy and interaction.

games.name: Scum Presidents
games.description: A variant of President that uses 'Scum' as the name for the lowest-ranking player, creating a social hierarchy game where players compete to get rid of all their cards first. All cards are dealt evenly among players, and players compete to discard all their cards by playing combinations (single cards, pairs, triples, straights, etc.). Higher combinations beat lower ones, and players must beat the previous play or pass. The first player to discard all their cards becomes the President, while the last player becomes the Scum. Between rounds, the Scum deals the cards and must give their best cards to the President, while the President gives their worst cards to the Scum. This creates a self-reinforcing hierarchy where the President has an advantage in subsequent rounds, while the Scum is at a disadvantage. The game continues over multiple rounds, with the social dynamics and card trading adding an extra layer of strategy and interaction.

games.name: Trump
games.description: A classic partnership trick-taking game for exactly four players. Each player receives 13 cards, and a trump suit is determined before play begins. Players must follow suit if possible during trick play, and the highest card of the led suit or the highest trump card wins each trick. The partnership that takes the most tricks wins the round.

games.name: Ninety-Nine
games.description: A unique trick-taking game for exactly three players that combines bidding with an unusual scoring system. The number of cards dealt varies by round, and each player bids on the exact number of tricks they'll take. Players must follow suit if possible during trick play. The scoring twist is that players score points for making their exact bid, and the game is played to 99 points - but the first player to reach or exceed 99 points loses the game. This creates a delicate balancing act where players must bid accurately to score points, but must avoid going over 99. The game requires careful calculation and strategic bidding, as players must manage their score while trying to force opponents over 99 points.

games.name: Black Lady
games.description: A variant of Hearts that emphasizes the penalty value of the queen of spades, also known as the 'Black Lady'. The game follows the same basic structure as standard Hearts: four players, 13 cards each, players pass 3 cards before play, and hearts cannot be led until they've been broken. Each heart card is worth 1 penalty point, and the queen of spades (the Black Lady) is worth 13 penalty points, making it the most dangerous card in the deck. Players must avoid taking both hearts and the queen of spades, with the queen being particularly costly. The player with the lowest score wins, and the game typically ends when a player reaches 100 points. The high penalty for the queen of spades adds extra strategic depth to the game.

games.name: Shooting the Moon
games.description: A Hearts variant that features the 'Shooting the Moon' rule, a high-risk, high-reward strategy option. The game follows standard Hearts rules: four players, 13 cards each, players pass 3 cards before play, and hearts cannot be led until broken. Each heart is worth 1 penalty point, and the queen of spades is worth 13 penalty points. However, if a player successfully takes all 13 hearts plus the queen of spades (26 points total), they 'shoot the moon' and receive 0 points for that hand, while all other players receive 26 penalty points each. This creates a dramatic strategic option where a player can attempt to take all penalty cards, which is extremely difficult but can completely reverse the score if successful. It's a high-risk, high-reward strategy that adds excitement and unpredictability to the game.

games.name: Blind Nil
games.description: A Spades variant that adds the 'Blind Nil' option, a high-risk, high-reward bidding strategy. The game follows standard Spades rules: four players in partnerships, 13 cards each, spades are always trump, and players bid on tricks. However, players have the option to bid 'blind nil' before looking at their cards, committing to take zero tricks without seeing their hand first. A successful blind nil is worth significantly more points than a regular nil (typically 200 points versus 100), but failing a blind nil results in a larger penalty. This creates a dramatic strategic option where players can commit to a nil bid before assessing their hand, which is extremely risky but can provide a huge point advantage if successful. The blind nil adds an extra layer of excitement and risk-taking to the game.

games.name: Mirror Spades
games.description: A Spades variant that emphasizes the partnership seating arrangement, with teams sitting across from each other (mirror positions). The game follows standard Spades rules: four players in two partnerships, 13 cards each, spades are always the trump suit, and players bid on how many tricks their partnership will take. Partnerships score 10 points for each trick they bid, but lose 10 points for each overtrick. A nil bid (bidding zero tricks) scores 100 points if successful, but loses 100 points if the player takes any tricks. The mirror seating arrangement (partners across from each other) is the standard setup for Spades, allowing partners to observe each other's play and coordinate strategy. The game requires careful communication and strategy between partners.

games.name: Double Deck Pinochle
games.description: A Pinochle variant that uses two 48-card pinochle decks (96 cards total), creating a longer and more complex game. The game is played by exactly four players in partnerships. Each player receives 12 cards. Like standard Pinochle, the game features a bidding phase where players bid on the points they'll make through both melds (card combinations laid down before play) and tricks won during play. The trump suit is determined during bidding, and scoring includes points for aces, tens, kings, queens, jacks, and various meld combinations. The partnership that makes the bid must reach their bid total or lose points. With twice as many cards, the game requires more strategic planning and partnership coordination. The first partnership to reach 1500 points wins the game.

games.name: Auction Pinochle
games.description: A Pinochle variant that emphasizes the auction bidding process, where players compete to become the declarer. The game uses a special 48-card pinochle deck (or two decks for larger games) and can be played by 3-4 players. During the auction phase, players bid on the points they'll make through both melds and tricks. The highest bidder becomes the declarer and plays against the other players (or partnership). The declarer must reach their bid total or lose points, while the opponents try to prevent the declarer from making their bid. Scoring is based on whether the declarer makes their bid and the number of tricks taken. The auction format creates competitive bidding and strategic decision-making about when to bid and how high to go.

games.name: Hand and Foot
games.description: A popular Canasta variant that adds complexity by giving each player two separate hands to manage. The game is played in partnerships using four decks with jokers (208 cards total). Each player receives two separate piles of cards: a 'hand' (the cards they can see and play from) and a 'foot' (a face-down pile that becomes available later). Players must play all cards from their hand before they can access their foot. The game follows standard Canasta rules: players form melds (sets of three or more cards of the same rank), with canastas (melds of seven or more cards) being particularly valuable. Red 3s are special bonus cards, and jokers and 2s act as wild cards. The first partnership to successfully play all cards from both their hand and foot wins the round. The game is typically played over multiple rounds, with the first team to reach a target score (often 5000 points) winning.

games.name: Bolivian Canasta
games.description: A Canasta variant with modified scoring rules that creates a longer, more strategic game. The game is played by exactly four players in partnerships, using two decks with jokers. Like standard Canasta, players form melds (sets of three or more cards of the same rank), with canastas (melds of seven or more cards) being particularly valuable. Red 3s are special bonus cards that must be laid down immediately, and jokers and 2s act as wild cards. The main difference is in the scoring system, which uses different point values for various melds and canastas. The game is played over multiple rounds, with the first partnership to reach 15,000 points winning. The higher target score makes it a longer game that requires more strategic planning and partnership coordination.

games.name: Samba
games.description: A Canasta variant that adds sequences (runs) to the standard melding rules, creating a more complex and strategic game. The game is played by exactly four players in partnerships, using two decks with jokers. Like standard Canasta, players form sets (three or more cards of the same rank), but Samba also allows players to form sequences (three or more consecutive cards of the same suit). Both sets and sequences can be built into canastas (seven or more cards), with sequence canastas being particularly valuable. Red 3s are special bonus cards, and jokers and 2s act as wild cards. The addition of sequences makes the game more complex than standard Canasta, as players must balance forming sets and sequences while managing their hand and working with their partner. The first partnership to reach the target score (typically 10,000 points) wins.

games.name: Six Card Cribbage
games.description: A Cribbage variant that increases the hand size and strategic options by dealing six cards instead of five. The game is played by two players, and each player receives 6 cards instead of the standard 5. Each player discards 2 cards to the 'crib' (an extra hand that scores for the dealer), leaving 4 cards in hand. The dealer turns up a starter card, then players alternate playing cards, scoring points for pairs, runs, combinations that total exactly 15, and combinations that total exactly 31. After the play phase, players count their hands (including the starter card) for additional points from pairs, runs, flushes, and combinations of 15. The crib scores for the dealer only. The extra card gives players more options for discarding and creates slightly different strategic decisions. The first player to reach 121 points wins.

games.name: Three Player Cribbage
games.description: A Cribbage variant adapted for three players, creating a different dynamic than the standard two-player game. Each player receives 5 cards, and each player discards 1 card to the 'crib' (an extra hand that scores for the dealer), leaving 4 cards in hand. The dealer turns up a starter card, then players alternate playing cards in rotation, scoring points for pairs, runs, combinations that total exactly 15, and combinations that total exactly 31. After the play phase, players count their hands (including the starter card) for additional points from pairs, runs, flushes, and combinations of 15. The crib scores for the dealer only. The three-player format adds complexity as players must consider two opponents' potential hands and strategies. The first player to reach 121 points wins.

games.name: Oklahoma Gin
games.description: A Gin Rummy variant that adds a dynamic element by making the knock threshold variable based on the upcard. The game follows standard Gin Rummy rules: two players, 10 cards each, players draw and discard, forming sets and runs. However, the upcard (the first card turned up from the stock) determines the knock threshold for that hand. If the upcard is a spade, players need 5 or less deadwood (unmatched cards) to knock instead of the standard 10. If the upcard is a heart, the threshold might be 6, diamond 7, club 8, etc. (the exact mapping varies). This adds a strategic element as players must adapt their strategy based on the upcard, making some hands easier to knock than others. The first player to reach 100 points wins the game.

games.name: Hollywood Gin
games.description: A Gin Rummy variant that uses a unique scoring system where three simultaneous games are tracked separately, creating a more complex and strategic experience. The game follows standard Gin Rummy rules: two players, 10 cards each, players draw and discard, forming sets and runs. However, scoring works differently: each hand's points are added to three separate game scores (Game 1, Game 2, and Game 3). Game 1 starts first, and when it reaches 100 points, Game 2 begins. When Game 2 reaches 100 points, Game 3 begins. Games end at different times, and the player who wins two out of three games wins the match. This scoring system adds strategic depth as players must consider which game to prioritize and how to manage their scores across all three games. It's a popular variant in competitive Gin Rummy play.

games.name: 500 Rummy Partnership
games.description: A partnership variant of 500 Rummy that adds teamwork and coordination to the classic rummy game. The game is played by exactly four players in two teams. Each player receives 7 cards (or 10 cards if playing with 2 players), and players take turns drawing from either the stock pile or the discard pile, then discarding one card. Players form sets (three or more cards of the same rank) and runs (three or more consecutive cards of the same suit). Once a player has valid combinations, they can lay them down on the table. The key partnership element is that players can lay off cards onto their partner's melds, allowing teams to work together to use all their cards. The first team to reach 500 points wins the game. The partnership format adds strategic depth as players must coordinate with their partner while competing against the opposing team.

games.name: 500 Rummy with Jokers
games.description: A 500 Rummy variant that includes jokers as wild cards, adding flexibility and strategic options to the classic game. The game follows standard 500 Rummy rules: players receive 7 cards (or 10 cards if playing with 2 players), draw and discard, and form sets and runs. However, jokers can be used as wild cards to represent any card in sets and runs, making it easier to form combinations. Jokers have a point value (typically 50 points) if left in a player's hand at the end of a round, so players must balance using jokers to go out versus holding them and risking penalty points. The first player to reach 500 points wins the game. The addition of jokers makes the game more dynamic and creates interesting strategic decisions about when and how to use the wild cards.

games.name: Royal Casino
games.description: A Casino variant with modified scoring rules that creates a different strategic focus. The game follows standard Casino rules: players capture cards from the table by matching ranks or building combinations that equal a card in hand. However, the scoring system is different: players score points for having the most cards captured, the most spades, each ace captured, the big casino (10 of diamonds), and the little casino (2 of spades). The game is played to 21 points instead of the standard target. This scoring system emphasizes different strategic priorities, as players must balance capturing cards, spades, aces, and the special casino cards. The first player to reach 21 points wins the game.

games.name: Scopa Briscola
games.description: A combination game that alternates between Scopa and Briscola, two classic Italian card games, creating a unique hybrid experience. The game alternates rounds between Scopa (a capturing game where players capture cards from the table by matching ranks or building combinations) and Briscola (a trick-taking game where players try to win tricks with the highest card of the led suit or trump). Players score points in both game types, and the scores are combined. The game requires players to be skilled in both capturing and trick-taking strategies, as they must adapt their play style depending on which game type is being played in the current round. The first player or partnership to reach the target score wins. This combination creates a varied and challenging game that tests multiple card game skills.

games.name: Briscola Chiamata
games.description: A variant of Briscola that adds a secret partnership element, making it a five-player game. One player (the caller) calls out a specific card that they do not have in their hand. The player who holds that card becomes the caller's secret partner, but this partnership is not revealed until the called card is actually played. The game follows standard Briscola rules: players use a 40-card deck, each receives cards, and players take tricks following suit when possible, with the trump suit determined by the last card dealt. The secret partnership adds a fascinating strategic element as players must try to identify who their partner is through gameplay while the other three players try to figure out the partnership. The first team to reach the target score wins.

games.name: Tressette
games.description: A classic Italian trick-taking game played by three or four players using a shortened 40-card deck (removing 8s, 9s, and 10s). Each player receives 10 cards, and players must follow suit if possible during trick play. The game features unique scoring where only aces, 3s, and face cards (Jacks, Queens, Kings) have point value, making these cards particularly valuable. The game is played to 21 points, and players compete to win tricks containing these valuable cards. Tressette is popular throughout Italy and requires strategic play as players must balance winning tricks with capturing high-value cards. The game can be played with three players (each playing individually) or four players (in partnerships).

games.name: Mariage
games.description: A French trick-taking game played by exactly four players in partnerships. The game's name comes from the 'marriage' combination, which is a king and queen of the same suit. Players deal cards and play tricks following suit when possible. The unique scoring feature is that players score points for marriages (king and queen of the same suit) that they hold in their hand or play during tricks. Marriages can be declared during play and score bonus points. The game combines trick-taking strategy with the bonus scoring from marriages, requiring players to balance winning tricks with holding or playing marriage combinations. The first team to reach the target score wins the game.

games.name: Bezique
games.description: A classic French card game for two players that combines trick-taking with melding, similar to Pinochle. The game uses a special 64-card deck (two of each card from 7 through Ace in all four suits). Each player receives 8 cards, and the game features two distinct phases: trick-taking and melding. During play, players take tricks and can declare melds (card combinations like marriages, sequences, and sets) which score bonus points. The game requires strategic balance between winning tricks and holding cards for valuable melds. Players score points for both tricks won and melds declared. The first player to reach 1000 points wins the game. Bezique was extremely popular in the 19th century and is considered a predecessor to modern Pinochle.

games.name: Piquet
games.description: An elegant French card game for two players that combines declarations, discarding, and trick-taking. The game uses a 32-card deck (7, 8, 9, 10, Jack, Queen, King, Ace of each suit). Each player receives 12 cards, and the remaining 8 cards form the stock. Players first make declarations (announcing point-scoring combinations in their hand), then discard and draw from the stock to improve their hands, and finally play tricks. Scoring includes points for declarations (point, sequence, set, and repique/pique bonuses) and for tricks won. The game requires careful calculation and strategic discarding to maximize both declaration points and trick-taking potential. The first player to reach 100 points wins the game. Piquet is considered one of the most sophisticated two-player card games.

games.name: Ecarte
games.description: A fast-paced French trick-taking game for two players that was popular in the 19th century. The game uses a 32-card deck (7, 8, 9, 10, Jack, Queen, King, Ace of each suit). Each player receives 5 cards, and the top card of the remaining deck is turned up to determine the trump suit. Players can accept or reject the trump suit, and if rejected, the dealer can propose a different trump. The game features a unique mechanic where the non-dealer can propose to play or exchange cards. Players then play tricks, and the player who wins the majority of tricks scores points. The game is played to 5 points, making it a quick and exciting game. Ecarte requires strategic decision-making about trump acceptance and card play.

games.name: All Fours
games.description: A classic English trick-taking game for two players that gets its name from the four ways players can score points. Each player receives 6 cards, and the top card of the remaining deck is turned up to determine the trump suit. Players then play tricks, and points are scored for four specific achievements: 'High' (the highest trump card in play), 'Low' (the lowest trump card in play, which is known from the start), 'Jack' (the jack of trumps, if it appears in play), and 'Game' (the player with the highest total point value of cards won in tricks). The first player to reach 7 points wins the game. All Fours is the ancestor of many American card games including Pitch and Seven Up.

games.name: Seven Up
games.description: A variant of All Fours that emphasizes reaching 7 points as the win condition. The game follows the same basic rules as All Fours: two players, 6 cards each, trump determined by a turned-up card, and scoring for High, Low, Jack, and Game. The main difference is in how the game is won - players compete to be the first to reach exactly 7 points, making it a race to accumulate points through the four scoring methods. The game maintains the strategic elements of All Fours while creating a clear and straightforward win condition. Seven Up is popular in both England and America as a quick and engaging two-player game.

games.name: Pitch
games.description: A popular All Fours variant that adds bidding to create a more strategic and competitive game. The game can be played by 2-4 players (individually or in partnerships). Players bid on the number of points they'll score from the four scoring methods: High (highest trump), Low (lowest trump), Jack (jack of trumps), and Game (highest point value of cards won). The highest bidder leads the first trick and chooses the trump suit. Players then play tricks, and points are scored for High, Low, Jack, and Game. The bidder must make their bid to score points; if they fail, they lose points. Other players score for any points they win. Pitch is extremely popular in America and adds strategic depth through the bidding mechanism.

games.name: Sixty-Six
games.description: A popular German trick-taking game for two players that combines marriages (king and queen of the same suit) with trick-taking. The game uses a shortened 24-card deck (9, 10, Jack, Queen, King, Ace of each suit). Each player receives 6 cards, and the top card of the remaining deck is turned up to determine the trump suit. Players can declare marriages (king and queen of the same suit) during play, which score bonus points. Players then play tricks, and points are scored for both marriages declared and tricks won. The game features a unique mechanic where players can close the stock (stop drawing new cards) to increase the point values. The first player to reach 66 points wins the game. Sixty-Six is popular throughout Central Europe and requires strategic balance between declaring marriages and winning tricks.

games.name: Sixty-Six Partnership
games.description: A partnership variant of Sixty-Six played by exactly four players in two teams. The game follows the same basic rules as the two-player version: uses a 24-card deck, players receive 6 cards each, trump is determined by a turned-up card, and players score for marriages and tricks. The partnership format adds teamwork and coordination, as partners work together to reach 66 points. Players can declare marriages and play tricks, with points being combined for the partnership. The game maintains the strategic elements of the two-player version while adding the complexity of partnership play. The first team to reach 66 points wins the game.

games.name: Schafkopf
games.description: A popular German trick-taking game, especially in Bavaria, played by exactly four players. The game uses a 32-card deck (7, 8, 9, 10, Jack, Queen, King, Ace of each suit). Each player receives 8 cards. The game features a bidding phase where players bid on different game types, which determines the trump suit, partnerships (if any), and scoring. The bidding can result in various game types, from partnership games to solo games where one player plays against the other three. Players then play tricks following suit when possible. Scoring varies based on the game type chosen during bidding. The first player or team to reach 61 points wins the game. Schafkopf is known for its complex bidding system and strategic depth.

games.name: Watten
games.description: A traditional Bavarian and Austrian trick-taking game played by exactly four players in partnerships. The game uses a 32-card deck (7, 8, 9, 10, Jack, Queen, King, Ace of each suit). Each player receives 5 cards. The game features a bidding phase where players bid to determine the trump suit, with the highest bidder choosing trump. Players then play tricks, following suit when possible. The game is known for its fast pace and social atmosphere, often played in taverns and social gatherings. Scoring is based on tricks won, and the first team to reach the target score (typically 11 or 15 points) wins the game. Watten is popular in Bavaria, Austria, and parts of Switzerland, and is often played as a drinking game.

games.name: Jass
games.description: A popular Swiss trick-taking game played by exactly four players in partnerships. The game uses a 36-card deck (6, 7, 8, 9, 10, Jack, Queen, King, Ace of each suit, or a 32-card deck depending on the variant). Each player receives 9 cards (or 8 cards in some variants). The game features a bidding phase where players bid to determine the trump suit, with the highest bidder choosing trump. Players then play tricks, following suit when possible. The game includes special scoring for certain card combinations and sequences, adding strategic depth beyond simple trick-taking. Points are scored for both tricks won and special combinations declared. The first team to reach 1000 points wins the game. Jass is extremely popular in Switzerland and is considered the national card game.

games.name: Klaverjassen
games.description: A popular Dutch trick-taking game played by exactly four players in partnerships. The game uses a 32-card deck (7, 8, 9, 10, Jack, Queen, King, Ace of each suit). Each player receives 8 cards. The unique feature of Klaverjassen is that the trump suit is determined by the first card played in the first trick, rather than through bidding. The suit of the first card played becomes trump for that hand. Players then play tricks, following suit when possible. The game requires quick adaptation as players must adjust their strategy based on which suit becomes trump. Points are scored for tricks won, and the first team to reach the target score (typically 162 points) wins the game. Klaverjassen is popular in the Netherlands and is known for its fast-paced, dynamic gameplay.

games.name: Mus
games.description: A traditional Spanish card game played by exactly four players in partnerships. The game uses a 40-card deck (removing 8s, 9s, and 10s). Each player receives 4 cards. Mus is unique in that it combines betting with card play, featuring distinct phases: Grande (highest card), Chica (lowest card), Pares (pairs), and Juego (game/point total). Players bet on these phases before revealing their cards, creating a bluffing and strategic element. After the betting phases, players play a trick-taking phase. The game requires both card skills and psychological skills, as players must read opponents and make strategic bets. Points are scored based on winning bets and tricks. The first team to reach the target score (typically 40 points) wins the game. Mus is extremely popular in Spain and the Basque Country.

games.name: Truco
games.description: A popular South American trick-taking game, especially in Argentina, Brazil, and Chile, played by exactly four players in partnerships. The game uses a 40-card deck (removing 8s, 9s, and 10s). Each player receives 3 cards. Truco features unique card rankings that differ from standard trick-taking games, with special high cards and a different hierarchy. The game includes a betting/raising mechanism where players can challenge each other to increase the stakes, and bluffing is a key element. Players play tricks with the special card rankings, and the game is fast-paced and exciting. The first team to reach 12 points wins the game. Truco is known for its social atmosphere, psychological elements, and the use of traditional hand signals and chants during play.

games.name: Conquian
games.description: An early Rummy variant that is considered one of the ancestors of modern Rummy games, originating in Mexico. The game is played by two players using a standard 52-card deck. Each player receives 10 cards, and the remaining cards form a stock pile with a discard pile. Players take turns drawing and discarding cards, trying to form sets (three or more cards of the same rank) and runs (three or more consecutive cards of the same suit). Unlike standard Rummy, Conquian has specific rules about when cards can be melded and how the game ends. The first player to successfully meld all 11 cards (10 in hand plus 1 drawn) into valid sets and runs goes out and wins the game. Conquian is known for its strategic depth and is considered more challenging than basic Rummy.

games.name: Five Crowns
games.description: A rummy-style card game that uses a special 116-card deck with five suits (the standard four suits plus stars), making it unique among card games. The game is played over multiple rounds, with the number of cards dealt increasing each round (starting with 3 cards and going up to 13 cards). Players take turns drawing and discarding, trying to form sets (three or more cards of the same rank) and runs (three or more consecutive cards of the same suit). Jokers are wild cards and can represent any card. The first player to successfully meld all their cards into valid sets and runs goes out and wins the round. Other players count the point value of their unmelded cards as penalty points. The game continues over multiple rounds, and the player with the lowest total penalty points at the end wins.

games.name: Phase 10
games.description: A rummy-style card game where players must complete 10 specific phases (combinations) in order to win. Each player receives 10 cards, and players take turns drawing and discarding. The game features 10 distinct phases that must be completed in sequence, such as 'two sets of 3', 'one set of 3 and one run of 4', 'one set of 4 and one run of 4', etc. Players can only work on one phase at a time and must complete it before moving to the next phase. The first player to complete all 10 phases wins the game. However, if a player goes out before others complete their current phase, those players continue playing until one player finishes all phases. The game requires strategic planning as players must balance completing their current phase while preventing opponents from finishing first.

games.name: Skip-Bo
games.description: A sequential card game that uses a special Skip-Bo deck (consisting of cards numbered 1-12 plus Skip-Bo wild cards). Each player has a stock pile of cards that they're trying to play through. Players build sequences from 1 to 12 on up to four build piles in the center. Skip-Bo cards act as wild cards and can be used as any number from 1 to 12. Players take turns playing cards from their hand or stock pile onto the build piles, trying to build sequences. When a sequence reaches 12, it's removed and a new sequence can be started. The first player to successfully play all cards from their stock pile wins the game. Skip-Bo is a fast-paced game that combines sequencing with strategic card management.

games.name: Uno with Standard Deck
games.description: A version of the popular Uno card game adapted to use a standard 52-card playing deck. Colors are assigned to suits: hearts and diamonds represent red, while spades and clubs represent black (or assign specific colors to each suit). Each player receives 7 cards, and players take turns matching either the color (suit) or rank of the top card on the discard pile. Special cards have specific functions: 8s act as skip cards (next player loses their turn), Jacks reverse the direction of play, Queens force the next player to draw 2 cards, and Kings are wild cards that can be played on any card and allow you to choose the color. The first player to discard all their cards wins. When you have one card left, you must say 'Uno' or draw penalty cards if caught.

games.name: King's Corner
games.description: A multiplayer solitaire-style game that combines elements of Klondike Solitaire with competitive play. Each player receives 7 cards, and four foundation piles are set up in the corners of the playing area. Players take turns playing cards, building foundation piles from Ace to King by suit, and building tableau piles in descending order with alternating colors (red and black). Players can play cards from their hand onto either the foundations or the tableau, and can move cards between tableau piles following solitaire rules. The first player to successfully play all their cards wins the game. King's Corner requires strategic thinking as players must balance building foundations, organizing the tableau, and preventing opponents from going out first.

games.name: Nerts
games.description: A fast-paced competitive solitaire game where multiple players play their own solitaire games simultaneously, racing to finish first. Each player has their own complete solitaire layout (similar to Klondike), including their own tableau, foundation piles, and stock pile. All players play at the same time, building foundation piles from Ace to King by suit and organizing their tableau in descending order with alternating colors. The first player to successfully move all cards to their foundation piles wins the game. Nerts is extremely fast-paced and requires quick thinking and dexterity, as players must manage their own game while keeping an eye on opponents' progress. It's a popular party game that combines solitaire skills with competitive speed.

games.name: Racing Demon
games.description: Another name for Nerts, a fast-paced competitive solitaire game where multiple players play their own solitaire games simultaneously. Each player has their own complete solitaire layout and plays at the same time as all other players. Players build foundation piles from Ace to King by suit and organize their tableau in descending order with alternating colors. The first player to successfully move all cards to their foundation piles wins the game. Racing Demon (or Nerts) is extremely fast-paced and requires quick thinking and dexterity, as players must manage their own game while racing against opponents. It's a popular party game that combines solitaire skills with competitive speed, creating an exciting and chaotic gaming experience.

games.name: Competitive Spit
games.description: A multiplayer variant of the fast-paced Spit card game that adds competitive elements. Each player has their own stock pile and spit pile (face-up cards). All players play simultaneously, trying to play cards from their hand onto center piles in ascending or descending sequence, regardless of suit. Players can play as fast as they can, and when no one can play, new cards are turned up from the stock piles. The first player to successfully play all cards from their stock pile wins the game. Competitive Spit maintains the fast-paced, reflex-based gameplay of standard Spit while adding the excitement of multiple players competing simultaneously. It requires quick thinking, fast reactions, and good hand-eye coordination.

games.name: Competitive Speed
games.description: A multiplayer variant of the fast-paced Speed card game that adds competitive elements for 3-4 players. Each player has a hand of cards and a stock pile. All players play simultaneously, trying to play cards from their hand onto two center piles in ascending or descending sequence, regardless of suit. Players can play as fast as they can, and when they run out of cards in hand, they immediately draw five more from their stock. The first player to successfully play all cards from both their hand and stock pile wins the game. Competitive Speed maintains the fast-paced, reflex-based gameplay of standard Speed while adding the excitement of multiple players competing simultaneously. It requires quick thinking, fast reactions, and excellent hand-eye coordination.

games.name: Progressive War
games.description: A variant of War that increases the stakes with each war, making the game more exciting and potentially longer. All cards are dealt evenly between the two players. Players simultaneously flip their top card face up, and the highest card wins both cards. When cards match in rank, it triggers a war, but in Progressive War, the number of cards placed face down increases with each war: the first war requires 3 cards face down, the second war requires 4 cards, the third requires 5 cards, and so on. Each player then flips a card face up, and the player with the higher card wins all the cards in play. This progressive system makes wars more dramatic and can create larger card exchanges. The player who collects all 52 cards wins the game.

games.name: Double War
games.description: A variant of War that uses two decks (104 cards total), creating a longer and more varied game. All cards are dealt evenly between the two players, giving each player 52 cards. Players simultaneously flip their top card face up, and the highest card wins both cards. When cards match in rank, it triggers a war: each player places three cards face down, then flips a fourth card face up. The player with the higher fourth card wins all the cards in play. With two decks, there are more opportunities for matching cards and wars, and the game can last significantly longer than standard War. The player who successfully collects all 104 cards wins the game.

games.name: Go Fish Partnership
games.description: A partnership variant of Go Fish that adds teamwork to the classic matching game. The game is played by exactly four players in two teams. Each player receives 7 cards (or 5 cards depending on the variant), and players take turns asking opponents for specific ranks. If an opponent has cards of that rank, they must give all of them. If not, they say 'Go Fish!' and the asking player draws from the draw pile. When a team successfully collects all four cards of the same rank, they lay them down as a completed set. Partners can work together by asking for cards that their partner needs. The first team to collect all possible sets wins the game. The partnership format adds strategic coordination as teams must communicate and plan their requests.

games.name: Crazy Eights Partnership
games.description: A partnership variant of Crazy Eights that adds teamwork to the fast-paced shedding game. The game is played by exactly four players in two teams. Each player receives 7 cards (or 5 cards if playing with just 2 players), and the top card of the remaining deck is turned up to start the discard pile. Players must match either the suit or rank of the top card, or play an 8, which acts as a wild card that can be played as any suit. Partners can work together to help each other go out. If a player cannot play a card, they must draw from the deck until they can play. The first team to have both players successfully discard all their cards wins the round. The partnership format adds strategic coordination as teams plan their discards together.

games.name: Slapjack Partnership
games.description: A partnership variant of Slapjack that adds teamwork to the fast-paced slapping game. The game is played by exactly four players in two teams. All cards are dealt evenly among players, and players take turns placing cards face up in a center pile. When a jack appears, the first player to slap it wins the entire center pile for their team. However, if you slap incorrectly (when it's not a jack), your team must give one card to the opposing team. Partners can work together, with both players able to slap jacks. The game requires quick reactions and careful observation as players must watch for jacks while avoiding false slaps. The first team to successfully collect all the cards wins the game.

games.name: Snap Partnership
games.description: A partnership variant of Snap that adds teamwork to the fast-paced matching game. The game is played by exactly four players in two teams. All cards are dealt evenly among players, and players take turns simultaneously flipping their top card face up into a central pile. When two cards of the same rank appear consecutively in the pile, the first player to shout 'Snap' wins the entire pile for their team. Partners can both shout 'Snap', and either partner's shout counts for the team. The game requires quick reactions and careful observation as players must watch for matching ranks while managing their own cards. The first team to successfully collect all the cards wins the game.

games.name: Memory Partnership
games.description: A partnership variant of Memory (also known as Concentration) that adds teamwork to the classic memory game. The game is played by exactly four players in two teams. The deck is shuffled and all cards are laid face down in a grid formation. Teams take turns flipping two cards face up. If the two cards match in rank (same number or face card), the team keeps the pair and takes another turn. If they don't match, both cards are flipped back face down, and play passes to the next team. Partners can work together to remember card positions and coordinate their flips. The game requires careful observation and memory as teams try to remember where specific cards are located. The team that collects the most pairs wins the game.

games.name: Old Maid Partnership
games.description: A partnership variant of Old Maid that adds teamwork to the classic matching game. The game is played by exactly four players in two teams. One queen is removed from the deck before play begins, leaving the 'old maid' (unmatched queen). All remaining cards are dealt to the players, and players immediately remove all pairs from their hands. Players then take turns drawing one card from the next player's hand. If the drawn card makes a pair with a card in your hand, you discard the pair. Partners can work together to help each other get rid of cards. The game continues until all pairs have been matched and discarded. The unlucky team left holding the unmatched queen (the 'old maid') loses the game.

games.name: Beggar My Neighbor Partnership
games.description: A partnership variant of Beggar My Neighbor that adds teamwork to the simple card game. The game is played by exactly four players in two teams. All cards are dealt evenly among players, and players take turns placing their top card face up in a central pile. When a face card (Jack, Queen, King, or Ace) is played, the next player must 'pay' a certain number of cards. If the paying player reveals another face card, the payment obligation passes to the next player. If no face card appears during the payment, the team that played the original face card wins the entire pile. Partners can work together to manage their cards. The first team to run out of cards loses the game.

games.name: Pigs Partnership
games.description: A partnership variant of Pigs that adds teamwork to the fast-paced matching game. The game is played by exactly four players in two teams. All cards are dealt evenly among players, and on each turn, all players simultaneously pass one card to the player on their left. When a player successfully collects four cards of the same rank, they quietly put a finger on their nose. Partners must watch for their teammate's signal. The last team to notice and put their finger on their nose loses the round. The game is played over multiple rounds, and it's a test of both speed and observation as players must watch for the nose signal from their partner while continuing to pass cards. The partnership format adds coordination as teams work together to signal and respond quickly.

games.name: Spoons Partnership
games.description: A partnership variant of Spoons that adds teamwork to the extremely fast-paced matching game. The game is played by exactly four players in two teams. Place one fewer spoon than the number of players in the center of the table (3 spoons for 4 players). Each player receives 4 cards, and players simultaneously pass one card to the left on each turn. When a player collects four of a kind, they grab a spoon from the center. As soon as one spoon is taken, all other players must grab a spoon as well. Partners can both grab spoons, and either partner's grab counts for the team. The team left without a spoon receives a letter, starting with 'S'. Teams who spell out 'SPOONS' are eliminated. The partnership format adds coordination as teams work together to grab spoons quickly.

games.name: Kemps Partnership
games.description: A partnership variant of Kemps that emphasizes explicit team coordination. The game is played by exactly four players in two teams. Each player receives 4 cards, and players take turns drawing from a central pile and discarding one card, trying to collect four of a kind (all four cards of the same rank). Players must secretly signal their partner when they have four of a kind using pre-agreed signals. When you notice your partner has four of a kind, you call 'Kemps!' to win the round. However, if you're wrong, the other team wins. The partnership format is explicit, with clear teams working together. The game requires careful observation to spot your partner's signals while avoiding detection by opponents, making it a test of both card skills and communication.

games.name: Spanish 21
games.description: A Blackjack variant that uses a 48-card deck (removing all 10s, but keeping face cards which are worth 10), creating different odds and strategic considerations. The game follows standard Blackjack rules: players compete against the dealer to get closer to 21 without busting, and players can hit, stand, double down, or split pairs. However, Spanish 21 features several player-friendly rules: a player's 21 always wins (even against dealer's 21), late surrender is allowed, players can double down on any number of cards, and there are bonus payouts for certain 21 combinations. The removal of 10s changes the card distribution and affects strategy, as there are fewer 10-value cards in the deck. These rule variations make Spanish 21 more favorable to players than standard Blackjack.

games.name: Pontoon
games.description: A British Blackjack variant with unique terminology and special hand rankings. The game follows standard Blackjack structure: players compete against the dealer to get closer to 21 without busting. However, Pontoon uses different terms: 'twist' instead of 'hit' and 'stick' instead of 'stand'. The game features a special hand called a 'five-card trick' (five cards totaling 21 or less), which beats a regular 21. A player's 21 always wins, even against the dealer's 21. Players can double down, split pairs, and surrender. The unique hand rankings and terminology make Pontoon distinct from standard Blackjack, and it's popular in the UK and Commonwealth countries.

games.name: Double Exposure Blackjack
games.description: A Blackjack variant that provides more information by showing both of the dealer's cards face up from the start.
