The game follows standard Blackjack rules: players compete against the dealer to get closer to 21 without busting, and players can hit, stand, double down, or split pairs. However, the key difference is that both dealer cards are visible, giving players complete information about the dealer's hand. To compensate for this advantage, the game has less favorable rules: the dealer wins all ties (instead of pushes), and blackjack pays only 1:1 instead of 3:2. These rule changes make the game more challenging despite having more information, requiring players to adjust their strategy accordingly.

games.name: Super Fun 21
games.description: A Blackjack variant with very player-friendly rules that make it more favorable than standard Blackjack. The game follows standard Blackjack structure: players compete against the dealer to get closer to 21 without busting. However, Super Fun 21 features liberal rules: a player's 21 always wins (even against dealer's 21), late surrender is allowed, players can double down on any number of cards, and there's a 'Super Match' side bet that pays if your first two cards match. These rule variations make the game more favorable to players, though blackjack typically pays 6:5 instead of 3:2. The combination of player-friendly rules and side bets makes Super Fun 21 an attractive option for players.

games.name: Match Play 21
games.description: A Blackjack variant that adds a matching bonus feature and side bets to the classic game. The game follows standard Blackjack rules: players compete against the dealer to get closer to 21 without busting. However, Match Play 21 features a bonus where players receive a payout if their first two cards match the dealer's upcard. A player's 21 always wins (even against dealer's 21), and the game includes various side bets that add excitement and additional betting opportunities. These features make the game more engaging while maintaining the core Blackjack gameplay. The matching bonus and side bets provide additional ways to win beyond the standard hand.

games.name: Baccarat
games.description: An elegant casino banking game where players bet on whether the 'player' or 'banker' hand will have a total closer to 9. Two hands are dealt: one for the player and one for the banker. Players bet on which hand will win, or on a tie. Card values are unique: face cards and 10s are worth 0, aces are worth 1, and all other cards are worth their face value. If a hand's total exceeds 9, only the ones digit counts (e.g., 15 becomes 5). The game follows specific third card rules that determine when an additional card is drawn for either hand. Baccarat is known for its simplicity and low house edge, making it popular in high-stakes casino settings.

games.name: Mini Baccarat
games.description: A faster-paced variant of Baccarat designed for lower stakes and quicker play. The game follows the same rules as standard Baccarat: players bet on whether the player or banker hand will be closer to 9, with the same card values and third card rules. However, Mini Baccarat is played at a smaller table with lower betting limits, and the dealer handles all cards (players don't touch the cards), making the game faster. The game maintains the same elegance and simplicity as standard Baccarat but is more accessible to casual players due to lower stakes and faster gameplay. Mini Baccarat is extremely popular in casinos and is often the most common form of Baccarat available.

games.name: Pai Gow Poker
games.description: A poker-based banking game that combines elements of the Chinese game Pai Gow with poker hand rankings. The game uses a 53-card deck (52 cards plus one joker). Each player receives 7 cards and must arrange them into two hands: a 5-card high hand and a 2-card low hand. The 5-card hand must rank higher than the 2-card hand. Players compete against the dealer, and to win, both of the player's hands must beat the dealer's corresponding hands. If one hand wins and one loses, it's a push (tie). The joker can be used as an ace or to complete straights and flushes. Pai Gow Poker requires strategic thinking about how to split your 7 cards into the two best possible hands.

games.name: Three Card Poker
games.description: A fast-paced poker-based casino game where players make the best three-card poker hand. Each player receives 3 cards face down, and the dealer also receives 3 cards. Players make an ante bet and can then make a 'play' bet to compete against the dealer, or fold and lose only the ante. There's also a 'pair plus' side bet that pays based on the strength of the player's hand regardless of the dealer's hand. Hand rankings are simplified for three cards: straight flush (highest), three of a kind, straight, flush, pair, and high card. To win the ante/play bets, the player's hand must beat the dealer's hand (dealer must qualify with queen high or better). Three Card Poker is popular for its simplicity and multiple betting options.

games.name: Caribbean Stud Poker
games.description: A poker-based casino game where players compete against the dealer using standard five-card poker hand rankings. Each player receives 5 cards face down, and the dealer receives 4 cards face down and 1 card face up. Players make an ante bet, then look at their cards and decide whether to fold (losing the ante) or make a 'raise' bet (double the ante) to compete. The dealer must qualify with a pair of kings or better; if the dealer doesn't qualify, players win even money on their ante (raise bet pushes). If the dealer qualifies, players must beat the dealer's hand to win. There's also an optional progressive jackpot side bet that pays for high hands. Caribbean Stud is popular for its progressive jackpot feature and straightforward gameplay.

games.name: Let It Ride
games.description: A poker-based casino game that combines community cards with the ability to control your bets. Each player receives 3 cards face down and makes three equal bets. Two community cards are then revealed one at a time. After each community card is revealed, players can choose to 'let it ride' (keep the bet) or 'pull back' (withdraw the bet). Players make the best five-card poker hand using their 3 cards plus the 2 community cards. Payouts are based on hand strength, with higher hands paying more. The unique feature is that players can pull back two of their three bets if they don't like their hand after seeing the community cards, giving them control over their risk. Let It Ride is popular for its player control and straightforward gameplay.

games.name: Australian Patience
games.description: A challenging two-deck solitaire game that requires managing 104 cards with strategic planning. All cards are dealt face up into 8 columns of 7 cards each, providing complete visibility of the layout from the start. Eight foundation piles are available (one for each suit) to build from Ace to King. The tableau columns are built in descending order with alternating colors (red and black). When a space opens in the tableau, it can be filled with any available card. The game's difficulty comes from managing twice as many cards as standard solitaire while maintaining careful sequencing to free up cards and build all eight foundation piles. The goal is to successfully move all 104 cards to the foundation piles.

games.name: Bisley
games.description: A challenging two-deck solitaire game that requires managing 104 cards with strategic planning. All cards are dealt face up into 10 columns of 5 cards each, providing complete visibility of the layout from the start. Eight foundation piles are available (one for each suit) to build from Ace to King. The tableau columns are built in descending order with alternating colors (red and black). When a space opens in the tableau, it can be filled with any available card. The game's difficulty comes from managing twice as many cards as standard solitaire while maintaining careful sequencing to free up cards and build all eight foundation piles. The goal is to successfully move all 104 cards to the foundation piles.

games.name: Busy Aces
games.description: A solitaire game that emphasizes the importance of aces in the foundation building. The game begins with 8 columns of 6 cards each, all dealt face up, providing full visibility of the layout. Four foundation piles start with aces (one for each suit), and players build up from ace to king by suit. The tableau columns are built in descending order with alternating colors (red and black). The game's name comes from the 'busy' nature of aces, as they're crucial for starting the foundation piles and must be freed from the tableau. The goal is to successfully move all 52 cards to the foundation piles, requiring careful planning to free up the aces and build the foundations.

games.name: Calculus
games.description: A unique solitaire game that incorporates mathematical operations into the card building rules, creating a puzzle-like experience. The game begins with 8 columns of 6 cards each, all dealt face up, providing full visibility of the layout. Four foundation piles are available, but unlike standard solitaire, cards are built onto foundations using mathematical operations rather than simple sequential building. The complex building rules may involve addition, subtraction, or other mathematical relationships between cards. This makes the game more challenging and requires mathematical thinking in addition to strategic card play. The goal is to successfully move all 52 cards to the foundation piles using the mathematical building rules.

games.name: Canfield Reserve
games.description: A variant of Canfield Solitaire with modified reserve rules that changes the strategic approach. The game begins by dealing 13 cards as a reserve pile (face down, with the top card turned up), one card to start the foundation, and the remaining cards dealt into a tableau. Players can use cards from the reserve pile to help build foundations and tableau. The reserve provides additional flexibility compared to standard Canfield, as players have more cards available to work with. Four foundation piles are built from the base card up by suit, and the tableau is built in descending order with alternating colors. The goal is to successfully move all 52 cards to the foundation piles, using the reserve strategically to free up cards.

games.name: Carpet
games.description: A challenging two-deck solitaire game named for its carpet-like layout of cards. All cards are dealt face up into 8 columns of 7 cards each, providing complete visibility of the layout from the start. Eight foundation piles are available (one for each suit) to build from Ace to King. The tableau columns are built in descending order with alternating colors (red and black). When a space opens in the tableau, it can be filled with any available card. The game's difficulty comes from managing twice as many cards as standard solitaire while maintaining careful sequencing to free up cards and build all eight foundation piles. The goal is to successfully move all 104 cards to the foundation piles.

games.name: Chinese Solitaire
games.description: A solitaire game with a layout and rules that may have Chinese origins or influences. The game begins with 8 columns of 6 cards each, all dealt face up, providing full visibility of the layout. Four foundation piles are available to build from Ace to King by suit. The tableau columns are built in descending order with alternating colors (red and black). The game requires careful planning and strategic sequencing to free up cards and build the foundations. The goal is to successfully move all 52 cards to the foundation piles. The game may have variations in rules depending on the specific Chinese solitaire variant being played.

games.name: Citadel
games.description: A challenging two-deck solitaire game named for its fortress-like structure. All cards are dealt face up into 10 columns of 5 cards each, providing complete visibility of the layout from the start. Eight foundation piles are available (one for each suit) to build from Ace to King. The tableau columns are built in descending order with alternating colors (red and black). When a space opens in the tableau, it can be filled with any available card. The game's difficulty comes from managing twice as many cards as standard solitaire while maintaining careful sequencing to free up cards and build all eight foundation piles. The goal is to successfully move all 104 cards to the foundation piles, creating a challenging puzzle that requires strategic planning.

games.description: A challenging two-deck solitaire game that requires managing 104 cards with strategic planning. All cards are dealt face up into 8 columns of 7 cards each, providing complete visibility of the layout from the start. Eight foundation piles are available (one for each suit) to build from Ace to King. The tableau columns are built in descending order with alternating colors (red and black). When a space opens in the tableau, it can be filled with any available card. The goal is to successfully move all 104 cards to the foundation piles.

Four foundation piles are available to build from Ace to King by suit. The tableau columns are built in descending order with alternating colors (red and black). The game requires careful planning and strategic sequencing to free up cards from the crescent-shaped tableau and build the foundations. The goal is to successfully move all 52 cards to the foundation piles.

games.name: Double Klondike
games.description: A two-deck variant of Klondike Solitaire that increases the challenge by doubling the number of cards. The game uses two decks (104 cards total). Cards are dealt into 10 columns: the first column has 1 card, the second has 2 cards, and so on up to 10 cards in the tenth column. All cards are dealt face up, providing complete visibility. Eight foundation piles are available (one for each suit) to build from Ace to King. The tableau columns are built in descending order with alternating colors (red and black). There is no stock pile, so all moves must be made using only the cards already on the table. The goal is to successfully move all 104 cards to the foundation piles, creating a more challenging puzzle than standard Klondike.

games.name: Eagle Wing
games.description: A challenging two-deck solitaire game named for its distinctive layout that may resemble an eagle's wing. All cards are dealt face up into 8 columns of 7 cards each, providing complete visibility of the layout from the start. Eight foundation piles are available (one for each suit) to build from Ace to King. The tableau columns are built in descending order with alternating colors (red and black). When a space opens in the tableau, it can be filled with any available card. The game's difficulty comes from managing twice as many cards as standard solitaire while maintaining careful sequencing to free up cards and build all eight foundation piles. The goal is to successfully move all 104 cards to the foundation piles.

games.name: Fan
games.description: A simple solitaire game named for its distinctive fan-shaped tableau layout. The game begins with 18 cards dealt face up in a fan shape (typically arranged in overlapping rows that create a fan pattern). Four foundation piles are available to build from Ace to King by suit. The remaining 34 cards form the stock pile, which is turned over one card at a time. Cards can be moved from the fan tableau to the foundations when they're the next card in sequence for that suit. The game requires strategic thinking about which cards to move from the fan to maximize your chances of building the foundations. The goal is to successfully move all 52 cards to the foundation piles.

games.name: Flower Garden
games.description: A solitaire game named for its garden-like layout of cards arranged in columns. The game begins with 6 columns of 6 cards each, all dealt face up, creating a visually appealing 'garden' of cards. Four foundation piles are available to build from Ace to King by suit. The tableau columns are built in descending order with alternating colors (red and black). When a space opens in the tableau, it can be filled with any available card. The game requires careful planning to free up cards from the garden-like tableau and build the foundations. The goal is to successfully move all 52 cards to the foundation piles.

games.name: Fortune's Favor
games.description: A challenging two-deck solitaire game that requires both skill and a bit of luck (fortune's favor) to succeed. All cards are dealt face up into 10 columns of 5 cards each, providing complete visibility of the layout from the start. Eight foundation piles are available (one for each suit) to build from Ace to King. The tableau columns are built in descending order with alternating colors (red and black). When a space opens in the tableau, it can be filled with any available card. The game's difficulty comes from managing twice as many cards as standard solitaire while maintaining careful sequencing to free up cards and build all eight foundation piles. The goal is to successfully move all 104 cards to the foundation piles.

games.name: Four Seasons
games.description: A solitaire game named for the four foundation piles, each representing a season (or suit). The game begins with four foundation piles set up, one for each suit. Cards are dealt into a tableau, and players build foundation piles from Ace to King by suit. The tableau is built in descending order with alternating colors (red and black). The game requires strategic planning to organize cards in the tableau and move them to the appropriate foundation pile (season). The goal is to successfully move all 52 cards to the foundation piles, completing all four seasons.

games.name: Double FreeCell
games.description: A challenging two-deck variant of FreeCell that doubles the complexity while maintaining the strategic use of free cells. All cards are dealt face up into 10 columns of 10 cards each, providing complete visibility of the layout. Four foundation piles are available to build from Ace to King by suit. Four free cells are available to temporarily store cards, which is crucial for managing the larger tableau and freeing up cards for the foundations. The tableau columns are built in descending order with alternating colors (red and black). The strategic use of free cells is even more important with twice as many cards. The goal is to successfully move all 104 cards to the foundation piles.

Eight foundation piles are available (one for each suit) to build from Ace to King. The tableau columns are built in descending order with alternating colors (red and black). games.description: A solitaire game named for its harp-like appearance, with cards arranged in columns that may resemble the strings of a harp. The game begins with 8 columns of 6 cards each, all dealt face up, providing full visibility of the layout. Four foundation piles are available to build from Ace to King by suit. The tableau columns are built in descending order with alternating colors (red and black). The game requires careful planning and strategic sequencing to free up cards and build the foundations. The goal is to successfully move all 52 cards to the foundation piles.

When a space opens in the tableau, it can be filled with any available card. games.name: Acey Deucey
games.description: A simple betting game that's more of a gambling game than traditional poker. Each player receives two cards face up. Players then bet on whether a third card (dealt from the deck) will rank between the two cards they hold. For example, if you hold a 5 and a 9, you're betting that the third card will be a 6, 7, or 8. If the third card falls between your two cards, you win your bet. If it doesn't (including if it matches one of your cards), you lose your bet. The game is simple, fast-paced, and relies entirely on luck rather than poker skill. It's popular in home games and as a side game.

games.name: Acey Deucey Poker
games.description: A poker variant that combines traditional poker gameplay with Acey Deucey betting elements. Players receive cards and play a poker hand, but the game incorporates betting mechanics from Acey Deucey, where players can bet on whether certain cards will fall between other cards. The game combines the strategic elements of poker with the additional betting opportunities from Acey Deucey. Players bet on various outcomes throughout the hand, and the best poker hand ultimately wins. This hybrid game adds extra excitement and betting opportunities to standard poker.

games.name: Ankle
games.description: A Five Card Draw poker variant with special wild card rules that add strategic complexity. The game follows standard Five Card Draw structure: each player receives 5 cards, there's a betting round, players discard and draw new cards, followed by a final betting round. However, Ankle features unique wild card rules that determine which cards are wild (the specific rules vary by house rules, but typically involve certain ranks or suits becoming wild based on the game's progression). These special wild card rules create more action and higher-value hands. The best five-card poker hand wins the pot.

games.name: Arnold
games.description: A poker variant with special rules that distinguish it from standard poker games. The game follows a poker structure with betting rounds, but includes unique rule variations that may involve wild cards, special hand rankings, or modified betting structures. The specific rules vary by house rules, but the game maintains the core poker mechanics of betting and hand comparison. Players compete to make the best hand according to the variant's specific rules, and the best hand wins the pot. Arnold is popular in home games where players enjoy experimenting with different poker variants.

games.name: Asshole Poker
games.description: A poker variant that combines standard poker gameplay with social hierarchy dynamics similar to the card game Asshole (President). Players play poker hands with betting rounds, trying to make the best five-card hand. However, after each hand, the player with the worst hand becomes the 'asshole' and must deal the next round. This creates a social dynamic where players try to avoid having the worst hand. The game continues over multiple rounds, with the hierarchy potentially affecting gameplay (such as the asshole having to pay extra or having restrictions). It's a fun variant that adds social elements to poker.

games.name: Baseball Wild
games.description: A variant of Baseball poker that increases the number of wild cards, creating even more action and higher-value hands. Like standard Baseball, 3s and 9s are wild cards, and 4s dealt face down allow a free card (no betting required). However, Baseball Wild may include additional wild cards or modified rules that create more wild card opportunities. The game follows Seven Card Stud structure with betting rounds. With more wild cards available, high-value hands like four of a kind, straight flushes, and even five of a kind are very common. The best five-card hand wins the pot. This variant is extremely action-packed and popular in home games.

games.name: Big Cincinnati
games.description: A poker variant that uses a unique cross-pattern layout for dealing cards. Cards are dealt in a cross pattern (typically 5 cards in a row and 5 cards in a column, intersecting at the center). The center card where the cross intersects becomes a wild card. Players use the cards in the cross pattern along with their hole cards (if any) to make their best five-card hand. The game follows standard poker betting structure, and the best hand wins the pot. The cross layout and wild center card create interesting strategic situations as players must consider how to use the cross pattern cards effectively.

games.name: Big Dog Little Dog
games.description: A poker variant that features two special hands: 'Big Dog' (A-K-Q-J-10, all different suits, no pair) and 'Little Dog' (7-6-5-4-3, all different suits, no pair). These special hands rank above a straight but below a flush in the hand hierarchy. The game follows standard poker structure with betting rounds. If a player makes a Big Dog or Little Dog, they receive bonus payouts or special consideration in the hand. The game can be played in various formats (Draw, Stud, or community card games). The best hand wins the pot, with Big Dog and Little Dog providing additional strategic options and excitement.

games.name: Black Marble
games.description: A poker variant with special rules that distinguish it from standard poker games. The game follows a poker structure with betting rounds, but includes unique rule variations that may involve wild cards, special hand rankings, or modified betting structures. games.name: Blind Baseball
games.description: A variant of Baseball poker where some cards are dealt face down, adding an element of hidden information. Like standard Baseball, 3s and 9s are wild cards, and 4s dealt face down allow a free card (no betting required). However, in Blind Baseball, some cards that would normally be face up in Seven Card Stud are dealt face down instead, creating more uncertainty and strategic depth. Players must make decisions with less information about opponents' hands. The game follows Seven Card Stud structure with betting rounds. The best five-card hand wins the pot. The hidden cards make the game more challenging and add psychological elements.

games.name: Blind Tigress
games.description: A poker variant where cards are dealt face down, creating a game of hidden information and strategic betting. Unlike standard poker games where some cards are visible, Blind Tigress deals cards face down, requiring players to make betting decisions with limited information about their own hand strength and no information about opponents' hands. The game follows standard poker structure with betting rounds, but the hidden nature of the cards adds significant psychological and strategic elements. Players must rely on betting patterns, position, and probability rather than visible cards. The best hand wins the pot.

games.name: Cincinnati
games.description: A community card poker game that combines elements of Five Card Stud and Hold'em. Each player receives 5 cards face down (like Five Card Stud), and 5 community cards are dealt face up in the center. Players make their best five-card hand using any combination of their 5 hole cards and the 5 community cards. The game follows standard poker betting structure with betting rounds before and after the community cards are dealt. This creates interesting strategic situations as players must balance using their hole cards versus the community cards. The best five-card hand wins the pot. Cincinnati is popular in home games and provides a unique twist on standard community card games.

games.name: Cincinnati Liz
games.description: A variant of Cincinnati poker that adds a wild card element. Like standard Cincinnati, each player receives 5 cards face down, and 5 community cards are dealt face up. However, in Cincinnati Liz, the lowest card in each player's hand becomes a wild card for that player only. This means different players may have different wild cards, creating interesting strategic situations. Players make their best five-card hand using any combination of their hole cards and the community cards, with their lowest card acting as wild. The game follows standard poker betting structure, and the best hand wins the pot. The dynamic wild card adds extra action and strategic depth.

games.name: Crazy Pineapple Hi-Lo
games.description: A split-pot variant of Crazy Pineapple that combines the discarding mechanics of Crazy Pineapple with high-low split rules. Each player receives three private hole cards. After the flop (first three community cards), players discard one hole card. After the turn (fourth community card), players discard another hole card, leaving them with one hole card. The pot is split between the player with the best high hand and the player with the best qualifying low hand. Players must use exactly two hole cards combined with three community cards for both their high and low hands. Aces can be used as either high or low. The best high hand and the best qualifying low hand (typically A-2-3-4-5) each win half the pot.

games.name: Criss Cross Pineapple
games.description: A Pineapple variant that uses a unique cross-pattern layout for the community cards. Each player receives three private hole cards. Instead of standard community cards, cards are dealt in a cross pattern (typically 5 cards in a row and 5 cards in a column, intersecting at the center). The center card where the cross intersects becomes a wild card. After the flop (first three cards of the cross), players discard one hole card. Players then make their best five-card hand using exactly two of their remaining hole cards combined with three cards from the cross pattern. The game follows standard poker betting structure, and the best hand wins the pot. The cross layout and wild center card create unique strategic situations.

games.name: Dealer's Choice
games.description: A flexible poker format where the dealer chooses which poker variant to play for each hand, creating variety and testing players' knowledge of different poker games. The dealer can choose any poker variant (Hold'em, Omaha, Seven Card Stud, Five Card Draw, or any other variant). The choice rotates with each hand as the dealer button moves. This format rewards players who are skilled in multiple poker variants rather than specializing in just one. It prevents any single player from dominating by being an expert in just one game type, and it keeps the game interesting with constant variety. Dealer's Choice is extremely popular in home games and creates a fun, dynamic poker experience.

games.name: Double Flop Hold'em
games.description: A Hold'em variant that adds strategic choice by dealing two separate flops instead of one. Each player receives two private hole cards, just like standard Hold'em. However, two separate flops (each consisting of three community cards) are dealt face up. Players must choose which flop to use for their hand, but they can see both flops before making their decision. After the turn and river are dealt (shared by both flops), players make their best five-card hand using their two hole cards and the five community cards from their chosen flop. The game follows standard Hold'em betting structure. This variant adds strategic depth as players must evaluate both flops and choose the one that works best with their hole cards.

games.name: Drawmaha Hi-Lo
games.description: A split-pot variant of Drawmaha that combines the hybrid structure of Drawmaha with high-low split rules. Each player receives five private hole cards, and the game includes community cards (flop, turn, river) like Omaha, but players also have the option to discard and draw new cards like in Draw poker. The pot is split between the player with the best high hand and the player with the best qualifying low hand. Players must use exactly two hole cards combined with three community cards for both their high and low hands. Aces can be used as either high or low. The best high hand and the best qualifying low hand (typically A-2-3-4-5) each win half the pot. The combination of community cards, draw mechanics, and split pot creates a complex and action-packed game.

games.name: English Poker
games.description: A poker variant that follows English poker rules, which may differ from standard American poker rules in betting structure, hand rankings, or other specific rules. The game follows standard poker structure with betting rounds, but the specific rules (such as betting limits, blind structures, or hand rankings) follow English conventions. English Poker maintains the core poker mechanics of betting and hand comparison, but with rule variations that reflect British poker traditions. Players compete to make the best hand according to English poker rules, and the best hand wins the pot.

games.name: Follow the Queen Hi-Lo
games.description: A split-pot variant of Follow the Queen that combines the dynamic wild card mechanics with high-low split rules. Like standard Follow the Queen, when a queen is dealt face up, the next card dealt determines which rank becomes wild for the remainder of that hand. The pot is split between the player with the best high hand and the player with the best qualifying low hand. Players must use exactly two hole cards combined with three community cards for both their high and low hands. Aces can be used as either high or low. The dynamic wild card determination adds extra complexity as players must adapt to changing wild card ranks while pursuing both high and low hands. The best high hand and the best qualifying low hand each win half the pot.

games.name: Guts
games.description: A high-risk, high-reward poker variant that tests players' courage and hand evaluation skills. Each player receives cards (the number varies by variant), and there's a betting round. Players then simultaneously decide whether to 'stay in' or 'fold' without seeing other players' decisions. After all decisions are made, players reveal their hands. The best hand among those who stayed in wins the pot. However, all players who stayed in and lost must pay double the pot amount, making it extremely costly to stay in with a weak hand. This creates a high-stakes game where players must have the 'guts' to stay in, but face severe penalties if they're wrong. Guts is known for creating large pots and dramatic moments.

games.name: Two Card Guts
games.description: A Guts variant that uses two-card hands, creating a fast-paced and high-risk game. Each player receives two cards, and there's a betting round. Players then simultaneously decide whether to 'stay in' or 'fold'. After all decisions are made, players reveal their two-card hands. The best two-card hand among those who stayed in wins the pot (hand rankings: pair is highest, then high card). However, all players who stayed in and lost must pay double the pot amount. With only two cards, hand evaluation is simpler but the risk is just as high. Two Card Guts is extremely fast-paced and creates dramatic moments as players must quickly decide if their two cards are strong enough to risk staying in.

games.name: Three Card Guts
games.description: A Guts variant that uses three-card hands, balancing hand strength evaluation with the high-risk Guts mechanics. Each player receives three cards, and there's a betting round. Players then simultaneously decide whether to 'stay in' or 'fold'. After all decisions are made, players reveal their three-card hands. The best three-card hand among those who stayed in wins the pot (hand rankings: three of a kind, straight flush, straight, flush, pair, high card). However, all players who stayed in and lost must pay double the pot amount. Three cards provide more hand possibilities than two cards, requiring more strategic evaluation, but the risk remains extremely high. Three Card Guts is popular for its balance of strategy and high-stakes action.

games.name: Hi-Lo Regular
games.description: A standard high-low split variant of Five Card Draw poker where the pot is divided between the best high hand and the best qualifying low hand. The game follows standard Five Card Draw structure: each player receives 5 cards, there's a betting round, players discard and draw new cards, followed by a final betting round. However, the pot is split between the player with the best high hand and the player with the best qualifying low hand. Aces can be used as either high or low cards, giving players flexibility. The best high hand and the best qualifying low hand (typically A-2-3-4-5, known as the wheel) each win half the pot. If no player has a qualifying low hand, the high hand takes the entire pot.

games.name: Hold'em Hi-Lo
games.description: A split-pot variant of Texas Hold'em, also known as 'Hold'em 8 or Better', where the pot is divided between the best high hand and the best qualifying low hand. Each player receives two private hole cards, and five community cards are dealt in the standard Hold'em fashion (flop, turn, river). The pot is split between the player with the best high hand and the player with the best qualifying low hand (typically requiring five unpaired cards 8 or lower, with A-2-3-4-5 being the best low). Players can use any combination of their two hole cards and the five community cards for both their high and low hands. Aces can be used as either high or low. The best high hand and the best qualifying low hand each win half the pot. If no player has a qualifying low hand, the high hand takes the entire pot.

games.name: Hollywood
games.description: A poker variant that uses the Hollywood scoring system, similar to Hollywood Gin Rummy. The game follows standard poker structure with betting rounds, but scoring works differently: each hand's points are added to three separate game scores (Game 1, Game 2, and Game 3). Game 1 starts first, and when it reaches a target score, Game 2 begins. When Game 2 reaches the target, Game 3 begins. Games end at different times, and the player who wins two out of three games wins the match. This scoring system adds strategic depth as players must consider which game to prioritize and how to manage their scores across all three games. It's a popular variant in home games.

games.name: Hurricane
games.description: A poker variant with special rules that distinguish it from standard poker games. The game follows a poker structure with betting rounds, but includes unique rule variations that may involve wild cards, special hand rankings, or modified betting structures. The specific rules vary by house rules, but the game maintains the core poker mechanics of betting and hand comparison. Players compete to make the best hand according to the variant's specific rules, and the best hand wins the pot. Hurricane is popular in home games where players enjoy experimenting with different poker variants.

games.name: Iron Cross Hi-Lo
games.description: A split-pot variant of Iron Cross poker that combines the cross-pattern layout with high-low split rules. Cards are dealt in a cross pattern (typically 5 cards in a row and 5 cards in a column, intersecting at the center). The center card where the cross intersects becomes a wild card. The pot is split between the player with the best high hand and the player with the best qualifying low hand. Players use the cards in the cross pattern along with their hole cards (if any) to make both their high and low hands. Aces can be used as either high or low. The best high hand and the best qualifying low hand (typically A-2-3-4-5) each win half the pot. The cross layout and wild center card create unique strategic situations.

games.name: Jacks Back
games.description: A poker variant where all jacks are wild cards, creating action-packed hands with frequent high-value combinations. The game can be played in various formats (Draw, Stud, or community card games). With 4 jacks acting as wild cards, players frequently make strong hands like four of a kind, straight flushes, and even five of a kind. The game follows standard poker structure with betting rounds. The best five-card hand wins the pot. The abundance of wild cards makes this a high-action game where even modest starting hands can become winners. Jacks Back is popular in home games for its exciting gameplay.

games.name: Jacks or Better
games.description: A video poker variant that can be adapted for table play, where players must have at least a pair of jacks to win. The game follows Five Card Draw structure: each player receives 5 cards, there's a betting round, players discard and draw new cards, followed by a final betting round. However, to win the pot, a player must have at least a pair of jacks or better (two pair, three of a kind, straight, flush, full house, four of a kind, straight flush, or royal flush). If no player has at least a pair of jacks, the pot carries over to the next hand. This rule creates more action as players need stronger hands to win, and it's popular in both video poker and home games.

games.name: Kansas City
games.description: A poker variant where the lowest card in each player's hand becomes a wild card for that player only. The game can be played in various formats (Draw, Stud, or community card games). This means different players may have different wild cards, creating interesting strategic situations. For example, if you have a 2 in your hand, all 2s become wild for you, but if another player has a 3 as their lowest card, all 3s become wild for them. The game follows standard poker structure with betting rounds. The best five-card hand wins the pot. The dynamic wild card system adds extra action and strategic depth as players must evaluate their hand strength based on their personal wild card.

games.name: Kansas City Lowball
games.description: A lowball variant of Kansas City poker where the lowest hand wins instead of the highest. Like standard Kansas City, the lowest card in each player's hand becomes a wild card for that player only. However, in this lowball variant, players want to make the worst possible hand according to standard poker rankings. Aces are typically low, and the best low hand is usually A-2-3-4-5 (the wheel). Straights and flushes may or may not count against you depending on the specific variant. The dynamic wild card system adds complexity as players must balance using their wild card to improve their low hand. The player with the lowest qualifying hand wins the pot.

games.name: Lazy Pineapple Hi-Lo
games.description: A split-pot variant of Lazy Pineapple that combines the simplified Pineapple structure with high-low split rules. Each player receives three private hole cards and keeps all three throughout the hand without discarding. Five community cards are dealt in the standard Hold'em fashion (flop, turn, river). The pot is split between the player with the best high hand and the player with the best qualifying low hand. Players must use exactly two of their three hole cards combined with three community cards for both their high and low hands. Aces can be used as either high or low. The best high hand and the best qualifying low hand (typically A-2-3-4-5) each win half the pot.

games.name: Little Chicago Hi-Lo
games.description: A split-pot variant of Little Chicago that combines the spade bonus feature with high-low split rules. Like standard Little Chicago, the player with the highest spade face down (in the hole) wins a portion of the pot. However, in this hi-lo variant, the pot is split three ways: between the player with the best high hand, the player with the best qualifying low hand, and the player with the highest hidden spade. If the same player has the highest hidden spade and wins either the high or low, they receive that portion plus the spade bonus. The game follows standard poker structure with betting rounds. This variant adds multiple ways to win portions of the pot.

games.name: Low Chicago
games.description: A variant of Chicago poker that inverts the spade bonus by awarding it to the lowest spade face down instead of the highest. The game follows standard poker structure (typically Seven Card Stud) with betting rounds. In addition to competing for the best poker hand, players also compete for the lowest spade that is face down (in the hole). The pot is split between the player with the lowest spade face down and the player with the best five-card hand. If the same player has both the lowest hidden spade and the best hand, they win the entire pot. This variant adds an extra strategic element as players must consider both their hand strength and their hidden spade when making betting decisions.

games.name: Ace to Five Lowball
games.description: A lowball poker variant where the lowest hand wins, using Ace-to-Five lowball rules. Aces are always low (worth 1), and the best possible hand is 5-4-3-2-A (known as the 'wheel' or 'bicycle'). Straights and flushes do not count against you, meaning they're treated as high-card hands. The game can be played in various formats including Draw, Stud, and community card games. Players want to make the worst possible hand according to standard poker rankings, with the wheel being the best low hand. The player with the lowest qualifying hand wins the pot. Ace-to-Five Lowball is one of the most popular lowball variants.

games.name: Deuce to Seven Lowball
games.description: A lowball poker variant, also known as 'Kansas City Lowball' or '2-7 Lowball', where the lowest hand wins using Deuce-to-Seven rules. Aces are always high (worth 14), and straights and flushes count against you, making them bad hands. The best possible hand is 7-5-4-3-2 (all different suits, no pair, no straight, no flush). The game can be played in various formats including Draw, Stud, and community card games. This variant is more challenging than Ace-to-Five because straights and flushes hurt your hand, and aces are high rather than low. The player with the lowest qualifying hand wins the pot. Deuce-to-Seven Lowball is popular in high-stakes games and is considered more skillful than Ace-to-Five.

games.name: Triple Draw Lowball
games.description: A lowball poker variant that gives players three opportunities to improve their low hand through drawing. Each player receives 5 cards face down. The game features three rounds of betting and drawing: players bet, then discard and draw new cards, bet again, discard and draw again, bet a third time, discard and draw a final time, then have a final betting round. Players want to make the lowest possible hand (typically using Ace-to-Five or Deuce-to-Seven rules). The three drawing rounds provide multiple opportunities to improve, making it a more strategic game than single-draw lowball. The player with the lowest qualifying hand wins the pot. Triple Draw Lowball is popular in both limit and no-limit formats.

games.name: Mad Marie
games.description: A poker variant with special rules that distinguish it from standard poker games. The game follows a poker structure with betting rounds, but includes unique rule variations that may involve wild cards, special hand rankings, or modified betting structures. The specific rules vary by house rules, but the game maintains the core poker mechanics of betting and hand comparison. Players compete to make the best hand according to the variant's specific rules, and the best hand wins the pot. Mad Marie is popular in home games where players enjoy experimenting with different poker variants.

games.name: Mexican Poker
games.description: A poker variant that follows Mexican poker rules, which may differ from standard American poker rules in betting structure, hand rankings, or other specific rules. The game follows standard poker structure with betting rounds, but the specific rules (such as betting limits, blind structures, or hand rankings) follow Mexican conventions. Mexican Poker maintains the core poker mechanics of betting and hand comparison, but with rule variations that reflect Mexican poker traditions. Players compete to make the best hand according to Mexican poker rules, and the best hand wins the pot.

games.name: Midnight Baseball
games.description: A variant of Baseball poker that adds an extra layer of wild card determination, typically played late at night (hence the name). Like standard Baseball, 3s and 9s are wild cards, and 4s dealt face down allow a free card (no betting required). However, in Midnight Baseball, the last card dealt to any player determines an additional wild card rank. For example, if the last card dealt is a 7, then all 7s also become wild cards. This creates even more action and higher-value hands than standard Baseball. The game follows Seven Card Stud structure with betting rounds, and the best five-card hand wins. The dynamic wild card determination adds strategic depth as players must adapt to the final wild card rank.

games.name: Mixed Game
games.description: A poker format that rotates through different poker variants, with each variant played for a set number of hands before moving to the next. The rotation typically includes popular variants like Texas Hold'em, Omaha, Seven Card Stud, Five Card Draw, Razz, and other poker games. Each variant is played for a predetermined number of hands (often 2, 4, or 6 hands) before the game moves to the next variant in the rotation. This format tests players' versatility and adaptability across multiple poker variants rather than specializing in just one. It prevents any single player from dominating by being an expert in just one game type, and it keeps the game interesting with constant variety. Mixed games are popular in both home games and professional poker tournaments.

games.name: Omaha Eight or Better
games.description: A split-pot variant of Omaha, also known as 'Omaha 8 or Better' or 'Omaha Hi-Lo', where the pot is divided between the best high hand and the best qualifying low hand (8 or better). Each player receives four private hole cards, and five community cards are dealt in the standard Hold'em fashion. The pot is split between the player with the best high hand and the player with the best qualifying low hand (typically requiring five unpaired cards 8 or lower, with A-2-3-4-5 being the best low). Players must use exactly two hole cards combined with three community cards for both their high and low hands. Aces can be used as either high or low. The best high hand and the best qualifying low hand each win half the pot. If no player has a qualifying low hand, the high hand takes the entire pot.

games.name: Omaha Hi-Lo Fixed Limit
games.description: A fixed-limit betting variant of Omaha Hi-Lo where bet sizes are predetermined and structured. The game follows standard Omaha Hi-Lo rules: each player receives four hole cards, five community cards are dealt, and the pot is split between the best high hand and the best qualifying low hand. However, betting is restricted to fixed amounts (e.g., $2/$4, $5/$10), with smaller bets in early betting rounds and larger bets in later rounds. Players can only bet or raise in these fixed increments, creating more structured and predictable betting. Fixed limit games are popular for their controlled action and are often preferred by players who want to limit their risk.

games.name: Omaha Hi-Lo Pot Limit
games.description: A pot-limit betting variant of Omaha Hi-Lo where the maximum bet is limited to the current pot size. The game follows standard Omaha Hi-Lo rules: each player receives four hole cards, five community cards are dealt, and the pot is split between the best high hand and the best qualifying low hand. However, betting is restricted to pot limit, meaning players can bet or raise up to the size of the current pot. This creates a balance between fixed limit (more controlled) and no limit (more aggressive) betting. Pot limit Omaha Hi-Lo is extremely popular in both live and online poker rooms, offering strategic depth while preventing extremely large all-in bets.

games.name: Omaha Hi-Lo No Limit
games.description: A no-limit betting variant of Omaha Hi-Lo where players can bet any amount up to their entire stack at any time. The game follows standard Omaha Hi-Lo rules: each player receives four hole cards, five community cards are dealt, and the pot is split between the best high hand and the best qualifying low hand. However, betting is unrestricted, allowing players to go all-in or make any bet size they choose. This creates the most aggressive and high-stakes version of Omaha Hi-Lo, where players can put their entire stack at risk. No limit games are popular for their excitement and the potential for large pots, though they require strong bankroll management.

games.name: Pass the Trash
games.description: A poker variant that adds a card-passing mechanic to create dynamic and unpredictable gameplay. Each player receives 5 cards. The game features multiple passing rounds where players simultaneously pass a certain number of cards (typically 1-3 cards) to the player on their left, and receive cards from the player on their right. After each passing round, there's a betting round. The number of passing rounds varies (typically 2-3 rounds). Players must strategically decide which cards to pass while trying to improve their hand with the cards they receive. After all passing and betting rounds, players reveal their hands and the best five-card poker hand wins the pot. The passing mechanic creates interesting strategic situations and adds an element of luck.

games.name: Pineapple Hi-Lo
games.description: A split-pot variant of Pineapple that combines the discarding mechanic with high-low split rules. Each player receives three private hole cards. After the flop (first three community cards) is dealt, players must discard one of their hole cards, leaving them with two hole cards for the remainder of the hand. The pot is split between the player with the best high hand and the player with the best qualifying low hand. Players must use exactly two of their remaining hole cards combined with three community cards for both their high and low hands. Aces can be used as either high or low. The best high hand and the best qualifying low hand (typically A-2-3-4-5) each win half the pot. The discarding decision after the flop adds strategic depth.

games.name: Pineapple Crazy Hi-Lo
games.description: A split-pot variant of Crazy Pineapple that combines the double-discarding mechanic with high-low split rules. Each player receives three private hole cards. After the flop (first three community cards), players discard one hole card. After the turn (fourth community card), players discard another hole card, leaving them with just one hole card for the river. The pot is split between the player with the best high hand and the player with the best qualifying low hand. Players must use exactly two hole cards combined with three community cards for both their high and low hands, but since they only have one hole card remaining after the turn, they must use that one plus one of the two previously discarded cards. Aces can be used as either high or low. The best high hand and the best qualifying low hand each win half the pot.

games.name: Razz Hi-Lo
games.description: A split-pot variant of Razz that combines lowball Stud with high-hand competition. The game follows Seven Card Stud structure: each player receives seven cards (some face up, some face down), and there are betting rounds. However, the pot is split between the player with the best low hand (following Razz rules: aces low, straights and flushes don't count, best low is A-2-3-4-5) and the player with the best high hand (using standard poker rankings). Players must use exactly two cards from their hand to make their low hand and exactly two (potentially different) cards to make their high hand. This variant requires players to balance their strategy between pursuing high and low hands simultaneously, making it a true test of all-around poker ability.

games.name: Roll Your Own
games.description: A Stud poker variant that gives players control over which of their cards are revealed. Each player receives cards face down (typically 5-7 cards depending on the variant). Players then choose which cards to turn face up, creating their own 'upcards' strategically. There are betting rounds between the card reveals, and players must decide when to reveal cards and which ones to show. This creates interesting strategic situations as players try to control the information available to opponents while maximizing their own hand strength. The game follows Stud structure with betting rounds, and the best five-card hand wins the pot. Roll Your Own adds a unique strategic element not found in standard Stud games.

games.name: Short Deck Omaha
games.description: An Omaha variant that uses a shortened 36-card deck (removing all cards from 2 through 5, keeping only 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, Jack, Queen, King, and Ace). Each player receives four private hole cards, and five community cards are dealt in the standard Hold'em fashion. Players must use exactly two hole cards combined with three community cards to make their best five-card hand. The reduced deck creates modified hand rankings: a flush beats a full house (because flushes are harder to make with fewer cards), and three of a kind beats a straight (because straights are easier to make). The game follows standard Omaha betting structure. Short Deck Omaha is popular in high-stakes games and creates more action with bigger hands.

games.name: Short Deck Hold'em
games.description: A Hold'em variant that uses a shortened 36-card deck (removing all cards from 2 through 5, keeping only 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, Jack, Queen, King, and Ace). Each player receives two private hole cards, and five community cards are dealt in the standard Hold'em fashion (flop, turn, river). The reduced deck creates modified hand rankings: a flush beats a full house (because flushes are harder to make with fewer cards), and three of a kind beats a straight (because straights are easier to make). The game follows standard Hold'em betting structure with pre-flop, flop, turn, and river betting rounds. Short Deck Hold'em is popular in high-stakes games and online poker rooms, known for its action-packed nature and frequent big hands.

games.name: Six Plus Omaha
games.description: Another name for Short Deck Omaha, an Omaha variant that uses a shortened 36-card deck (removing all cards from 2 through 5, keeping only 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, Jack, Queen, King, and Ace). Each player receives four private hole cards, and five community cards are dealt. Players must use exactly two hole cards combined with three community cards to make their best five-card hand. The reduced deck creates modified hand rankings: a flush beats a full house, and three of a kind beats a straight. The game follows standard Omaha betting structure. Six Plus Omaha is popular in high-stakes games and creates more action with bigger hands due to the modified rankings.

games.name: Seven Card Stud Eight or Better
games.description: A split-pot variant of Seven Card Stud, also known as 'Stud 8 or Better' or 'Stud Hi-Lo', where the pot is divided between the best high hand and the best qualifying low hand (8 or better). The game follows Seven Card Stud structure: each player receives seven cards (some face up, some face down), and there are betting rounds. The pot is split between the player with the best high hand and the player with the best qualifying low hand (typically requiring five unpaired cards 8 or lower, with A-2-3-4-5 being the best low). Players must use exactly two cards from their hand to make their high hand and exactly two (potentially different) cards to make their low hand. Aces can be used as either high or low. The best high hand and the best qualifying low hand each win half the pot.

games.name: Stud Hi-Lo Fixed Limit
games.description: A fixed-limit betting variant of Seven Card Stud Hi-Lo where bet sizes are predetermined and structured. The game follows standard Stud Hi-Lo rules: each player receives seven cards, and the pot is split between the best high hand and the best qualifying low hand. However, betting is restricted to fixed amounts (e.g., $2/$4, $5/$10), with smaller bets in early betting rounds and larger bets in later rounds. Players can only bet or raise in these fixed increments, creating more structured and predictable betting. Fixed limit games are popular for their controlled action and are often preferred by players who want to limit their risk while still enjoying the strategic depth of Stud Hi-Lo.

games.name: Stud Hi-Lo Pot Limit
games.description: A pot-limit betting variant of Seven Card Stud Hi-Lo where the maximum bet is limited to the current pot size. The game follows standard Stud Hi-Lo rules: each player receives seven cards, and the pot is split between the best high hand and the best qualifying low hand. However, betting is restricted to pot limit, meaning players can bet or raise up to the size of the current pot. This creates a balance between fixed limit (more controlled) and no limit (more aggressive) betting. Pot limit Stud Hi-Lo is popular in both live and online poker rooms, offering strategic depth while preventing extremely large all-in bets.

games.name: Stud Hi-Lo No Limit
games.description: A no-limit betting variant of Seven Card Stud Hi-Lo where players can bet any amount up to their entire stack at any time. The game follows standard Stud Hi-Lo rules: each player receives seven cards, and the pot is split between the best high hand and the best qualifying low hand. However, betting is unrestricted, allowing players to go all-in or make any bet size they choose. This creates the most aggressive and high-stakes version of Stud Hi-Lo, where players can put their entire stack at risk. No limit games are popular for their excitement and the potential for large pots, though they require strong bankroll management and strategic discipline.

games.name: Tahoe
games.description: A poker variant with special rules that distinguish it from standard poker games. The game follows a poker structure with betting rounds, but includes unique rule variations that may involve wild cards, special hand rankings, or modified betting structures. The specific rules vary by house rules, but the game maintains the core poker mechanics of betting and hand comparison. Players compete to make the best hand according to the variant's specific rules, and the best hand wins the pot. Tahoe is popular in home games where players enjoy experimenting with different poker variants.

games.name: Texas Hold'em Fixed Limit
games.description: A fixed-limit betting variant of Texas Hold'em where bet sizes are predetermined and structured. The game follows standard Hold'em rules: each player receives two hole cards, and five community cards are dealt. However, betting is restricted to fixed amounts (e.g., $2/$4, $5/$10), with smaller bets in early betting rounds and larger bets in later rounds. Players can only bet or raise in these fixed increments, creating more structured and predictable betting. Fixed limit Hold'em was the original format of the game and is still popular in both live and online poker rooms. It's often preferred by players who want controlled action and more mathematical gameplay.

games.name: Texas Hold'em Pot Limit
games.description: A pot-limit betting variant of Texas Hold'em where the maximum bet is limited to the current pot size. The game follows standard Hold'em rules: each player receives two hole cards, and five community cards are dealt. However, betting is restricted to pot limit, meaning players can bet or raise up to the size of the current pot. This creates a balance between fixed limit (more controlled) and no limit (more aggressive) betting. Pot limit Hold'em is extremely popular in both live and online poker rooms, particularly in Europe. It offers strategic depth while preventing extremely large all-in bets, making it appealing to players who want action without the extreme variance of no limit.

games.name: Texas Hold'em No Limit
games.description: The most popular variant of Texas Hold'em where players can bet any amount up to their entire stack at any time. The game follows standard Hold'em rules: each player receives two hole cards, and five community cards are dealt in stages (flop, turn, river). However, betting is completely unrestricted, allowing players to go all-in or make any bet size they choose. This creates the most aggressive and high-stakes version of Hold'em, where players can put their entire stack at risk. No limit Hold'em is the format used in the World Series of Poker Main Event and most televised poker, making it the most recognizable poker format worldwide. It requires strong bankroll management and strategic discipline.

games.name: Texas Hold'em Hi-Lo
games.description: A split-pot variant of Texas Hold'em, also known as 'Hold'em 8 or Better', where the pot is divided between the best high hand and the best qualifying low hand. Each player receives two private hole cards, and five community cards are dealt in the standard Hold'em fashion (flop, turn, river). The pot is split between the player with the best high hand and the player with the best qualifying low hand (typically requiring five unpaired cards 8 or lower, with A-2-3-4-5 being the best low). Players can use any combination of their two hole cards and the five community cards for both their high and low hands. Aces can be used as either high or low. The best high hand and the best qualifying low hand each win half the pot. If no player has a qualifying low hand, the high hand takes the entire pot.

games.name: Tornado
games.description: A poker variant with special rules that distinguish it from standard poker games. The game follows a poker structure with betting rounds, but includes unique rule variations that may involve wild cards, special hand rankings, or modified betting structures. The specific rules vary by house rules, but the game maintains the core poker mechanics of betting and hand comparison. Players compete to make the best hand according to the variant's specific rules, and the best hand wins the pot. Tornado is popular in home games where players enjoy experimenting with different poker variants.

games.name: Triple Draw Lowball
games.description: A lowball poker variant that gives players three opportunities to improve their low hand through drawing, using Ace-to-Five lowball rules. Each player receives 5 cards face down. The game features three rounds of betting and drawing: players bet, then discard and draw new cards, bet again, discard and draw again, bet a third time, discard and draw a final time, then have a final betting round. Aces are low, and straights and flushes don't count against you. The best possible hand is 5-4-3-2-A (the wheel). The three drawing rounds provide multiple opportunities to improve, making it a more strategic game than single-draw lowball. The player with the lowest qualifying hand wins the pot. Triple Draw Lowball is popular in both limit and no-limit formats.

games.name: Wild Widow
games.description: A poker variant that determines wild cards through a 'widow' card dealt face up before play begins. One card is dealt face up in the center (the 'widow'), and all cards of that rank become wild cards for the entire hand. For example, if the widow is a 7, then all 7s are wild. The game can be played in various formats (Draw, Stud, or community card games). The game follows standard poker structure with betting rounds, and the best five-card hand wins the pot. The wild widow card adds action and creates more high-value hands. Players must adapt their strategy based on which rank becomes wild, making it an interesting variant that combines luck with skill.

games.name: Wildcard
games.description: A poker variant where the wild card rank changes each hand, creating variety and requiring players to adapt their strategy. The wild card rank rotates through different cards each hand (for example, 2s might be wild in the first hand, 3s in the second, 4s in the third, etc.). The game can be played in various formats (Draw, Stud, or community card games). The game follows standard poker structure with betting rounds, and the best five-card hand wins the pot. The rotating wild cards add excitement and prevent players from relying on a single strategy. Players must adapt to the changing wild card rank, making it a dynamic and engaging variant.

games.name: Worm
games.description: A poker variant with special rules that distinguish it from standard poker games. The game follows a poker structure with betting rounds, but includes unique rule variations that may involve wild cards, special hand rankings, or modified betting structures. The specific rules vary by house rules, but the game maintains the core poker mechanics of betting and hand comparison. Players compete to make the best hand according to the variant's specific rules, and the best hand wins the pot. Worm is popular in home games where players enjoy experimenting with different poker variants.

games.name: Xyz
games.description: A poker variant where three specific ranks are designated as wild cards, represented by X, Y, and Z (typically corresponding to three specific ranks, such as 10s, Jacks, and Queens, or other combinations). All cards of these three ranks become wild cards, creating action-packed hands with frequent high-value combinations. With 12 wild cards in the deck (4 of each rank), players frequently make strong hands like four of a kind, straight flushes, and even five of a kind. The game can be played in various formats (Draw, Stud, or community card games) and follows standard poker structure with betting rounds. The best five-card hand wins the pot. The abundance of wild cards makes this a high-action game.

games.name: Buraco
games.description: A popular Rummy variant from South America, particularly popular in Brazil and Argentina, that combines elements of Canasta and traditional Rummy. The game uses two standard decks plus jokers (108 cards total). Four players play in partnerships (two teams of two). Each player is dealt 11 cards, and the remaining cards form a stock pile with a discard pile. Players form sets (three or more cards of the same rank) and sequences (three or more consecutive cards of the same suit). To go out, a team must form at least one 'canasta' (a meld of seven or more cards). The game features special scoring for canastas and bonuses for going out. The first team to reach a target score (typically 2000 points) wins the game. Buraco requires strategic partnership play, careful melding, and skillful use of jokers.

games.name: Sueca
games.description: A popular trick-taking card game from Portugal, played extensively throughout Portuguese-speaking countries. The game is played by four players in partnerships (two teams of two) using a 40-card deck (standard deck with 8s, 9s, and 10s removed). Each player receives 10 cards. The trump suit is determined by the last card dealt (turned face up), and that suit becomes trump for the entire hand. Players must follow suit if possible, and the highest card of the led suit or the highest trump wins the trick. Teams score points for winning tricks, with special values for certain cards. The first team to reach 60 points wins the game. Sueca is known for its strategic depth, partnership communication, and the importance of trump management.

games.name: Copas
games.description: A Portuguese trick-taking game for exactly four players in partnerships. The game uses a 40-card deck (typically removing 8s, 9s, and 10s from a standard deck). Each player receives 10 cards, and players compete in tricks. Partnerships score points for tricks won, and the first team to reach the target score wins the game.

games.name: Truco Argentino
games.description: The Argentine variant of Truco, a popular trick-taking card game from South America. The game is played by four players in partnerships (two teams of two) using a 40-card deck (standard deck with 8s, 9s, and 10s removed). Each player receives 3 cards. The game features special card rankings that differ from standard trick-taking games, with certain cards having higher values. Players play tricks, but the game includes a unique 'truco' (challenge) mechanic where players can raise the stakes during play. Bluffing and psychological play are integral parts of the game, as players can challenge opponents to increase the point value of the hand. The first team to reach 30 points wins the game. Truco Argentino is known for its fast-paced action, strategic challenges, and the importance of reading opponents.

games.name: Truco Brasileiro
games.description: The Brazilian variant of Truco, a popular trick-taking card game from South America. The game is played by four players in partnerships (two teams of two) using a 40-card deck (standard deck with 8s, 9s, and 10s removed). Each player receives 3 cards. The game features special card rankings that differ from standard trick-taking games, with certain cards having higher values. Players play tricks, but the game includes a unique 'truco' (challenge) mechanic where players can raise the stakes during play. Bluffing and psychological play are integral parts of the game, as players can challenge opponents to increase the point value of the hand. The first team to reach 12 points wins the game. Truco Brasileiro is known for its fast-paced action, strategic challenges, and the importance of reading opponents.

games.name: Tute
games.description: A popular trick-taking card game from Spain, played extensively throughout Spanish-speaking countries. The game is played by four players in partnerships (two teams of two) using a 40-card deck (standard deck with 8s, 9s, and 10s removed). Each player receives 8 cards. The trump suit is determined by the last card dealt (turned face up), and that suit becomes trump for the entire hand. Players must follow suit if possible, and the highest card of the led suit or the highest trump wins the trick. Teams score points for winning tricks, but also score bonus points for 'marriages' (holding both the King and Queen of the trump suit). The first team to reach 100 points wins the game. Tute is known for its strategic depth, partnership play, and the importance of trump management and marriage bonuses.

games.name: Tute Cabrero
games.description: A variant of Tute with different scoring rules and special combinations. The game is played by four players in partnerships (two teams of two) using a 40-card deck. The game follows standard Tute structure with trick-taking and trump suits, but features modified scoring that emphasizes special card combinations beyond just marriages. Players score points for winning tricks and for forming specific combinations of cards. The scoring differences make this variant more complex and strategic than standard Tute, as players must balance pursuing tricks with forming valuable combinations. The first team to reach the target score wins the game.

games.name: Schwyzer Jass
games.description: A Swiss variant of Jass, a popular trick-taking card game from Switzerland. The game is played by four players in partnerships (two teams of two) using a 36-card deck (standard deck with 2s, 3s, 4s, and 5s removed). Each player receives 9 cards. The game features a bidding phase where players bid to determine the trump suit for the hand. After bidding, players take tricks following suit when possible, with the highest card of the led suit or the highest trump winning the trick. Teams score points for winning tricks and for forming special combinations of cards (such as sequences or sets). The first team to reach the target score wins the game. Schwyzer Jass is known for its strategic bidding, partnership play, and the importance of combination scoring.

games.name: Coiffeur Jass
games.description: A variant of Jass with different rules and scoring mechanics. The game is played by four players in partnerships (two teams of two) using a standard Jass deck. The game follows standard Jass structure with trick-taking and trump suits, but features modified rules that may affect bidding, card play, or scoring. Players take tricks following suit when possible, and teams score points for winning tricks and for forming special combinations of cards. The rule variations make this variant distinct from standard Jass, requiring players to adapt their strategy. The first team to reach the target score wins the game.

games.name: Bayerischer Schafkopf
games.description: The Bavarian variant of Schafkopf, a popular trick-taking card game from Germany. The game is played by four players using a 32-card deck (standard deck with 2s, 3s, 4s, 5s, and 6s removed). Each player receives 8 cards. The game features a bidding phase where players bid to determine the game type, which can include different trump arrangements and partnership structures. After bidding, players take tricks following suit when possible, with scoring based on the specific game type chosen. The game includes various game types with different rules and scoring methods. The first player or team to reach 61 points wins the game. Bayerischer Schafkopf is known for its complex bidding system, multiple game types, and strategic depth.

games.name: Wendischer Schafkopf
games.description: A variant of Schafkopf with different rules and scoring mechanics. The game is played by four players using a standard Schafkopf deck. The game follows standard Schafkopf structure with trick-taking and trump suits, but features modified rules that may affect bidding, card play, or scoring. Players take tricks following suit when possible, and teams score points for winning tricks. The rule variations make this variant distinct from standard Schafkopf, requiring players to adapt their strategy. The first player or team to reach the target score wins the game.

games.name: Tournament Doppelkopf
games.description: A tournament variant of Doppelkopf with standardized rules for competitive play. The game is played by four players using two standard decks (104 cards total). The game follows standard Doppelkopf structure with trick-taking, but tournament rules standardize bidding, scoring, and gameplay to ensure fair competition. Players take tricks following suit when possible, and teams score points for winning tricks. The tournament format may include specific rules about partnerships, scoring systems, and game length. The first team to reach the target score wins the game. Tournament Doppelkopf is used in official competitions and ensures consistent rules across different playing groups.

games.name: Ramsch
games.description: A variant of Skat where all three players compete individually against each other, with negative scoring. The game is played by three players using a 32-card deck. Unlike standard Skat, there is no declarer or bidding phase. All players play against each other, and the player who takes the most tricks (and therefore the most points) actually loses the hand and receives negative points. This creates an interesting dynamic where players want to avoid taking too many tricks, but also can't let opponents take too few. The game uses negative scoring, meaning players lose points rather than gain them. Ramsch is often played when no player wants to bid in standard Skat, or as a penalty game.

games.name: Grand
games.description: A game type in Skat where only the four jacks are trumps, making it one of the highest-value game types. The game is played by three players using a 32-card deck. Through bidding, one player becomes the declarer and plays against the other two players. In Grand, only the four jacks (one of each suit) are trumps, and they rank in a specific order. All other cards follow suit normally, with no additional trumps. The declarer must take at least 61 points in tricks to win. Grand is a high-risk, high-reward game type that requires careful play, as the declarer has very limited trumps. The scoring is based on the number of tricks and points taken, with Grand being worth more points than standard suit games.

games.name: Null
games.description: A game type in Skat where the declarer must take zero tricks to win, making it one of the most challenging and high-scoring game types.
