The game is played by three players using a 32-card deck. Through bidding, one player becomes the declarer and plays against the other two players. In Null, there are no trumps, and cards rank in their natural order. The declarer must take absolutely no tricks to win the hand - if they take even one trick, they lose. This creates an extremely challenging situation where the declarer must play their cards in such a way that they never win a trick, while the opponents try to force them to take one. Null is a high-risk, high-reward game type that requires exceptional card play and strategic thinking.

games.name: Null Ouvert
games.description: An even more challenging variant of Null where the declarer plays with all their cards face up, making it the highest-scoring and most difficult game type in Skat. The game is played by three players using a 32-card deck. Through bidding, one player becomes the declarer and plays against the other two players. In Null Ouvert, there are no trumps, and the declarer must play with all their cards visible to the opponents. The declarer must take absolutely no tricks to win the hand. Playing with cards face up makes this extremely difficult, as opponents can see exactly what the declarer holds and can coordinate to force them to take a trick. Null Ouvert is the ultimate test of card play skill in Skat and offers the highest possible score.

games.name: Belote Coincée
games.description: A variant of Belote with different rules and scoring mechanics. The game is played by four players in partnerships (two teams of two) using a 32-card deck. The game follows standard Belote structure with trick-taking and trump suits, but features modified rules that may affect bidding, card play, or scoring. Players take tricks following suit when possible, and teams score points for winning tricks and for forming special combinations of cards. The rule variations make this variant distinct from standard Belote, requiring players to adapt their strategy. The first team to reach the target score wins the game.

games.name: Belote Contrée
games.description: A variant of Belote with a bidding phase that determines the trump suit. The game is played by four players in partnerships (two teams of two) using a 32-card deck. The game features a bidding phase where players bid to determine the trump suit for the hand. After bidding, players take tricks following suit when possible, with the highest card of the led suit or the highest trump winning the trick. Teams score points for winning tricks. The bidding mechanic adds strategic depth as players must evaluate their hands and bid appropriately. The first team to reach the target score wins the game.

games.name: Rotterdam Klaverjassen
games.description: A regional variant of Klaverjassen from Rotterdam, Netherlands, with local rule variations. The game is played by four players in partnerships (two teams of two) using a standard Klaverjassen deck. The game follows standard Klaverjassen structure with trick-taking and trump suits, but features regional rules specific to Rotterdam that may affect bidding, card play, or scoring. Players take tricks following suit when possible, and teams score points for winning tricks. The Rotterdam variant maintains the core mechanics of Klaverjassen while incorporating local traditions and rule preferences. The first team to reach the target score wins the game.

games.name: Amsterdam Klaverjassen
games.description: A regional variant of Klaverjassen from Amsterdam, Netherlands, with local rule variations. The game is played by four players in partnerships (two teams of two) using a standard Klaverjassen deck. The game follows standard Klaverjassen structure with trick-taking and trump suits, but features regional rules specific to Amsterdam that may affect bidding, card play, or scoring. Players take tricks following suit when possible, and teams score points for winning tricks. The Amsterdam variant maintains the core mechanics of Klaverjassen while incorporating local traditions and rule preferences. The first team to reach the target score wins the game.

games.name: Mus Txapelketa
games.description: A tournament variant of Mus with standardized rules for competitive play. The game is played by four players in partnerships (two teams of two) using a 40-card deck. The game follows standard Mus structure with betting phases and playing phases, but tournament rules standardize bidding, scoring, and gameplay to ensure fair competition. Players bet on their hands and then play cards, scoring points for specific combinations of cards (pairs, three of a kind, etc.). The tournament format may include specific rules about partnerships, scoring systems, and game length. The first team to reach the target score wins the game. Mus Txapelketa is used in official competitions and ensures consistent rules across different playing groups.

games.name: Mus Hordago
games.description: A high-stakes variant of Mus that features 'hordago' (all-in) betting, where players can bet their entire stake on a single hand. The game is played by four players in partnerships (two teams of two) using a 40-card deck. The game follows standard Mus structure with betting phases and playing phases, but the hordago mechanic allows players to go all-in, dramatically increasing the stakes. Players bet on their hands and then play cards, scoring points for specific combinations. The hordago variant is known for its high-risk, high-reward gameplay, where a single hand can determine the outcome of the entire game. This variant is popular among experienced Mus players who enjoy high-stakes action.

games.name: Briscola Chiamata Romana
games.description: A Roman variant of Briscola Chiamata (called Briscola) that adds a secret partnership element, making it a five-player game. One player (the caller) calls out a specific card that they do not have in their hand. The player who holds that card becomes the caller's secret partner, but this partnership is not revealed until the called card is actually played. The game follows standard Briscola rules: players use a 40-card deck, each receives cards, and players take tricks following suit when possible, with the trump suit determined by the last card dealt. The secret partnership adds a fascinating strategic element as players must try to identify who their partner is through gameplay while the other three players try to figure out the partnership. The first team to reach the target score wins.

games.name: Briscola Napoletana
games.description: A Neapolitan variant of Briscola with regional rule variations. The game is played by four players in partnerships (two teams of two) using a 40-card deck. The game follows standard Briscola structure with trick-taking and trump suits, but features regional rules specific to Naples that may affect card play or scoring. Players take tricks following suit when possible, with the highest card of the led suit or the highest trump winning the trick. Teams score points for winning tricks and for forming special combinations of cards. The Neapolitan variant maintains the core mechanics of Briscola while incorporating local traditions. The first team to reach the target score wins the game.

games.name: Scopa d'Assi
games.description: A variant of Scopa where aces have increased value and scoring importance. The game is played by 2-4 players using a 40-card deck. The game follows standard Scopa structure where players capture cards from the table by matching values or combinations, but in this variant, aces are worth more points in scoring. Players score points for: having the most cards, having the most diamonds (coins), capturing aces, and making 'scopa' (sweeping all cards from the table). The increased value of aces makes capturing them strategically important. The first player or team to reach 21 points wins the game. Scopa d'Assi adds an extra layer of strategy through ace valuation.

games.name: Scopa a Quindici
games.description: A variant of Scopa where players capture cards that total exactly 15, rather than matching individual values. The game is played by 2-4 players using a 40-card deck. The game follows standard Scopa structure, but the capturing mechanic is different: players must capture cards from the table that sum to exactly 15 when combined with the card they play. For example, if a 7 is on the table and you play an 8, you capture the 7 (7+8=15). This creates different strategic considerations than standard Scopa. The scoring system is also modified to reflect this different capturing mechanic. The first player or team to reach the target score wins the game. Scopa a Quindici offers a unique mathematical challenge.

games.name: Scopa Un Sette
games.description: A variant of Scopa where the seven of diamonds (sette bello) has special significance and scoring value. The game is played by 2-4 players using a 40-card deck. The game follows standard Scopa structure where players capture cards from the table by matching values or combinations. However, the seven of diamonds is particularly valuable and has special scoring rules. Players score points for various combinations and achievements, with the seven of diamonds playing a key role in scoring. The first player or team to reach the target score wins the game. Scopa Un Sette emphasizes the importance of capturing and holding the seven of diamonds.

games.name: Tressette Napoletano
games.description: A Neapolitan variant of Tressette with regional rule variations. The game is played by four players in partnerships (two teams of two) using a 40-card deck. The game follows standard Tressette structure with trick-taking and no trump suits, but features regional rules specific to Naples that may affect card play or scoring. Players must follow suit if possible, and the highest card of the led suit wins the trick. Teams score points for winning tricks and for forming special combinations of cards. The Neapolitan variant maintains the core mechanics of Tressette while incorporating local traditions. The first team to reach the target score wins the game.

games.name: Tressette Romano
games.description: A Roman variant of Tressette with regional rule variations. The game is played by four players in partnerships (two teams of two) using a 40-card deck. The game follows standard Tressette structure with trick-taking and no trump suits, but features regional rules specific to Rome that may affect card play or scoring. Players must follow suit if possible, and the highest card of the led suit wins the trick. Teams score points for winning tricks. The Roman variant maintains the core mechanics of Tressette while incorporating local traditions. The first team to reach the target score wins the game.

games.name: Piquet Rubicon
games.description: A variant of Piquet with modified scoring rules. The game is played by two players using a 32-card deck (standard deck with 2s through 6s removed). Each player receives 12 cards, and the remaining 8 cards are set aside. Players discard and draw cards to improve their hands, then make declarations (announcing combinations like sequences, sets, etc.) before playing tricks. Players score points for their declarations and for winning tricks. The game features complex scoring with bonuses for various achievements. The first player to reach 100 points wins the game. Piquet Rubicon is known for its strategic depth, requiring careful hand evaluation, declaration strategy, and trick-taking skill.

games.name: Six Pack Bezique
games.description: An extended variant of Bezique that uses six decks instead of the standard two, creating a much longer and more complex game. The game is played by two players using six standard decks (312 cards total). The game follows standard Bezique structure with trick-taking and melding, but with six times as many cards, the game becomes significantly longer. Players deal cards, play tricks, and meld combinations to score points. With so many cards, players have more opportunities to form high-value melds and the game requires more strategic planning. The first player to reach a higher target score (typically 2000 or 3000 points) wins the game. Six Pack Bezique is for players who enjoy extended gameplay sessions.

games.name: Rubicon Bezique
games.description: A variant of Bezique with modified scoring rules. The game is played by two players using two standard decks. Each player receives 8 cards, and the remaining cards form a stock pile. Players play tricks and meld combinations of cards to score points. The game combines trick-taking with melding, where players can score points for specific card combinations (like pairs, sequences, etc.) in addition to winning tricks. Players score points for their melds and for winning tricks, with complex scoring rules. The first player to reach 1000 points wins the game. Rubicon Bezique is known for its strategic depth, requiring careful hand management, melding strategy, and trick-taking skill.

games.name: Ecarte Partnership
games.description: A partnership variant of Écarté, a classic French trick-taking game, adapted for four players. The game is played by four players in partnerships (two teams of two) using a 32-card deck. Each player receives 5 cards, and the next card is turned up to determine the trump suit. Players can exchange cards with the stock pile before play begins. Players then take tricks following suit when possible, with the highest card of the led suit or the highest trump winning the trick. The first team to reach 5 points wins the game. Écarté Partnership adds the strategic element of partnership play to the classic two-player game, requiring coordination between partners.

games.name: Auction All Fours
games.description: A variant of All Fours that adds a bidding phase where players bid on how many points they will score. The game is played by 2-4 players using a standard 52-card deck. The game features a bidding phase where players bid on the number of points they believe they can score. The highest bidder becomes the dealer and leads the first trick. Players then take tricks, and points are scored for: high (highest trump card), low (lowest trump card), jack (jack of trumps), and game (most card points in tricks). The bidding mechanic adds strategic depth as players must evaluate their hands and bid appropriately. The player who makes their bid wins points; otherwise they lose points.

games.name: Schnapsen
games.description: A variant of Sixty-Six, also known as Schnapsen, that uses a reduced 20-card deck. The game is played by two players using only the Aces, 10s, Kings, Queens, and Jacks from a standard deck (20 cards total). Each player receives 5 cards, and the next card is turned up to determine the trump suit. Players take tricks following suit when possible, with the highest card of the led suit or the highest trump winning the trick. Players score points for winning tricks and for 'marriages' (holding both the King and Queen of the same suit, especially trumps). The first player to reach 66 points wins the game. Schnapsen is a fast-paced, strategic two-player game popular in Central Europe.

games.name: Bauernschnapsen
games.description: A variant of Schnapsen, also known as 'Peasant Schnapsen', with simplified rules. The game is played by two players using a 20-card deck (Aces, 10s, Kings, Queens, and Jacks). Each player receives 5 cards, and the next card is turned up to determine the trump suit. Players take tricks following suit when possible, with the highest card of the led suit or the highest trump winning the trick. Unlike standard Schnapsen, Bauernschnapsen has simplified scoring that focuses primarily on trick-taking, without the marriage bonuses. The first player to reach 66 points wins the game. Bauernschnapsen is a simpler, more straightforward version of Schnapsen that's easier to learn.

games.name: Bayrisch Watten
games.description: The Bavarian variant of Watten, a popular trick-taking card game from Austria and Bavaria. The game is played by four players in partnerships (two teams of two) using a 32-card deck. Each player receives 5 cards. The game features a bidding phase where players bid to determine the trump suit for the hand. After bidding, players take tricks following suit when possible, with the highest card of the led suit or the highest trump winning the trick. Teams score points for winning tricks. The bidding mechanic adds strategic depth as players must evaluate their hands and bid appropriately. The first team to reach the target score wins the game. Bayrisch Watten is known for its fast-paced action and strategic bidding.

games.name: Tiroler Watten
games.description: The Tyrolean variant of Watten, a popular trick-taking card game from the Tyrol region of Austria. The game is played by four players in partnerships (two teams of two) using a standard Watten deck. The game follows standard Watten structure with trick-taking and trump suits, but features regional rules specific to Tyrol that may affect bidding, card play, or scoring. Players take tricks following suit when possible, and teams score points for winning tricks. The Tyrolean variant maintains the core mechanics of Watten while incorporating local traditions. The first team to reach the target score wins the game.

games.name: Tarot Français
games.description: The classic French variant of Tarot, a complex trick-taking game using a 78-card tarot deck. The game is played by four players. Each player receives 18 cards, and 6 cards are dealt to the 'dog' (kitty), which remains hidden. The game features a bidding phase where players bid to become the declarer, who plays against the other three players. The declarer takes the dog and discards 6 cards before play begins. Players then take tricks following suit when possible, with trumps (the 22 major arcana cards) having special powers. Scoring is complex, based on the bid made, tricks taken, and special card combinations. The declarer must meet their bid to win points; otherwise they lose points. French Tarot is known for its strategic depth and is one of the most popular card games in France.

games.name: Tarot à Trois
games.description: A three-player variant of French Tarot using a 78-card tarot deck. Each player receives 24 cards, and 6 cards are dealt to the 'dog' (kitty), which remains hidden. The game features a bidding phase where players bid to become the declarer, who plays against the other two players. The declarer takes the dog and discards 6 cards before play begins. Players then take tricks following suit when possible, with trumps (the 22 major arcana cards) having special powers. Scoring is based on the bid made, tricks taken, and special card combinations. The declarer must meet their bid to win points; otherwise they lose points. Tarot à Trois adapts the complex game of French Tarot for three players, creating different strategic dynamics.

games.name: Tarot à Cinq
games.description: A five-player variant of French Tarot using a 78-card tarot deck. Each player receives 15 cards, and 3 cards are dealt to the 'dog' (kitty), which remains hidden. The game features a bidding phase where players bid to become the declarer, who plays against the other four players. The declarer takes the dog and discards 3 cards before play begins. Players then take tricks following suit when possible, with trumps (the 22 major arcana cards) having special powers. Scoring is based on the bid made, tricks taken, and special card combinations. The declarer must meet their bid to win points; otherwise they lose points. Tarot à Cinq adapts the complex game of French Tarot for five players, creating different strategic dynamics with more players.

games.name: American Sheepshead
games.description: The American variant of Sheepshead, a trick-taking card game popular in German-American communities. The game is played by five players using a 32-card deck. Each player receives 6 cards, and 2 cards are dealt to the 'kitty' (blind). The game features a bidding phase where players bid to become the 'picker', who takes the kitty and discards 2 cards before play begins. The picker plays against the other four players, but partnerships may form during play based on card play. Players take tricks following suit when possible, with special card rankings. Scoring is based on tricks taken and special card combinations. The picker must meet their bid to win points; otherwise they lose points. American Sheepshead is known for its complex bidding and partnership dynamics.

games.name: Partnership Sheepshead
games.description: A partnership variant of Sheepshead where players form fixed teams. The game is played by four players in partnerships (two teams of two) using a 32-card deck. Each player receives 8 cards. Unlike standard Sheepshead where partnerships form during play, in Partnership Sheepshead the teams are fixed from the start. Players take tricks following suit when possible, with special card rankings. Teams score points for winning tricks and for special card combinations. The first team to reach the target score wins the game. Partnership Sheepshead simplifies the game by removing the bidding and dynamic partnership elements, making it more straightforward while maintaining the core trick-taking mechanics.

games.name: Oh Hell Partnership
games.description: A partnership variant of Oh Hell for exactly four players in two teams. Cards are dealt to each player, and each player bids on the exact number of tricks they'll take. Players then compete in tricks, and partnerships score points for making their exact bid. The team-based format adds an extra layer of strategy as partners must coordinate their bidding and play.

games.name: Progressive Oh Hell
games.description: A variant of Oh Hell where the number of cards dealt changes each round in a progressive pattern. The game starts with just 1 card per player, then increases round by round until reaching the maximum number of cards, then decreases back down. Each player bids on the exact number of tricks they'll take, and players score points for making their exact bid. This progressive structure creates a unique challenge as players must adapt their strategy to different hand sizes throughout the game.

games.name: Wizard Junior
games.description: A simplified version of Wizard designed for children, using a standard deck plus wizards and jesters (jokers). The game features simpler rules than standard Wizard while maintaining the core mechanics of trick-taking and bidding. Each player bids on the exact number of tricks they'll take, then players compete in tricks. Players score points for making their exact bid, making it accessible for younger players while still teaching strategic thinking.

games.name: Wizard Partnership
games.description: A partnership variant of Wizard for exactly four players in two teams. The game uses a standard deck plus wizards and jesters (jokers), which act as the highest and lowest cards respectively. Each player bids on the exact number of tricks they'll take, then players compete in tricks. Partnerships score points together for making their exact bids, requiring coordination and communication between partners to succeed.

games.name: Jack of Diamonds
games.description: A Hearts variant where the jack of diamonds has special scoring value. Like standard Hearts, the goal is to avoid taking penalty cards: each heart is worth 1 point and the queen of spades is worth 13 points. However, the jack of diamonds is worth -10 points, meaning it actually reduces your score if you take it. This creates an interesting strategic element where players may want to take the jack of diamonds to offset penalty points from hearts. The player with the lowest score wins.

games.name: Spot Hearts
games.description: A Hearts variant where the point value of hearts is determined by their face value rather than all being worth 1 point. The ace of hearts is worth 14 points, the king of hearts is worth 13 points, the queen of hearts is worth 12 points, and so on down to the 2 of hearts worth 2 points. The queen of spades remains worth 13 points. This scoring system makes higher-value hearts much more dangerous to take, adding strategic depth as players must consider not just avoiding hearts, but specifically avoiding high-value hearts. The player with the lowest score wins.

games.name: Domino Hearts
games.description: A Hearts variant that follows the same basic rules as standard Hearts: each heart is worth 1 penalty point and the queen of spades is worth 13 penalty points. The game continues until one player reaches or exceeds 100 points, at which point the player with the lowest score wins. The name 'Domino Hearts' refers to the cascading effect that can occur when players are forced to take penalty cards, potentially leading to a player quickly accumulating points.

games.name: Omnibus Hearts
games.description: A Hearts variant that combines multiple special rules. Like standard Hearts, each heart is worth 1 penalty point and the queen of spades is worth 13 points. However, the jack of diamonds is worth -10 points, providing a way to reduce your score. Additionally, players can 'shoot the moon' by taking all hearts and the queen of spades, which typically reverses the scoring (giving all other players the penalty points instead). The player with the lowest score wins.

games.name: Mirror Nil
games.description: A Spades variant for exactly four players in partnerships where teams sit across from each other. Like standard Spades, spades are always the trump suit and players bid on how many tricks they'll take. This variant allows players to bid 'blind nil' (bidding zero tricks without looking at their cards), which adds significant risk and reward. Partnerships score points for making their bids, and the team-based format requires coordination between partners.

games.name: Suicide Spades
games.description: A Spades variant for exactly four players in partnerships with restrictive bidding rules. Like standard Spades, spades are always the trump suit and partnerships score for making their bids. However, in this variant, players must bid at least one trick and cannot bid nil (zero tricks). This eliminates the strategic option of nil bids, forcing all players to commit to taking at least one trick, which changes the dynamic of the game significantly.

games.name: Spades Whist
games.description: A Spades variant for exactly four players in partnerships that removes the bidding element. Like standard Spades, spades are always the trump suit, making them the most powerful cards. However, there is no bidding phase - players simply compete in tricks, and the partnership that takes the most tricks wins the round. This simpler format focuses purely on trick-taking skill without the strategic complexity of bidding.

games.name: Cutthroat Spades
games.description: A Spades variant for exactly three players played without partnerships. Each player bids individually on how many tricks they'll take, then players compete in tricks with spades always serving as the trump suit. Players score individually for making their bids, creating a competitive free-for-all where each player must fend for themselves. The three-player format and lack of partnerships make this a more cutthroat, individual-focused version of Spades.

games.name: Boston Whist
games.description: A Whist variant for exactly four players in partnerships. Each player receives 13 cards, and a trump suit is determined before play begins. Players compete in tricks, following suit when possible, and the highest card of the led suit or the highest trump wins each trick. Partnerships score points for tricks won, and the game follows the traditional Whist structure with partnership play.

games.name: Bid Whist
games.description: A Whist variant for exactly four players in partnerships that adds a bidding phase. Before play begins, players bid on how many tricks their partnership will take, adding strategic depth to the game. After bidding, players compete in tricks with a trump suit determined during bidding. Partnerships score points for making their exact bid, requiring careful coordination between partners to succeed.

games.name: Duplicate Whist
games.description: A tournament format of Whist where the same hands are played by multiple tables simultaneously. This format eliminates luck as a factor, as all partnerships play with identical cards. After all tables complete play, scores are compared to determine which partnerships performed best with the given hands. This format is commonly used in competitive Whist tournaments to ensure fair competition.

games.name: Hoyle Whist
games.description: A Whist variant for exactly four players in partnerships that follows the rules established by Edmond Hoyle, the famous card game authority. The game follows traditional Whist structure with partnerships competing in tricks, following suit when possible, and scoring points for tricks won. Hoyle's codification of the rules helped standardize Whist play and establish it as a formal card game.

games.name: Duplicate Bridge
games.description: The most common tournament format for Bridge, where the same hands are played by multiple tables simultaneously. This format eliminates luck as a factor since all partnerships play with identical cards. After all tables complete play, scores are compared using matchpoint or IMP (International Match Points) scoring to determine which partnerships performed best with the given hands. Duplicate Bridge is the standard format for competitive Bridge tournaments worldwide.

games.name: Rubber Bridge
games.description: The traditional format of Bridge for exactly four players, played in rubbers. A rubber consists of the best of three games, where a partnership must win two games to win the rubber. Partnerships score points for both individual games and for winning rubbers, with bonus points awarded for winning a rubber. This format was the standard way to play Bridge before duplicate Bridge became popular in tournaments, and it remains a favorite for casual and social play.

games.name: Chicago Bridge
games.description: A Bridge variant for exactly four players that uses a fixed format of four deals per round. Vulnerability (which affects scoring bonuses and penalties) rotates systematically through the four deals, following a predetermined pattern. Partnerships score points for making their contracts, and the format provides a structured way to play Bridge in a time-limited setting, making it popular for casual and club play.

games.name: Mini Bridge
games.description: A simplified version of Bridge designed to be easier to learn, removing the complex bidding phase. Instead of bidding, the declarer is determined by which player holds the highest card. Players then compete in tricks, and partnerships score points for tricks won. This format allows players to learn the trick-taking and card play aspects of Bridge without mastering the bidding system first, making it an excellent introduction to the game.

games.name: Lone Hand Euchre
games.description: An Euchre variant for exactly four players in partnerships, using only 24 cards (9 through Ace of each suit). In this variant, a player can choose to 'go alone' against the other three players, playing without their partner. If successful, the lone player scores higher points than a normal partnership win, but the risk is greater since they must win the required number of tricks without their partner's help. This adds a high-risk, high-reward strategic element to the game.

games.name: Stick the Dealer Euchre
games.description: An Euchre variant for exactly four players in partnerships, using only 24 cards (9 through Ace of each suit). In this variant, if all other players pass on accepting the trump suit, the dealer must accept it and cannot pass. This 'sticks' the dealer with the trump suit, forcing them to play even if they have a weak hand. This rule prevents games from being passed around indefinitely and ensures every hand is played.

games.name: Pepper
games.description: An Euchre variant for exactly four players in partnerships, using only 24 cards (9 through Ace of each suit). The game follows the same rules as standard Euchre, but is played to 7 points instead of 10, making it a faster-paced version. This shorter format is ideal for quick games or when time is limited, while maintaining all the strategic elements and partnership play of standard Euchre.

games.name: Railroad Euchre
games.description: An Euchre variant that can be played with 5 or 6 players, using only 24 cards (9 through Ace of each suit). Unlike standard Euchre where partnerships are fixed, in Railroad Euchre the calling of trump determines the partnerships dynamically. The player who calls trump becomes the declarer and chooses a partner, creating shifting alliances that add excitement and variety to the game. This format accommodates larger groups while maintaining the fast-paced trick-taking gameplay of Euchre.

games.name: Auction Partnership Pinochle
games.description: A Pinochle variant for exactly four players in partnerships, using a special 48-card deck with duplicate cards (two of each card from 9 through Ace). The game features auction bidding where players bid on how many points they'll score, and the highest bidder becomes the declarer. Partnerships score points for both melds (card combinations) and tricks won. The auction format adds strategic depth as partnerships must balance aggressive bidding with realistic assessment of their hands.

games.name: Tournament Pinochle
games.description: A Pinochle variant for exactly four players in partnerships, using a special 48-card deck with duplicate cards (two of each card from 9 through Ace). This format follows standardized tournament rules, with partnerships competing in tricks and scoring points for both melds (card combinations) and tricks won. The tournament format ensures consistent rules and scoring across all games, making it suitable for competitive play and organized events.

games.name: Hand and Foot Tournament
games.description: A tournament format of Hand and Foot Canasta for four to six players in partnerships. The game follows the standard Hand and Foot rules where each player has two hands (a 'hand' and a 'foot'), and players must play from their hand first before accessing their foot. Partnerships must form canastas (melds of 7 or more cards) to go out. The tournament format uses standardized rules and scoring, making it suitable for competitive play and organized events.

games.name: Samba Tournament
games.description: A tournament format of Samba Canasta for exactly four players in partnerships. Samba is a Canasta variant that allows sequences (runs) in addition to sets, and partnerships must form canastas to go out. The tournament format uses standardized rules and scoring, ensuring consistent play across all games in competitive settings.

games.name: Bolivian Canasta Tournament
games.description: A tournament format of Bolivian Canasta for exactly four players in partnerships. Bolivian Canasta is a Rummy-style game where partnerships form melds of 7 or more cards called canastas, using two decks with jokers. This variant features different scoring rules than standard Canasta. The tournament format uses standardized rules and scoring, making it suitable for competitive play.

games.name: Muggins
games.description: A Cribbage variant for two players that adds a penalty element to scoring. Like standard Cribbage, players count points for pairs, runs, and combinations that total 15 or 31 using a pegging board. However, if a player fails to count all their points, the opponent can claim those missed points (called 'muggins'). This rule adds extra pressure to count accurately and rewards attentive play. The first player to reach 121 points wins.

games.name: Lowball Cribbage
games.description: A Cribbage variant for two players that reverses the standard scoring objective. Like standard Cribbage, players count points for pairs, runs, and combinations that total 15 or 31 using a pegging board. However, in this variant, the lowest score wins instead of the highest. Players must count their points but try to minimize them, and the first player to reach a negative target score loses. This creates an interesting strategic twist on the classic game.

games.name: Oklahoma Gin Rummy
games.description: A Gin Rummy variant for two players where the upcard (the first card turned up from the discard pile) determines the knock card value. Players form sets and runs, trying to be the first to use all their cards. If the upcard is a spade, players need 5 or less deadwood (unmatched cards) to knock, adding an extra strategic element. The first player to reach 100 points wins the game.

games.name: Hollywood Gin Scoring
games.description: A Gin Rummy variant for two players that uses Hollywood scoring, where three simultaneous games are played and tracked separately. Players form sets and runs, trying to be the first to use all their cards in each game. The games end at different times as players reach the target score, creating a complex scoring system where points from each game are tracked independently. This format adds excitement as players can be winning one game while losing another.

games.name: 500 Rummy Tournament
games.description: A tournament format of 500 Rummy for two to eight players with points-based scoring. Players meld sets and runs, and can lay off cards on existing melds. The tournament format uses standardized rules and scoring, with the first player to reach 500 points winning. This format ensures consistent play across all games in competitive settings.

games.name: Kalooki Tournament
games.description: A tournament format of Kalooki Rummy for two to four players. Kalooki is a Rummy variant where jokers are wild cards, and players must make an initial meld worth at least 40 points before they can lay down cards. The tournament format uses standardized rules and scoring, ensuring consistent play across all games in competitive settings.
